content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I actually really enjoyed and still enjoy this game. True, everything about this game is dated, the graphics though good then seem poor now and the interactions between you and in game NPCS range from linear to non-existent. That being said, I love this game, it is dark, gritty, and really gives you that predatory sense you would expect from being on top of the food chain. The dialogue that you do experience between your character and other characters never feels forced and is almost always engaging. Additionally I want to say,  being Malkavian is so entertaining that even though the general story does not change regardless of what clan you pick, it feels like a completely different experience.  This game gives out multiple endings, with interesting plot twists and a whole ranges of level concepts ranging from frightening to pure combat. My only real complaint about this game are in the in game cut scenes, I don't know exactly what it is, but the models at times look so hunched over and walk like they have too poop sometimes that I get actively annoyed. All that being said, definitely worth exploring the world of darkness if you got the time.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												I'm not normally a fan of Vampire games, but I picked up this one upon recommendation by a friend, and holy cow is it good! Important points include:1) There are violent encounters you can turn into diplomatic ones, if you're very diplomatic.2) There are stealth encounters you can turn into shoot 'em up encounters, if you're inclined.3) The game is reasonably faithful to the tabletop, but makes some pretty clear changes to make it a good video game.4) There's a mission where you're supposed to get rid of a ghost. It just might be the scariest mission in the whole game, and you don't fight a single monster or enemy the whole time.5) If you play the game as a Malkavian, your flaw is that you're crazy. So they changed all the dialogue options to reflect this, voiced over responses to your crazy talk, and made a few other changes to make it really work.6) This is the first time since high school that I felt like I really wanted to play a vampire tabletop game.NOTE: The unofficial patch (now in version 9.0) is basically required to play this game on a modern computer. You can get it here: http://www.patches-scrolls.com/vampire_bloodlines.php

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23
												This is by the far the best single vampire game in existence.There have been countless vampire games through the years.  Some focus on the monster, some focus on the romance,  Most you don't particularly have to think about all the consequences of becoming one.  This game will immerse you in a seductive and dangerous world of vampirism the likes of which has not been replicated to this degree in a game.  And when I say you, I mean you.  It is a deeply personal affair in which you can take a personal journey or a journey of any character you wish, with whatever depth you wish.Do you want to be the outcasts of society?  Do you want to be the Hollywood monster that people avert their gaze from?  Do you want to be the Anne Rice version of a vampire?  Smart, seductive, ruthless.  Do you want to be utterly insane?  So many ways to make yourself your own, so many ways to interact with the myriad of story lines in the dark, urban nightlife of Cali.The music is also phenomenal.  Utterly fantastic.  The soundtrack feels dark and gritty while you're wandering the streets, diving in sewers and popping in night clubs seducing and making your way.Modding is REQUIRED.  I say again, R E Q U I R E D.  Don't think about playing this without extensive research on the must have mods.  The story of this title is infamous, go read if you want to know why it requires so much rework and how passionate this community around it is.  I did the unofficial patch and a few graphic overall mods myself, your mileage may vary.Writing this review makes me want to install it again and play...If you have any interest of vampires whatsoever, pick it up!

content:
Posted: February 28
												As a huge fan of the VTM tabletop game, I'll admit, I was skeptical when I first bought this.  Sometimes adapting one media into another (be it book to movie, game to movie or, in this case, one type of game to another), it either loses something or gains WAY too much to be enjoyable to longtime fans of whatever the previous media was.  So, yeah, I had my doubts -- but let me tell you, they were entirely unfounded.  This has become one of my favorite (if not absolute favorite) RPGs of all time.  Not only does it stay true to the source, which was a big selling point for me, but it is so incredibly easy to become immersed in the world you're presented.  The atmosphere is wonderful, especially for an older game when creating those elements is a bit more limited than it is now; maybe it's just me, but while wandering around Santa Monica, L.A., and the rest, I definitely do get that feeling of 'city by night'.  Lots of memorable NPCs scattered about, and the combat system is..fair, I think.  A little wonky here and there, but for the most part, it's pretty smooth.  That your decisions/dialogue affect some aspects of gameplay is always a neat element, too,  and as an added bonus:  no sparkly, wussy vampires.  That goes along with 'staying true to the source', yes, but for anyone who can't help but roll their eyes upon seeing 'vampire', it's worth calling attention to this.Really, I can only find two major downfalls for this game:  first and foremost would be the graphics.  While again, it is a beautiful game, especially for its age, it certainly could benefit from some better visuals, especially where player characters and NPCs are concerned.  This isn't super important to me or anything, as it doesn't take...well, anything, away from the game, but it is worth mentioning.  Second would be the fact that there is no fast travel while in a zone.  It DOES help with immersion, I'll admit, and it's not like the zones are HUGE, by any means, but sometimes it does seem tedious to have to run from point A to point B.All in all, thought, this game is absolutely fantastic.  It's hardly perfect, but for anyone who enjoys RPGs, I cannot possibly recommend this one enough.  This is just one of those games where, every time someone mentions it, someone else will just HAVE to reinstall it.  It's just THAT good.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2011
												This game, moreso than any others I've played, embodies the word "classic". Though buggy and unpolished in its original state of release, the unofficial patch allows this title to reach its full potential: an experience that completely draws you into its gloomy, thoroughly immersive settings, with characters so vibrant as to make you almost think - and certainly wish - that you were carrying on conversations with the most intriguing individuals you could ever imagine. The class customization and dialogue options allow you to feel like you're shaping your own destiny, and progression is steady and fairly well paced, so that by the end, you feel like you're ready to step into whatever epic showdown awaits. With atmospheric music, witty personalities, unique game mechanics, and absolutely top-notch voice-acting, this is a  vampire adventure you'd be sorry you missed out on.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												This is a great game! If you can get it to work. That's right. Before buying VTMB, you should know what you're getting yourself into. The game was never finished; it was released as an imcomplete, buggy, broken product - and that's what it still is, even today. Teams of modders have been working on it to either fix as many bugs as they could or even to rebalance and redesign it and to install one of the unofficial patches is, after installing the game to your hard drive, the very first thing you should do; but even so, be prepared for a world of bugs, crashes, google searches, .exe replacing, .cfg tweaking and so on.Let me tell you about my experience with this game. I bought it. Then, I installed Tessara's gold patch which, supposedly (and I have no reason to think otherwise) does an amazing job at fixing all the imaginable problems this game was released with. Then I had to find a way to make the screen resolution acceptable (not 1024*768, this isn't 1999 anymore). Then I was on the street and I noticed a loss of framerate, so I tweaked the .cfg file to deactivate meteo effects. After a couple hours I reached a beach and the game started crashing, forcing my computer into sleep mode. I couldn't get past that beach. Later on I found that the sea's texture was making my comps go bananas so I went for more .cfg tweaking. Then I played a couple more hours and the AI, suddenly, disabled itself - meaning, NPCs froze in place, making the game completely unplayable. Then, as I was looking for a solution, my comps started crashing again.That was it. I decided to wait a year or two for the (unbelievably dedicated) teams of modders who were working at fixing this game, and uninstalled Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.Now don't get me wrong - some people (with Tessara's help in any case) are able to play VTMB just fine. I was able to play for like 5 hours and it was great - dark, immersive, great attention to detail, thrilling game system, great infiltration sequences... It feels like Deus Ex all over again. It feels like a pen & paper experience where I'm alone with the game master. It feels great.But it's ♥♥♥♥ing unstable. It's broken. Anyone considering purchasing this game should know that there's a risk that it won't work at all, that you'll spend as much time fixing it as playing it. Buying this game is a gamble - you're risking your money here.But, again, when it works, whoa, guys - what a ride!

												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, is a near perfect gaming experience despite coming across hundreds of flaws in most every aspect of the game, from the visuals, audio, optimization, rushed mechanics, poor save files, and so forth... Bloodlines suffers from a plagued development, and is far from finished, but comes across as a product both greatly entertaining and lengthy in gameplay. Utilizing the HL2 Source engine, Bloodlines is easily modifiable, and as such many fan made community patches are in circulation around the internet. I highly recommend downloading these patches for a more refined and polished gaming experience (although it is optional as the game is still playable all the way through without said patches). Bloodlines delivers exceptional voice acting, a grim and atmospheric setting, a fantastically agreeable soundtrack, a fair amount of character customization, and at times, a fair amount of role-playing choices, all for a low sum of 20 bucks, and believe me folks - with said amount of issues, it's still very much worth it.

												This game is buggy as all hell with horrible combat and glitches to put you in a state of rage, but I still enjoy it. I hate some of the aged mechanics as much as I love them. Vampire Bloodlines has all these faults but also nostalgic charm. It's set in a goth/punk world with great music, atmosphere and just a berserk personality all on its own. There are many quests and 5 endings to explore but I recommened checking out GameBanshee to guide you along the way for the sewers are difficult to navigate. Also helps you save on EPs and hooks you up with more info about the clans. This game sucks sometimes but I believe its worth the adventure.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												This is a great older RPG with a dark atmosphere and interesting background lore. You don't just deal with vampires. Just a few things you do are investigate a haunted house, rummage through a serial killers' abode, and make your way through an abandoned hospital to discover what has been dragging people to the basement. There are also numerous moral choices in the game and multiple endings. The game offers major replayability due the numerous possibilities through clan selection. Although, I reccommend not doing the Malkavian clan or the Nosferatu until your second playthrough given how much they alter the game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Have you ever played Deus Ex and thought to yourself, "This game is great, but it wouldn't it be awesome if instead of a Cyberpunk setting it had Vampires?" Well that is exactly what this game is like and it has a very complex structure of Vampire that I've frankly, never seen before where there are many different races of Vampire each with their own distinct look, personality traits, and strengths/weaknesses, for example, the Malkavians are absoultely insane and have different personalities talking in their head and see telephone lines swaying constantly in the air and people will be a little off-put by you (if you choose to be this class...this is exactly what you'll see and hear as well along with crazy dialogue options)The gameplay is more or less exactly like Deus Ex with more modern day weaponry and the fact that in order to use your special ablities you need blood which you can either drink a blood pack or find a victim and follow them into a back alley and have a buffet delight.The story is also very intriguing and is inline with the lore from the tabletop games where its essentially about this ancient vampire coming back to life and eating Vampires and causing the end of the world.I'd recommend this game to anybody really and especially those who are a fan of Deus Ex, Vampires, or fans of RPG/Action games. This is another really underrated game that definitely should get more sequels (comeon Activision, I know you have it in your black heart somewhere!) If you see it during a sale for about $10, which is rare, think about picking it up because you shouldn't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												This game is amazing.  I actually stood around a radio in this game just to listen to each radio program loop in each game chapter because it was so damn entertaining.  This game is loaded with so much awesome stuff, and the humor in it is great.  It's a shame these guys when out of business, they had the potential to make games as good as anything Bethesda has put out.   A note about all the people complaining about this game needing a patch to run: Of course it does, morons, stop your whining.  This game was made to run on an operating system that's been obsolete for over a decade (and people could argue that Windows ME/2000/XP/etc were garbage when they came out), and the company that made the game was crushed and is long gone, of course you will need to DL a patch to run it.  The good news is that these patches also fix bugs that were originally issues in the game.  So look up and follow the easy to install patches, it's totally worth it (and they are free, so ... yeah).    This game is also worth multiple play-throughs, which can be hard to find with linear story/plot games.  As each clan (and gender) has some different perks, playing through more than once can be rewarding.  And if you haven't played as a Malkavian (the crazy ones), that is always good for a last play-through for the whole game.   Great for any fan of Vampire the Masquerade, great for any vampire genre fan, great for any FP/RPG game lover.  I played this a LONG time ago, and playing again now is just as fun, and it is still an impressive game.  I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												“Remember, wherever we go, it is the blood of Caine which makes our fate.”Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines is a great role-playing game with an immersive dark atmosphere, authentic characters and a solid storyline, that does the game justice. The bloodline (clan) you choose will affect your relationship with other characters, the available quests and the choices presented to you throughout the game, offering plenty of variation and replayability. While the A.I. is simple and pretty straight forward, the game often gives you several ways to solve a situation, including combat, stealth and rhetorical possibilities. The unbalanced combat mechanics are the weakest link of the game, which can create partially frustrating combat situations. The official support for this game was stopped in 2005, leaving it behind with numerous bugs. The fan community has released an unofficial patch, which addresses most of the issues and can be found on the link below (thanks to Voxel).http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647To fix the runtime error, try the following link (thanks to Zzero).http://steamcommunity.com/app/2400/discussions/3/846959521009517711/Fun Fact: The several different vampire clans and their various strengths and weaknesses are based on the tabletop role-playing franchise Vampire: The Masquerade. --My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere-	Characters-	Details-	Tactical gameplay-	Story-	Combat & ControlsBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: S-Rank(Ah, your’re gonna love this! Alright, check it out. Blood: It’s your new rack o’lamb, your new champagne – blood’s your new ♥♥♥♥in’ heroin, kid.)Characters: S-Rank (I am the proprietor and salesman of the month several years in a row; the ladies call me “Oh, god!”, but you can call me Fat Larry with F-A-T, ‘cause I know I got a weight problem and I just don’t give a ♥♥♥♥.)Details: S-Rank (Man, we got everything you’ll ever need. Softcore, hardcore, gay, straight, farm or furry. We got shockers, shiverers, self-lubricators and strap-ons. Chains, crops and canes are in the back next to the triple-ripple. Like I said, we got it all.)Tactical gameplay: A-Rank Story: B-Rank Combat & Controls: C-Rank --There are no achievements to conquer.Achievement difficulty: none--Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines (PC) – First-person role-playing game(Dark Fantasy) – 2004-Vampire: The Masquerade – Redemption (PC) – Action role-playing game Dark Fantasy) – 2000

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Know that if you get this game, there is a decent chance that it will need some tweaking to even run.  The instructions to do this can be found here.http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/forumdisplay.php?f=229Talking to people, I cannot pinpoint the reason that some new computers will run it without the fix and some will not.This game is old and the people that made it are out of business.  Steam has posted it up here basically "As-Is", without warning us.  While I have the assurance of many Steam users that this game is excellent, I have yet to play it as I haven't felt like jumping through the hoops.Granted that patching or modding older games to work has been a staple of PC gaming for years, shouldn't we be past that in the age of digital distribution? I am appealing to Steam here, you are the future(some would argue the present) of PC gaming distribution, putting a game for sale that has issues with so many modern computers is step backwards.This is the edited version of the review based on input from other users.(you can find my original dissapointment filled review below)----This game crashes as soon as you run it.  If you want, you can follow guides like some kind of treasure map to get it to run but that kind of misses the point of steam.Knowing the bad press that would come from this, Steam requires a 5 minute play-time minimum before posting a review, so I ran the game and let it crash over and over until i got to 5 minutes.  Hopefully I can reach a few people to spread the message that, instead of buying a fun vampire game, you are being the target of an insidious cash grab.Shame on the game's makers for it not being fixed and shame on Steam for selling it.----

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												One of the best ARPG games ever made. It's a "flawed gem," as somebody once said. This game gets my highest recommendation, and is one of my all-time favorites.+ Extremely atmospheric:Each location in this game leaves a lasting impression. From the music to the aesthetics, this game will draw you into it's dark world and have you enthralled.+ Interesting, memorable characters:I can remember the names of many of the minor characters in this game. The characters are all expressive, with interesting dialogue options. I really enjoyed the voice acting.+ Very high replay value:There are many different clans to play in this game, all with their own unique abilities and dialogue options. You'll find something new in this game every time you play it.The only drawback are the bugs, but the worst and most game-breaking of them have been fixed in a fan-made unofficial patch. That said, some bugs still exist, but they're all easily overlooked and in no way stop the progression of the game.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Everytime you mention Bloodlines, someone installs it, or so it's said.Anyway, onto the review!Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines has a ridiculous title but that's alright. It's based off a tabletop RPG called Vampire: The Masquerade by White Wolf Publishing.It's set in Los Angeles by night where the player controls their own vampire. There are seven clans to choose from and each has their own "thing". There's a clan which focuses on art, one that speaks in riddles, one that lurks in the shadows etc (Also adds replayability!). The PC is sadly not customisable, but it's possible to play as female or male. Gender doesn't have a very big impact on the game, but it affects NPC interaction a couple of times.There's also some crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥going down in game. I won't be going into too much details but it can be kinda scary sometimes. Also there will be gore, sex and even a snuff movie. And maybe about two jump scares.BUT WAIT. Luckily there's a console in case you really don't want to/can't do something. Hooray!There's no such game as levels in the game. Like a real RPG, there's a character sheet and you can upgrade your abilities by spending experience, which you get from completing quests.Questing is fairly fun in this game. There's no such thing as mindless farming! The first challenge is getting the quest, through picking the right dialogue. In some cases, if you pick the wrong dialogue you're missing out on quests and thus, experience.Quests can be completed in different manners. You can either kill everything, stealth and in some cases just with dialogue, which is nice for the lazy people among us. Sometimes it affects the experience gain though. (For example, getting 3 XP instead of 2 if you aren't seen).Combat is decent-ish, but at least you can switch between first- and third-person perspective.The game isn't sandbox, but there are a few hubs you can go to as you progress through the game. You can travel as much as you want, as you have your personal vampire cabdriver! Awesome!NPCs are all voiced and depending on the clan, even the whispers in your PCs head too! Isn't that fun, you'll never be lonely again! Anyway, it kinda adds to the already dark atmosphere of the game.And unlike a lot of games, choices DO matter, throughout the whole game. If you aren't nice to someone, you might miss out on a quest/experience/ending.The downside is that combat becomes more important as you get closer to the ending. This is probably because the developers were in a rush to finish the game. The vanilla game has some game-breaking bugs even, but if you use a patch by Wesp the game is definitely play-able.There are also a lot of loading screens. Fortunately, loading times aren't long.True, it's not a game for everyone. But what game is? BUT. IN THIS GAME...You'll meet fellow vampires, werewolves, ghosts, zombies and humans!You can be nice, sarcastic, or really mean!Your vampire can dance just as good as you can!Also you can make people explode so their blood is everywhere. Did I mention that? 'Cause that's cool you know.For a rushed game from 2004, it has a lot of mods and some even revamp whole game mechanics. So I guess it's kinda hard to get bored of it.Ten years and going strong!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5
												There isn't much I can say about this game that hasn't already been said, but since this has become one of my top five favorite games of all time, I have to leave a review.There are very few RPGs that have this level of depth. Fantastic atmosphere with fleshed out NPCs. Excellent writing is complimented by voice acting. The clan you choose and the choices you make have a direct effect on how the world responds to you and on how the story unfolds, which has become increasingly rare in modern games. Your choices have consequences that open and close doors. There's a lot of replay value just in exploring the "what ifs". That being said, it is an unfinished game, and the gameplay leaves something to be desired. You /have/ to install a fanmade patch in order to be able to even complete the game, which is why I have so few hours logged since I forgot to have it launch via Steam. Even with it intalled there are some bugs that I needed to fix with the console. Combat is clunky and the unavoidable camera change in melee is annoying. Some skills become very unviable in late game. However, I do like the perk system and how there is a real feel of progression. Obviously the graphics are going to be dated since it's a thirteen year old game, but I think they hold up pretty well and it's not a deal breaker for me, especially since I don't own a powerful gaming PC.Overall, Bloodline's succesions highly outweight its shortcomings. If Troika hadn't been rushed and had time to fully develop and complete this game, I have no doubt it would be considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time.

												Excellent and atmospheric action RPG - various choices in the way you play & complete missions and the way you fight, an engrossing story with brilliant voice acting to back it up (Joe DiMaggio as a biker vampire, nuff said), rounded off with a mix of great audio ambience and music (Bloodlines by Ministry and Swamped by Luna Coil are the two stand outs).One cavet: you really must install the unoficial patch (currently available via http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patchalphabet/v failing this link search 'vampire bloodlines unofficial patch' should find you a link), it not only fixes outstanding issues, but really puts the polish on.Now if we could've just had that Werewolf - The Forsaken game as well...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												I would like to note that before anyone buys this, it will NOT RUN on modern machines unless you install fanmade patches. ( http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035 ) In this day and age vampires are often a mockery in pop culture, thanks in large part to sensations like Twilight. But let me tell you, this game has no glittering pretty boys. It's a true painting of what the modern vampire should be- they walk among us in society because they look like us, often using their intelligence and sex appeal to feed and maintain their powers. The game largely focuses on the politics within vampire society known as The Masquerade- it's this web of politics that sends you off on several quests where, depending on how you've chosen to level your character and converse in dialogue with NPCs can play out very differently. The side quests are also very compelling. And I'm usually incredibly disinterested in these- the lore and the characters are all just so well written it made me want to explore the game more.If you're looking for an obscure gem, excellent writing, unique atmosphere, or just tired of seeing Vampires suck♥♥♥♥♥like they have been in recent years this game is up your alley.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2012
												This is what I call a good electronic RPG.Not only because you can build and evolve your character, but more importantly:- story is good and makes sense,- nice atmosphere,- your choices do make difference (without the usual need to play the good boy to get more rewards)- your character's clan and stats define which options you have on dialogues (Malkavian dialogues are awesome! Specially if you have Dementia power...)If you like the pen-and-paper Vampire: The Masquerade you'll probably enjoy this game. It is a very nice implementation of the World of Darkness, and you know, vampires aren't the only supernatural creatures in the night...Only three issues bothered me (but were not enough to make me quit playing):1- streets sometimes feel too empty, but than you remember you're a vampire and it's probably late at night! Also you'll probably be thankful for that, after all, you don't really want people discovering you're a vampire all the time ;-)2- you need to install an unofficial patch (at least on my Win7 64 bits, the game was broken without the patch)3- for those used to the pen-and-paper Vampire, some of the disciplines were replaced by new ones due to limitations of a PC game, but they are still nice;I really recommend this one!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines was originally released November 16, 2004 It was developed by the ill-fated Troika games and published by Activision. Unfortunately, this was also the release date of Valve Softwares magnum opus, Half-Life 2. Vampire, like Half-Life 2, made excellent use of the Source Engine developed by Valve. However, since this game was using the brand new Source Engine, it was not allowed to release before Half-Life 2. This alone made Activison decide to "crack the whip" at Troika and push the release date to that of Half-Life 2. Ultimately, this lead to the game being riddled with bugs at release.  Troika, unable to find funding, laid off all of it's employees in several waves over time. Despite this, several employees developed a patch for the game without pay. Three weeks after the games release patch 1.2 released and official support of the game was shuttered. Despite this, even nearly ten years later, this game is still supported by fan patches developed by Wesp5. This review is written based on experiences with fan patch 9.0Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines is a video game translation of White Wolf Publishings table top rpg, Vampire: The Masquerade. By translation, I mean this in an almost litteral sense. The game mimics the table top rpgs systems exceedingly well, right down to the way the character sheet works. You are actively encouraged through out the game to actually play your role in the twisted tale that is woven for you. Humanity, or the lack thereof, is one of the key features in the game. Can you (your character) pretend to still be human, integrating yourself into society, while being a Vampire. Killing an innocent on the streets will make you lose a humanity point, further driving home the fact that you are a supernatural beast. Lose too many humanity points and you may frenzy if you run out of the games main resource, blood. Going into a frenzy unleashes the savage beast within you, temporarily causing you to lose all control of your character. One of the other key elements of the game, The Masquerade, challanges you to act human. If anyone sees you doing anything that a Vampire normally would do (using magick, feeding on an npc, etc,) you lose a Masquerade point. Losing these is an astoundingly bad thing. Did that Npc see you feeding on a bum? Yep, and they ran to the cops, you my friend are now being hunted. Sure, losing one point only gets the police on your tail, they are nothing compared to you, you're a damn vampire. But, begin losing more (up to six) and you will have Hunters (one of the games antagonists) or even other vampires after you. The systems from the table top RPG are translated so well into the game it is astounding. So, I just explained some of the systems in the game, while that is all well and good, an rpg would be nothing without a good story and good mechanics to tell it to you. You begin the game with a questionaire of all things. This decides which Vampire clan you will play as. Will you be a melee powerhouse Bruhaj, or will you be a magick centric Tremere? Maybe a stealthy Nosferatu, or the absolutely (literally) insane Malkavian. After a thorough quizzing and assigning points to your character sheet the game begins. Your character is in the throws of passion with a vampire from which ever clan you picked (or were assigned) from the questionaire. You are turned, and are essentially born anew as a vampire.I will be absolutely honest here, this game, it has some of the finest writing, and voice acting, I have ever encountered. I really have to commend Troika for the stellar cast they gathered. A few examples of the voice actors in the game are, Steve Blum (Cowboy Bebop), John DiMaggio (Futurama, Adventure Time), Phil LaMarr (Pulp Fiction, Samurai Jack) and Kathryn Cressida (Tarzan, Dexters Laboratory). All of the voice actors do a phenomenal job of playing the characters they were assigned, you actually believe these characters are apart of a living, breathing, world. The entire game feels as if it is alive. Bums wander the streets of LA, hookers propisition you, cops make your life hell and get in the way. Even politics play a roll in this game. So, the story, is not just a story about your character, it's about the world of Vampire: The Masquerade. From the charismatic leader of the Camarilla, to the "all too happy to be a vampire" Smiling Jack, Troika crafted a story that not only grabs you, but makes you care about what is going on. I don't want to spoil anything of the story, even giving cliff notes of it would be doing a disservice to the reader. This story is one you must truly experience for yourself. The gameplay of Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines may seem familiar at times, after all, this is a story driven RPG. You can play in first or third person, but I recommend a healthy mix of two. While first person mode takes away a good bit of perephrial vision, it makes the experience all the more personal. Speaking to npcs, you are given fully voiced and written dialog, with (for current times) pretty standard RPG choices. Depending on how your character is developed, you can get special dialog in the form of persuasion, intimidation, and even mind control. While it doesn't seem like anything really special now-a-days, back in 2004, this was pretty damn spectacular. The combat, to be honest, is the weakest part of this game. I am by no means, putting the combat down, it is a fully functional, working combat system, that, at sometimes, is a little bit wonky. Transitioning from first person gameplay to third person, at first, is a little jarring, especially if you're fighting with a melee weapon and casting certain spells. Doing this, the game keeps jumping back and forth between third and first person view, and can make combat a little more difficult than it should be. The only black mark that I can find that makes the game even slightly frustrating is the slight bit of downtime you have when casting spells during combat while using a gun. If you're trying to fight enemies while using a firearm and casting spells, the game delays you being able to shoot, reload, or even cast a different spell. This kinda breaks the immersion of the game at times, because it makes fighting certain enemies incredibly frustrating, more than once I had to take a break from playing because fighting the same foe for twenty minutes was grating on my nerves. (Though, this is a slight disclaimer, I was playing a Tremere, the heavy magick using class.) There is still so much I can say about this game, but, I don't want the review to be exceedingly long. Yes I wanted to be thorough, but, all I really want to say is that Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines, with the fan patch 9.0, is an absolutely astounding game. The patch, in addition to making it work on Windows 7 and 8, actually adds back in some content that was missing from the base game. I really have to give it to Wesp5, he really has brought this game back out of the shadows and gotten it the attention it deserves. I cannot recommend this game enough, it is truly, one of the finest games I have played in ages. I give Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines a 9.5 out of 10. The wonderful story, voice acting, and general gameplay make this an absolute treat.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												This game actually made me like vampires, something that I'd never thought would happen. The world and lore are really interesting, and you find yourself reading the loading screen splashes and milking every dialogue tree for all their worth. Sadly, it seems unlikely we'll ever see a similar game in this universe, which is a shame after seeing, reading of hearing about the various supernatural beings inhabiting it. I would've wanted to learn more about the werewolves, the Giovanni, the Society of Leopold any many other things, damnit!It is also a fairly complex RPG, and both creating your character and levelling up will probably require some contemplative chin-stroking and sipping a beverage of your choice. I especially loved the game's multiple social skills, which put Bioware's simplified NICE GUY/BAD GUY systems to shame.Unfortunately, both stealth and combat kind of suck, but they aren't bad enough to be a real annoyance until the game's later quests, when the amount of fighting goes up as the plot intrigue and character interaction goes down.Yes, unfortunately the quality does suffer a bit towards the end, but the journey there will still be memorable enough to heartily recommend this game.NOTE: I played the game with Unofficial Patch v9.2, which fixes bugs and restores cut content

content:
Posted: July 29, 2011
												This game is an amazing adventure through the old World of Darkness, suitable for anyone regardless of experience with the tabletop roleplaying game. For those interested in that, I'd like to note the world in which this game takes place has been rebooted in a new game, and the current analogue to Vampire: The Masquerade is called Vampire: The Requiem. Some terms and ideas still exist, but the very feel of the world and the themes of the game are wholly different. They've switched from the advertised "gothic-punk" atmosphere (a term the company itself uses to describe the old setting) to a more supernatural mystery/thriller feel. Even if you don't intend to play the tabletop game, this is still one of my favorite RPGs, period. Just make sure you go out and download the unofficial patch collection from a mod website. It's still buggy as hell.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												This game is such a delight to anyone a fan of horror and vampires, the attention to detail of gameplay and storyline for a game of the day and age for once it came out is of a unique high quality.The ability to turn from first person shooter to 3rd person at a moments notice for play style makes it versatile and keeps it fresh, full spoken dialog from characters in the world and questlines, the ability to choose and customize yourself/character from a variety of talents to apply to the game to finish objectives, play styles have a wide variety (be a sneaky lockpicking/hacker, a monster of a vampire with a brutish thirsts for blood and chaos, or a socialite with a sharp tongue for manipulation etc etc!). This aspect makes this game very re-playable, if one would like to explore all aspects that the game can offer.The character creation also gives you a variety of vampire clans to choose from, each with their own personal look and place within the world; special attacks and specializations are given for each clan presented depending on which one you choose from, some clans provide abilities that will help cater to the play style that you would wish to use.The beauty of this game is that they're more than one solution to finish a job and it purely depends on how you want to play the game and how you spread out your talent system. I don't want to give too much away but I highly recommend this game! I also recommend that before you play the game that you download the unofficial patch for the game as it removes some of the ingame bugs. http://www.moddb.com/mods/vtmb-unofficial-patchThe link also has a few cool mods to add onto the game like the Final Nights mod that changes the selection of clans in the character creation menu with all new special abilities and all that good stuff (do this after you play the origianls clans/clan if you are looking for more fun!)It's probably a very short review compared to the grand scale of this game has to offer but I hope I helped someone in convincing them to play this great game :D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Everytime you mention Bloodlines, someone installs it, or so it's said.Anyway, onto the review!Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines has a ridiculous title but that's alright. It's based off a tabletop RPG called Vampire: The Masquerade by White Wolf Publishing.It's set in Los Angeles by night where the player controls their own vampire. There are seven clans to choose from and each has their own "thing". There's a clan which focuses on art, one that speaks in riddles, one that lurks in the shadows etc (Also adds replayability!). The PC is sadly not customisable, but it's possible to play as female or male. Gender doesn't have a very big impact on the game, but it affects NPC interaction a couple of times.There's also some crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥going down in game. I won't be going into too much details but it can be kinda scary sometimes. Also there will be gore, sex and even a snuff movie. And maybe about two jump scares.BUT WAIT. Luckily there's a console in case you really don't want to/can't do something. Hooray!There's no such game as levels in the game. Like a real RPG, there's a character sheet and you can upgrade your abilities by spending experience, which you get from completing quests.Questing is fairly fun in this game. There's no such thing as mindless farming! The first challenge is getting the quest, through picking the right dialogue. In some cases, if you pick the wrong dialogue you're missing out on quests and thus, experience.Quests can be completed in different manners. You can either kill everything, stealth and in some cases just with dialogue, which is nice for the lazy people among us. Sometimes it affects the experience gain though. (For example, getting 3 XP instead of 2 if you aren't seen).Combat is decent-ish, but at least you can switch between first- and third-person perspective.The game isn't sandbox, but there are a few hubs you can go to as you progress through the game. You can travel as much as you want, as you have your personal vampire cabdriver! Awesome!NPCs are all voiced and depending on the clan, even the whispers in your PCs head too! Isn't that fun, you'll never be lonely again! Anyway, it kinda adds to the already dark atmosphere of the game.And unlike a lot of games, choices DO matter, throughout the whole game. If you aren't nice to someone, you might miss out on a quest/experience/ending.The downside is that combat becomes more important as you get closer to the ending. This is probably because the developers were in a rush to finish the game. The vanilla game has some game-breaking bugs even, but if you use a patch by Wesp the game is definitely play-able.There are also a lot of loading screens. Fortunately, loading times aren't long.True, it's not a game for everyone. But what game is? BUT. IN THIS GAME...You'll meet fellow vampires, werewolves, ghosts, zombies and humans!You can be nice, sarcastic, or really mean!Your vampire can dance just as good as you can!Also you can make people explode so their blood is everywhere. Did I mention that? 'Cause that's cool you know.For a rushed game from 2004, it has a lot of mods and some even revamp whole game mechanics. So I guess it's kinda hard to get bored of it.Ten years and going strong!

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												One of the best ARPG games ever made. It's a "flawed gem," as somebody once said. This game gets my highest recommendation, and is one of my all-time favorites.+ Extremely atmospheric:Each location in this game leaves a lasting impression. From the music to the aesthetics, this game will draw you into it's dark world and have you enthralled.+ Interesting, memorable characters:I can remember the names of many of the minor characters in this game. The characters are all expressive, with interesting dialogue options. I really enjoyed the voice acting.+ Very high replay value:There are many different clans to play in this game, all with their own unique abilities and dialogue options. You'll find something new in this game every time you play it.The only drawback are the bugs, but the worst and most game-breaking of them have been fixed in a fan-made unofficial patch. That said, some bugs still exist, but they're all easily overlooked and in no way stop the progression of the game.

												This is what I call a good electronic RPG.Not only because you can build and evolve your character, but more importantly:- story is good and makes sense,- nice atmosphere,- your choices do make difference (without the usual need to play the good boy to get more rewards)- your character's clan and stats define which options you have on dialogues (Malkavian dialogues are awesome! Specially if you have Dementia power...)If you like the pen-and-paper Vampire: The Masquerade you'll probably enjoy this game. It is a very nice implementation of the World of Darkness, and you know, vampires aren't the only supernatural creatures in the night...Only three issues bothered me (but were not enough to make me quit playing):1- streets sometimes feel too empty, but than you remember you're a vampire and it's probably late at night! Also you'll probably be thankful for that, after all, you don't really want people discovering you're a vampire all the time ;-)2- you need to install an unofficial patch (at least on my Win7 64 bits, the game was broken without the patch)3- for those used to the pen-and-paper Vampire, some of the disciplines were replaced by new ones due to limitations of a PC game, but they are still nice;I really recommend this one!

												I seriously can not believe I still enjoy this game as much as I did when it first came out (2004). There's definitely something special about this game. The quests in this game are lots of fun, and the characters are likeable. I really enjoy the overall gaming experience.There has been some annoying bugs, and still are a few. Also this game does not originally work on newer PC's running Windows Vista or newer. Thankfully there has been a lot of unofficial patch releases for this game, making it possible to play.If I would ever get the chance to choose a sequel to be made for any game in the world, it would be this one!

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines was originally released November 16, 2004 It was developed by the ill-fated Troika games and published by Activision. Unfortunately, this was also the release date of Valve Softwares magnum opus, Half-Life 2. Vampire, like Half-Life 2, made excellent use of the Source Engine developed by Valve. However, since this game was using the brand new Source Engine, it was not allowed to release before Half-Life 2. This alone made Activison decide to "crack the whip" at Troika and push the release date to that of Half-Life 2. Ultimately, this lead to the game being riddled with bugs at release.  Troika, unable to find funding, laid off all of it's employees in several waves over time. Despite this, several employees developed a patch for the game without pay. Three weeks after the games release patch 1.2 released and official support of the game was shuttered. Despite this, even nearly ten years later, this game is still supported by fan patches developed by Wesp5. This review is written based on experiences with fan patch 9.0Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines is a video game translation of White Wolf Publishings table top rpg, Vampire: The Masquerade. By translation, I mean this in an almost litteral sense. The game mimics the table top rpgs systems exceedingly well, right down to the way the character sheet works. You are actively encouraged through out the game to actually play your role in the twisted tale that is woven for you. Humanity, or the lack thereof, is one of the key features in the game. Can you (your character) pretend to still be human, integrating yourself into society, while being a Vampire. Killing an innocent on the streets will make you lose a humanity point, further driving home the fact that you are a supernatural beast. Lose too many humanity points and you may frenzy if you run out of the games main resource, blood. Going into a frenzy unleashes the savage beast within you, temporarily causing you to lose all control of your character. One of the other key elements of the game, The Masquerade, challanges you to act human. If anyone sees you doing anything that a Vampire normally would do (using magick, feeding on an npc, etc,) you lose a Masquerade point. Losing these is an astoundingly bad thing. Did that Npc see you feeding on a bum? Yep, and they ran to the cops, you my friend are now being hunted. Sure, losing one point only gets the police on your tail, they are nothing compared to you, you're a damn vampire. But, begin losing more (up to six) and you will have Hunters (one of the games antagonists) or even other vampires after you. The systems from the table top RPG are translated so well into the game it is astounding. So, I just explained some of the systems in the game, while that is all well and good, an rpg would be nothing without a good story and good mechanics to tell it to you. You begin the game with a questionaire of all things. This decides which Vampire clan you will play as. Will you be a melee powerhouse Bruhaj, or will you be a magick centric Tremere? Maybe a stealthy Nosferatu, or the absolutely (literally) insane Malkavian. After a thorough quizzing and assigning points to your character sheet the game begins. Your character is in the throws of passion with a vampire from which ever clan you picked (or were assigned) from the questionaire. You are turned, and are essentially born anew as a vampire.I will be absolutely honest here, this game, it has some of the finest writing, and voice acting, I have ever encountered. I really have to commend Troika for the stellar cast they gathered. A few examples of the voice actors in the game are, Steve Blum (Cowboy Bebop), John DiMaggio (Futurama, Adventure Time), Phil LaMarr (Pulp Fiction, Samurai Jack) and Kathryn Cressida (Tarzan, Dexters Laboratory). All of the voice actors do a phenomenal job of playing the characters they were assigned, you actually believe these characters are apart of a living, breathing, world. The entire game feels as if it is alive. Bums wander the streets of LA, hookers propisition you, cops make your life hell and get in the way. Even politics play a roll in this game. So, the story, is not just a story about your character, it's about the world of Vampire: The Masquerade. From the charismatic leader of the Camarilla, to the "all too happy to be a vampire" Smiling Jack, Troika crafted a story that not only grabs you, but makes you care about what is going on. I don't want to spoil anything of the story, even giving cliff notes of it would be doing a disservice to the reader. This story is one you must truly experience for yourself. The gameplay of Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines may seem familiar at times, after all, this is a story driven RPG. You can play in first or third person, but I recommend a healthy mix of two. While first person mode takes away a good bit of perephrial vision, it makes the experience all the more personal. Speaking to npcs, you are given fully voiced and written dialog, with (for current times) pretty standard RPG choices. Depending on how your character is developed, you can get special dialog in the form of persuasion, intimidation, and even mind control. While it doesn't seem like anything really special now-a-days, back in 2004, this was pretty damn spectacular. The combat, to be honest, is the weakest part of this game. I am by no means, putting the combat down, it is a fully functional, working combat system, that, at sometimes, is a little bit wonky. Transitioning from first person gameplay to third person, at first, is a little jarring, especially if you're fighting with a melee weapon and casting certain spells. Doing this, the game keeps jumping back and forth between third and first person view, and can make combat a little more difficult than it should be. The only black mark that I can find that makes the game even slightly frustrating is the slight bit of downtime you have when casting spells during combat while using a gun. If you're trying to fight enemies while using a firearm and casting spells, the game delays you being able to shoot, reload, or even cast a different spell. This kinda breaks the immersion of the game at times, because it makes fighting certain enemies incredibly frustrating, more than once I had to take a break from playing because fighting the same foe for twenty minutes was grating on my nerves. (Though, this is a slight disclaimer, I was playing a Tremere, the heavy magick using class.) There is still so much I can say about this game, but, I don't want the review to be exceedingly long. Yes I wanted to be thorough, but, all I really want to say is that Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines, with the fan patch 9.0, is an absolutely astounding game. The patch, in addition to making it work on Windows 7 and 8, actually adds back in some content that was missing from the base game. I really have to give it to Wesp5, he really has brought this game back out of the shadows and gotten it the attention it deserves. I cannot recommend this game enough, it is truly, one of the finest games I have played in ages. I give Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines a 9.5 out of 10. The wonderful story, voice acting, and general gameplay make this an absolute treat.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												A game every RPG fan should play.It takes place in LA, putting you in the shoes – or heels – of a freshly made vampire. They have a secret society and live among us with a certain set of rules to maintain order and ensure that their existence won't become widespread knowledge. This is the Masquerade. You become the new pawn for the local leader in his political wars. Not all is well in vampire community, and some factions are eager to change things.It's a comfortable entry – just as you're in the dark, so is your character, letting the two of you learn together who's who and what's what in vampire life. It's a pretty crazy one, too. Violence and sex are plentiful and the game doesn't shy from either. You'll find it hard, and not too rewarding, to play your regular Good Hero sort. It's also a very humorous game with plenty of moments that made me chuckle. The voice acting is terrific and there are many great characters. I found myself often just standing still and listening to the in-game news report on the TV, or the late-night radio show for the laughs. The story develops in unexpected ways and the ending managed to surprise me. Maybe I haven't found them out yet, but I didn't feel as if my choices bore significant consequences. It didn't really bother me, though, because the ride was a good one. The game is divided into city hubs that open one at a time after plot checkpoints, and you can jump from one to the other freely once they're available. You won't find the trademark "collect 10 donkey tails" side-quests that pollute fantasy RPGs, but instead many fun investigative missions outside the main plot. Backtracking can be annoying, though.While the story isn't too divergent, the gameplay is. It shares similarities with Deus Ex – many missions (though not all) don't offer just one way to the solution. Usually you can take a stealthy approach as well as the loud and bloody one. If your hacking skill is low, often your lockpicking will let you do the job instead – or vice versa. And while, like many other RPGs, it has its skills which aren't as useful as the others, I was happy to find out that many non-combat ones are still well utilized in the game. I won't write down a guide to power-building, though. One, because you can easily google it. Two, because it's hard to suck at the game.You can focus either on guns or melee. I did one playthrough of each, and while I felt that later on my gun-focused character was stronger, the melee was more satisfying, despite how simple it was. I really liked playing an immortal psychopath who charges into a room while people shoot at her and she just jumps around slashing everything. However, just like the graphics, keep in mind the year of the game and don't expect anything advanced in terms of combat mechanics.The game also has serious replay value. I'm already during my 3rd playthrough, and I'm not crossing out the possibility of a 4th sometime in the future. It's not due to different choices, because – as I said – they're not too significant here. It's partly due to reviewing the story with the insight of the twist at the end and partly due to different approach in mechanics – like many RPGs. You don't choose a specific class, but instead a clan. They're set apart by their own few unique abilities (some even have different dialogue options, which is pretty amazing if you ask me), while the bulk of the simple ones are shared between them all. Before you start, two things. First, the game is buggy as hell and you shouldn't play it without the unofficial patch. Google it, it'll come up. Second, don't play the Malkavian clan in your first run – they're lunatics who hear voices, and their dialogue is completely overhauled and special, partly due to their weird insights into matters. So without understanding the plot after a complete playthrough, and knowing what happens in each interaction, playing a Malkavian can be really confusing. But after your first playthrough? Highly recommended. They're very entertaining.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												If this game had more time for polishing (*cough* thanks a lot Activision *cough*), it would have easily been the best RPG. The combat is mediocre at best, but on the other hand, the dialogue, characters and story are great. The class system also adds a lot of replayability too, thanks to how different each gameplay can be depending on what kind of vampire you picked. Don't expect to play the game without any issues though. Even with the community's unofficial patches, I still encountered multiple major bugs (bosses went through the level, quests couldn't be completed, characters not appearing when they are supposed to and so on). But still, it's definitely worth playing.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2012
												Do not betray the Masquerade, Kindred, for the penalties of alerting humanity to our presence is dire indeed. Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines is an RPG powerhouse. In this game, you are embraced by a vampire clan of your choice and go through late night Los Angeles preying on humans and exploring the grim city that vampires call their home. The story is to die for, the mechanics are phenomenal and the world is incredibly immersive. It's pretty much a perfect 10/10 with memorable characters, distinctive settings and replay value as each clan of vampire plays differently from the others. Two minor things put this game back: The combat system is similar to that of Borderlands and that enough should tell you that it isn't the best way of doing things (it still executes this system better than Borderlands) and in order to even run the game, you must find the latest version of the Unofficial Patch and install it. Other than that, get this game. You'll be wishing you were a Child of Caine in no time.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Pros: Fantastic Storytelling, perhaps the game's strongest element. Plenty of options for characters: Strong, Charismatic, Deadly; however you'd like to play, there's a way to do it. A plethora of memorable characters, backed with Excellent voice acting. An engaging plot, with plenty of sidequests: At least 30 hours of content. Unique character development that adheres to White Wolf's game system. Cons: Combat is sketchy. Those looking for a beat-em-up or a FPS will be dissapointed.  The endgame involves a lot of combat, and may be dissapointing for relatively pacifist players. Also, see above. The out of box product is rather buggy, and even the official patched and plus patched versions can have memory leak issues. Save early, and save often.If you get this game (and you should, believe me) Be sure to install either the unofficial patch, which fixes a lot of inherent issues with the game, or the plus patch, which restores deleted content and improves existing content for smoother gameplay. As is, the game includes the 1.2 official patch Patch 9.2 [forums.planetvampire.com]Being one of the finest RPGs out there in the sense that it adheres to Role-Playing,  Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines  Is a must for anyone who considers themselves a fan of RPGs. It has its flaws, yes, but it's a shining example of what interactive roleplaying can and should look like. TL;DR I give it 9/10. Install the unofficial patch.

Posted: August 18, 2016
												One of the best games i've ever played. The graphics of course don't live up to todays standards but even so they're not that bad and i personally don't put all my stock in graphics. The game itself is wonderful, its very eerie and dark (which isn't normally my kind of thing but in this case i loved it.) You can choose whether to play as male or female (something i LOVE) and you get to choose what 'Clan' you're in which is a super cool concept. This game also has great replay value as it has multiple endings and new things you'll discover everytime. I definitely think this game is worth purchasing.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												This game rocks.Like hardcore.Most people will never truly understand how good the VTM series was.And why I will digitally hound White Wolf to release another game for the rest of my life.VTM is based off the pen and paper bit done by the afforementioned company.  It's based off of Vampires respecting the "masquerade" they keep with humans.  So none of this modern teen-vampire ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Real vampire politics.It gets nitty-gritty.This game is incredible if you want a real grasp of what being a vampire would be like, without wrecking everyone's face like it's some Devil May Care spin-off.  Make the right mistakes and you might see vampire boobies!  Make the wrong mistakes and the guys you thought were your friends are now out to put you down for that "long nap."♥♥♥♥ onions, I bathe sometimes; but shotguns, now that smarts.  This game is as real as Vampires get!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2012
												While this may not be the greatest RPG I have ever played, nor the most well-executed or polished by any means...VTM: Bloodlines is hands-down my favorite RPG to this date. The setting and characters absolutely ooze flavor with great writing, voice acting, and character animations that while often obviously canned manage to be more emotive, expressive and entertaining than anything you'll see in a modern WRPG.While the gameplay systems aren't stellar at all points of the game, when they work they really shine in a brilliant light, and it's admirable to see a small developer take this many risks in order to push the envelope of what you can do in an RPG.This game has a heart and soul and passion that's incomperable to any modern RPG, because you can just about taste the effort and passion that the developers poured into this project.It's just a damn shame those beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at Troika will never see a dime of the profits that this game makes on steam.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												While suffering somewhat from some bugs and glitches, the game itself is a good challenge, to keep the simple review. You will need to find the patch.Moving to the more detailed review...The intial attempts you may make to load the game could end in heartbreak, as the game possesses a bug which prevents you, or at least prevented me, from playing the game without downloading a key patch. The good news is that this patch is available for free online, in fact there is an extended unofficial patch, also available, which does not prevent the game being played on steam. Not that you would be missing much, the game doesn't have 100% steam compatiable 'chieves all over the place, or much else. It's single player, after all.Once you get into the game you find that there is both a tutorial section - skippable, if you don't mind loosing some work towards stat increases and having to pay for a set of lockpicks - and a guided character creation, which is perfectly good if a little impersonal. You also have the option to set everything yourself, if the guided version did not set things to your pleasure.And then you get to the story, and that... Well, it's hardly my place to spoil it, especially with it's numbers of little twists and hidden reprocussions.You should play it if you really want to find out.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Do you enjoy a good story from tales that take you to the lady by the sea?In short, buy this game.However, if you need a longer answer, let me tell you that this game is a masterpiece and display of great writing that everyone should give a try. Whether you prefer the rebellious tongue of a Brujah, the witty arsenal of a Toreador, or the black hole of knowledge that inhabits the speech patterns of a Malkavian, there's some satisfaction to be found for anyone who likes their character to be a certain way. This is the kind of game you wish you could play over blind again, or the kind of game that you just cant give details about, so all I can say is play it, and make sure to install the unofficial patch which actually adds a lot(currently at version 8.9!)One last thing:Don't open it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Highly recommended.  One of the best games I have ever played.  Fair warning, It is buggy, the graphics are dated, and it fizzles at the very end because the devs were rushed to release.  However, moving beyond that, this is a cult gem.  It is the only game that gets the RPG elements and first person perspective nearly perfect.  It is NOT a dumbed down game, it is an actual MATURE game that actually earns the M title.  There is sex, violence, addiction, slavery, and many other adult themes.  It is the closest I have ever seen of an RPG pen and paper game brought to life.  This should be the standard that all modern RPG/'first person games' should astrive too.

content:

												This game is amazing... buggy as hell, but amazing nonethelessa fine example of FPS and RPG mixture done right in a non-Borderlands way (I do love Borderlands, by the way)the story develops really well, as it should in an RPG, and it gives you a play-style totally unique to your senses, You like to play sneaky and talk your way through things? Good, have funYou like bashing skulls and punching down your way through the game? Good as well, have funYou are just a madman wanting to shout a little nonsense into a nonsensical world? Awesome, good for you, have fun!that said, boy, this game was rushed... with a plethora of game-crashing bugs that will leave you quite♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥..the game saves automatically quite often, so it should not be much of a problem anyway... depending on your play-style, that extra drop of rage might even make you an unstopable killing machineother than that, well worth the promotional price given every halloween, and, for completionists, there is a hell of a lot of content in this baby, with various side-quests triggered in ways quite funny to discover...also, if you buy it, go after the unnoficial patches... high-res did not favor this game over time... but the fan community tackled this issue quite beautifully (actually fixing some bugs in the process)even with the bugs, double thumbs up for this game

												Clunky, ugly, and outdated as hell, this is one of my favorite games of all time. Dont let the whole vampire thing turn you away (this game was out years before the whole twilight thing) Much like [OG] Deus Ex, this game has aged quite well dispite exclusivly using older shooter mechanics. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This game is a buried gem. Activision, as per their hitleristic standards, rushed this game into release about halfway through the development. The result is somewhat painful as far as bugs and glitches go. For me, the game wouldn't even start on its own, and when I initially tried to play it, I uninstalled and felt regret for buying it on my boyfriend's recommendation.A few months afterwards, I installed it again while I had a craving for RPGs. Here's the single key to enjoying this game: go and download the unofficial patch, and make sure to select the patch plus during the installation process. A large amount of the game's content is in unactivated code. The patch is regularly updated - the most recent update was this year, last I checked - which fixes all of the game breaking bugs and readds content that wasn't quite finished or activated.The game? Great. The lore is excellent, which most of anyone who has experience with the Old World of Darkness universe would know. Even if you're not, the game is a great introduction. I wasn't a huge expert before I started playing, but a few hours in, I pulled up the wiki and simply started reading. The writing is quality. The characters are memorable, and it's hard not to feel about them; usually, if they're not Beckett or Jack, that feeling is indescribable loathing. The quests are so interesting, you feel a need to go out and find all of the ones avaliable. The environment offers many areas to explore and makes you want to explore them.The only two things I would say aren't perfect about the game are the graphics and the combat. The graphics, naturally, are as dated as the game, and they haven't aged well. I honestly enjoy them because sometimes they're literally laughable. The combat is charmingly schizophrenic, in that you're never quite sure what you're doing, nor what you should be doing, but gosh dang if the results aren't fun. The combat difficulty jerks up and down with little in game conceivable reason, and initially I was confused, but then I realized that the difficulty wasn't based on game mechanics. It's based on lore. If the game makes you fight vampire hunters, no matter at what point you're at in the game, the fight's going to be very hard because vampire hunters in the Old World of Darkness are damned near impossible to kill. It's a great game, and I think that if lore, missions, writing, and plots are your thing, you should play it. However, don't buy it. Pirate it. A larger company - I think it was Bioware - bought the company that made it and fired everyone who worked on it. Your money would be spent paying the people who ruined the chance of a second game.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												So long as you install the unofficial patch before you try it, this is an awesome game, and surprisingly engaging considering its age. Sure the graphics are pretty bad, and the voice acting is somewhat static-y, but the characters feel real, and there's tons to explore. Even once the game's been completed, there's more to do, from extremely in-depth mods, to entirely different playstyle choices. I've just finished playing Vampire: The Masquerade for almost 4 days straight; personally, I haven't begun to get tired of it yet, and not one ounce of that is nostagia.

												This game with the addition of the unofficial patch is hands down one of the absolute best RPG's I have ever played. Here are a few bulletpoints of awesome traits this game has in no particular order.* A unique and sophisticated universe/worldspace that really makes you feel like your in a vampiric underworld beneath society.* A very wide variety of different skills/abilities your character can use and develop that truly fleshes out the character building part of this RPG.* An intriguing storyline and dialogue system that keeps the player deeply involved in what's happening.I genuinely love this game and absolutely recommend that you at the very least consider purchasing it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Alright, for real though, this is a game that has aged very well. It was a golden RPG for 2004, and today is still Golden. With Troika dead, and before Paradox bought out the rights to White Wolf and WOD, CCP didn't do crap with this series including updates, letting other people remaster it, etc. Luckily this game still has a somewhat active, but small, community, and came out with amazing patches even after a decade of death and silence. There was a project to remake/remaster the game called Project Vaulderie, but unfortunately it got shut down by CCP even though CCP had been doing nothing besides working on Eve Online. The best:-The music is A1. Introduced me to some good gothic metal bands, and the soundtracks for a lot of the hubs are very pleasing. -The dialogue is hilarious most of the time, and it changes depending on what clan you are. -While there was some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting, there was also a lot of good voice acting from well known voice actors.-Clans: There are several you get to choose from, each one has its own special abilities, appearance, and ways you run through the game. -There is no leveling up, you gain experience points and then assign those earned experience points to certain skills you want to increase, which is a simple and nice. -Kind of has it's own karma system to put it basically, you kill innocents, you lose humanity, you lose all your humanity, you go into a frenzy which isn't always the prettiest. So most of the time you have to be conscious of your actions.-The atmosphere was greatly crafted; to be a dark gothic setting. Everything is eerie, not especially scary, but eerie and dark really no matter where you are. -You get to dance like a maniac.-You get paid good for a lot of quests.-A ♥♥♥♥♥ON of lore.The Bad: A lot of this can be excused because of the time it was released, but still mentioning,-The map is absolutely tiny. There are only 4 hubs you can go to, which all are pretty damn small and will take you like 10 minutes to run through all the buildings. -The bugs. Of course, this has to do with the state it was released in, problems with the devs and Valve, etc. But if you don't install the patch that was wonderfully made by fans, then you're going to have a hard time playing because this game is bug heaven.-A lot of the NPCs are the same, there's probably like 5-7 differen't types of NPCS in one city, with 3-4 repeats. -The AI is awful. You can have a decent sneak level and be crouching in front of a group of cops that are on a hunt for you and they wouldn't see you. -The game is fairly short. I think the first time I played this I completed the main and side quests within at least 14 hours. -You don't really get a choice in who you side with. Throughout the game, you are working for LaCroix no matter if you don't like him, but at the end you do indeed get a decision. -You can't really replay this game much differently than a last playthrough mainly because in terms of storyline, there isn't too much you can choose differently, besides minor decisions.-It really doesn't show too much or hint at the enormous amount of lore the WOD and VtM series has. The first time I played this I had no idea that there was a crap ton of books belonging to this series. But luckily, once I found out, I bought all of them. -Because the environment is small and all the work went into the quests, you really can't do much in terms of just exploring. There's not much to interact with. -LOOT. There is rarely any loot throughout the entire game. Which any loot you find is sold for dirt cheap and you get barely any $$$. Overall, a lot of the flaws of this game I can look past because of the age. Lets all hope Paradox does a good job dealing with this series, because it can either go absolutely horribly or incredibly wonderful. And lets hope they don't make a MMO.
