content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												The game is nearly ten years old so the graphics are obviously dated but this game is still really solid. It's similar to Deus Ex in that a few months after you complete it, someone somewhere will mention it in passing and you'll curse their name while you reinstall it and play through it one more time. Some parts are really atmospheric while some are extremely frustrating (hollywood sewers, if you used noclip, I don't blame you). The way you can customize your character is really nice too, there are a lot of different combinations you can mess around with. I put 32 hours into it over one playthrough so you can judge for yourself whether it's worth the money, but I certainly enjoyed it. Also, USE THE LATEST VERSION OF THE UNOFFICIAL FAN PATCH, this game is buggy and the patch fixes it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												One of the most immersive and unique RPGs you will ever find. Imagine if you take the action, skills, moral choises and decisions from games like Deus Ex and Fallout 3, and combine that aspect with a modern world secret vampire society set in the midst of Hollywood - Los Angeles. Then you have the recipe that is Vamire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.As a newly turned vampire you are off to a rocky start. You begin to unravel ancient mysteries and conspiracies within the society itself. Many clans are at war with eachother, and it's up to you to decide which sides to take. You can either try to resolve things through diplomatic efforts to stay in touch with your human side as much as possible, or go the more animalistic way of violence and murder. But beware, everything you do may have serious consequences!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Pros:-one of the few fully fledged RPGs to feature vampires (and I'm not even a vampire fan)-interesting twist on the vampires - 7 playable clans, each with their own strengths and weaknesses-nonlinear gameplay - sneak around without being seen or slaughter everyone with a gun-diverse 'disciplines' (basically supernatural powers) - invisibility, charm, induce insanity and more-decent dialogue system-good plot with ingenious quests-strong cast of characters-can be witty at times, playing with stereotypes and such-length - it probably took me around 30+ hours to finish, including most of the subquests (don't mind the hours on record, I often play in offline mode)Cons:-the graphics (that is to be expected from a game released in 2004) - clipping issues are unfortunately quite common-difficulty spikes - very easy at first, can be frustrating at the end depending on what weapons you're using-lackluster and unbalanced combat system - upgrading your melee comabt skills will only increase the damage you deal, the movesets and attack speed remain the same (or improve just slightly); there is also no good reason to choose unarmed combat over melee weapons-hubs offer relatively little to do once the sidequests are finished (justified in that you only ever walk the streets at night)-buggy (be sure to install unoffical patches)-the inventory can be messy-price - about 20 bucks for a ten-year-old game that isn't even a cult classic (albeit, for what it is - a very decent RPG, perhaps it should be)My rating: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: March 26
												Notice: the reason the play time is low is because of the unofficial patch mod to actually play it. Details are in the review.(spoken in a dark macho manly voice)"The time is 12:30am or something, i dunno i can't read the time, everyone is trying to mind their own buisness and telling me to♥♥♥♥♥♥off because i keep getting way too close to them. I'm given another bazillionth task to retrieve some♥♥♥♥♥♥that will 'definetly' not backfire by some girl i obviously can tell that has dual personalities, but for some strange fate i'm the only one that notices but can't say so because the writers, uhhh i mean God thought i have a perception of a seven year old and gave me a speech impared stroke." "I'm still not able to date that girl at the bar without being shuned so hard that i slam through a brick wall, why must i be given the curse of being able to defend myself against an entire army of thugs, and generally being badass at everything else, EXCEPT TALKIING LIKE A NORMAL PERSON TO A GIRL! Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ dating women who think socially awkward men are 'cute', this is how i became a vampire in the first place."This is a generalization on my thoughts in "Vampire: the masquerade-Bloodlines". I played through the game as a  combat hardened vampire with the dating capability of a five year old, and ended the game as a combat hardened Vampire with the dating capability of an eight year old. So thats 1,000 bodies piled up in one night, and 0 women shaged blood sucked through what was supposed to be shagging in a lifetime. But  everything else was A ok, the story was fantastic, the characters were likeable, and the combat was riged but interesting enough to be worthy of a Bethesda RPG. But beating a dead horse five or eight times is not enough, noooo you want to eviserate it and smear the entestines all over yourself. You deffinetly don't want to be affiliated with something like that, so im gona help you look like you do by framing you and calling the cops on you. For now why don't you read the rest of this review while i make sure that your into snuff films.gameplayIf your eyes were too lazy to read the description of the game, you play as a vampire in the modern world. But the game dosn't want to be that kind of game, like the recent fallout game, it want's to be unique and engaging like a hetrosexual. You have your penalties, your overbearing number of skills to track, your journal, blood because your a vampire obviously and your soon to be overburdened inventory. if thats hard to keep track of, pray to God that the police won't arrest you, if not continue reading.Then we got the combat, what about it, like a bethesda RPG, clunky, unpolished but original enough to keep you interested. wacking people sends them flying and slaming against a wall if there is one, and shooting people is as interesting as the new call of duty, the same as every call of duty game. Then theres your supernatural skills, because vampire, and that the affect is what race of vampire you are, like a hetrosexual. Theres a dozen different races, but on my first run i played as a carniverous hippy with Bob Marly enthusiast hair.But where it really shines like a flash bang going off in your eyes is the dialouge. Almost everyone in the game has profesional voice acting (except for the same looking security guards) and have facial animations of melted chocolate being forcefully poured down your throat. The protagonist (yourself dumbass) even has great dialouge that made me actually feel about the scenarios the game passes to me on a silver platter, which looks to me was  suppost to be a golden platter.atmosphereThe world is dark, scary and sleazy like Detroit, probably is inspired by real world Detroit. The game almost looks believable enough to be a real city with bumbs walking around in the dozens and the looks of what was suppost to be a city with imbition is strife with poverty. Hope and kindness is a rare comodity, and even if its not impossible to be nice, conflicting consequences force youto chose between human, or monster. Even the game has a moral meter but instead of getting to look bad, the more evil you are the likelier you are to have no control over you character while they go on a rampage, im serious.But underneath that exterior lies a society of, you already know what it is. The world of the dead always changes the tone of being in a normal place, to being in somewhere where you are powerless. you'll be one minute fighting thugs in the dozens while some will try to flee in terror, then you'll be in a haunted mansion or a house of a crazed vampire, making you sick and spooked at the same time, it actually works very well.Everything from lighting to texture work makes this a believable place, almost at the same levels as 'Deus ex'.negativesBUGS, bugs everyhere even if you start it throws at you a '15 gb of space required' prompt that throws you out like a bouncer at a strip club. Fortunatly i have a solution here[www.patches-scrolls.com]. even if you get that to work your still going to run into problems, like asanine enemy locations and game braking bugs. a noticable one is the CARGO SHIP LEVEL. I see cops everywhere, i sneak past them to investigate something, i try to escape but i don't know how to without killing the guards blocking my escape route and i can't kill anyone. You know what the solution was,  NO CLIP. I had to use it to pass through that level because i tried every solution to get out without getting spotted by the 'highly trained officers' who shoot on site, because making advance ai is hard.conclusionThis game has fantasticly told story with slightly dogy but engaging combat with loads of bugs, but you know what it is. An unfinished masterpeace because the developers were on a tight schedual and tried to cram everything in a reasonably long game. It works for the most part and optimization is great, its a shame that it has so many bugs that would scare alot of players away. I recommend this if you like decent RPG's and don't mind cheating a little.The police are probably there already and your thinking of ways to kill me, well i get alot of death threats so im a popular guy .Ill be in hiding while you plan your escape route, even though i am most likely to get assasinated by the many secret agencies and lives of people worthy enough for a protagonist of a John Woo film.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Ok yeah so the game is old. And it shows. And it's pretty janky and buggy and needs a bit of patching to run smoothly (crash to desktop on boot, anyone?) BUT...Seriously, if you enjoy RPG action games, PLEASE give this one a try. The story is brilliant, and it features one of the best spooky levels/missions I've ever experienced in a videogame. It's pretty authentic to the hard-copy pen and paper (and LARP) RPG system which it is based on, so if you're a fan of the tabletop/larp, you should get a kick out of this!It's a little treasure of a game, beloved by its fans, and honestly if you can look past the dated appearance (I personally find it rather charming) and deal with the occasional bugs (seriously, PLEASE check the forums for this game if you pick it up and download the unofficial patch) you should have a pretty good time.Also vampires. :)

Posted: February 21, 2014
												LOVE this game.It look old and it's a bit janky (particularly combat using firearms, melee is must more rewarding) but the world is amazingly well constructed and highly immersive.This is a world you can get lost in with multiple play style options and great ways to have a completely different experience. If you've already played through and want something different picking a different clan can give open up options and pathways that you previously couldn't have found. Great examples of this are the Nosfertu which prevent you from being seen by human without incurring penalty making you spend the game learning the under paths of the hub areas and the Malkvians who, being insane, replace all of your dialogue options with entertaining non-sequiturs and giving different dialogue from NPC (usually remarking that you're insane).Just make sure you get the unofficial patch which fixes a range of issues and greatly improves the game.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												Pros: 1. This game has tons of options for character cutomization. Different vampire clans, each with their own advantages/disadvantages make each playthrough unique.2. Many different dialogue options. Conversations with characters can go different ways depending on what you choose.3. Interesting and engaging storyline.Cons:1. Know that this game has MANY bugs. It took me multiple tries to get it to work. First, there was an issue with space, then its display settings had to be changed, then it couldn't connect to steam etc etc. It's a pain and takes a while to work them all out, but so many people experience it that you can find the solution easily.2. The character outfits are sort of glitchy. I doubt this will bother some but I noticed it with certain clothing options.3. I didn't really care for the more action-oriented aspects of the game. I ended up just trying to get through combat areas quickly so I could get back to the story.This game is a lot of fun and I would definitely recommend it. However, you have to be willing to go through the process of weeding out the bugs. Like I said, there are a lot of them, but the game is worth it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2013
												I once read a comment that said "Whenever someone mentions Vampire Bloodlines you just know that someone, somewhere, is installing it again.", and I must agree wholeheartedly. I read that a few years ago, mind you, and I have since found other RPGs to add to my "best RPGs of all time" list. But Bloodlines, despite its age, its sort of mediocre gameplay that can confuse you for being based on a set of rules that are not always apparent, despite its dated visual and lack of character customization... Despite all that, the world, characters and tone still keep me coming back. Pretty much every quest is interesting, the dialogs are well writen, the urban fantasy setting is something I wish I could see more often in gaming (especially in RPGs) and it has what simply must be my favourite haunted house level in gaming. Ever.So yes, after almost ten years I still recommend Vampire, if nothing else because it will show you a world like which you won't find in any other videogame.Man, now I feel like starting another playthrough.

												The game is quite old, so the graphics are not all that. You will also need to download a fan-made patch to make it work properly, but once that's sorted the game works just fine.You get to choose one out of seven clans, your gender, and if you want - a backstory. All of these will have an impact on your playthrough, and gives you a lot of diversity to play with. Each clan has different abilities and traits. Sadly, you don't get to customise your appearance though, it's set by your sex and clan.The dialogue options allows you to voice your opinion, often in a rude way. The game gives you the options you need to go around and be an a-hole to everyone, and you can of course lick butt if that's more of your style. There will also be unique dialogue options based off your clan, stats and abilities.As you play through the game you will eventually be part of a story of politics, intrigue, and the fight for power and gain in the city. You will get to choose through your actions the outcome of this struggle, which I found very satisfying as you can make the ending of the game directly reflect your opinion on the conflicting factions of LA. There is no black and white answer here, as all these factions could be considered bad in different ways.All in all it's a good experience, and I highly recommend it.Oh, and one last bit of advice: Do not open the sarcophagus.

The story is the darkest and most sophisticated you'll come across in a game, the dialogue is the best I've ever come across in a game, and the Role-Playing elements are brilliantly strong, the amount of options open to you is matched only by Deus Ex. While this game is buggy, the fans are still making patches since Trokia sadly went bankrupt after completing this game. You will still experience bugs, and that is the only bad thing about this game, but if you can get past this (and you should) you will find, in my opinion one of the best games ever made. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Well, where do I begin, telling you about this gem? I suppose I'll start with what it is.Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is an action-RPG based on the tabletop game of the same name. Gamplay-wise, it plays similarly to the original Deus Ex, leaving multiple options to accomplish your objectives. You could go for the good-old fashioned direct assault, use stealth, or alternatively talk your way out of situations. It's really up to you.There are numerous vampire clans to choose from, all with their own unique focus. Brujahs and Gangrels focus more on combat, whereas the Tremere make use of powerful blood magic, and the Toreador and Ventrue manipulate their way towards their objectives. There are, however, two more, special clans. The Nosferatu are mutated horribly by their vampiric curse, and must skulk around the sewers and alleys lest they be seen. Needless to say, they're good at stealth. And last, but certainly not least, are the Malkavians. These guys are completely insane, which is reflected in game by your bizarre dialogue choices, hallucinations and voices in your head. They do have some nice powers, though, such as invisibilty and Dementation, which is useful for both dialogue and enemies. You'll also be treated quite differently based on your clan, leaving a lot of replay value.Really, though, it's the story and atmosphere which make this game truly special. Walking through the streets of a depiction of LA apparently going through it's Goth phase. The hubworlds are small in size but full of detail, and you always feel like you're doing something different. From tracking down and killing a cabal of blood disease-spreading vampires, to exploring a haunted house, to getting your own ghoul (basically someone who has recieved vampire blood and gets some basic vampire abilities from it, but not the whole set), it always feels like you're doing something unique. It feels good to drink blood, and the political intrigue of the secret vampire society you're involved in is extremely engrossing, and all the characters have different personalities, and a good few are quite memorable. The story moves at a good pace, although the story path to a seemingly simple objective often becomes quite convoluted.Sadly. this game is not without its flaws. First off the bat, there's the bugs and poor optimisation. This game was Christmas rushed (which, as we all know, always ends well), and the game was in an extremely buggy state upon launch, and Troika were unable to fix it on account of going bust shortly after. The game will ouright refuse to work on some modern systems without an unofficial patch, and may be almost unplayable. Even with the patch installed, you will see bugs often. Most won't affect gameplay, but will pull you out of that fantastic atmosphere Troika worked so hard to make. After a certain point close to the end of the game, due to it being rushed out the door, the game forces you into a repetetive series of combat arenas, with no alternative paths. So, if you've not been putting points into combat skills, you're screwed. The final boss (oh, and the boss fights aren't very good throughout the game) is impossible to kill without a gun, when guns are next to useless for a good part of the game. Oh, and even if you have gone the combat route, the game still has a massive unfair difficulty spike near the end. The combat itself is bearable, but very repetetive, and essentially consists of wailing on attack and spamming your most powerful clan Disciplines.Still, overall, VtM-B is easily one of the best RPGs ever made, and you owe to yourself to get it. Accept the Embrace and find your place in the world of the Kindred...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2011
												This game pretty much makes up for every one of its shortcomings, and there are plenty, through pure style. There are some fantastic fan mods that even out the rough edges, but even unmodded this is one of the most immersive games out there, one that throws you into its world and lets you explore its darkest reaches. Rather than excessive exposition, it lets you discover the ins and outs of the underground vampire society yourself, much as an outsider like the player character would have to do. It has a fantastic amount of player choice, and a genuinely good storyline to follow, however you choose to play. Many of the core mechanics are pretty sloppy, and the various skills are terribly balanced. Not to mention an excess of bugs can impede your progress. But if you can ignore, or mod out these issues, you'll find it's the perfect vampire game. Just as the Arkham games make you feel like you really are Batman, this makes you really feel like a vampire. And makes vampires cool again in the process.(As usual, ignore my low recorded playtime, as I've already played my non-steam version multiple times.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Resurrected as a vampire after your death, you are recruited to assist in an ongoing war of attrition between several vampire clans who vie for control of Los Angeles. Using a combination of stealth, cunning and brute force, only you can ultimately shape the result of the conflict.Famously released in an unfinished state (though several patches and mods have been released that largely fix this), Bloodlines is a flawed yet absolutely captivating gem of a game that takes the stealth-action RPG hybrid gameplay of series such as Deus Ex and Thief, drapes it in a veneer of equal parts Anne Rice sensual horror and goth club sleaze, and ties it all together with an excellent script dripping with lore, mystery, sexuality, and violence. There's plenty of replay value to be had as well thanks to the diverse array of vampire clans one can play as; from the seductive Toreador or traditionalist Ventrue, to the monstrous Nosferatu or gibbering and insane Malkavian. Just be ready to do some patching after you've installed the game.

The dirty, disgusting, depraved setting is a nice change, too.Only major downside is the last quarter of the game starts feeling rushed--Chinatown, the last quest hub, is almost devoid of activities--and pushes you headlong into a series of unavoidable battles using a messy, unsatisfying combat system. Playing as a sneaky-sneaky, bat-crazy Malkavian, however, must be experienced.  Same with the haunted hotel level. x_x Spooky spooky spooky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade is a tabletop RPG game that was brought into the video gaming world with its first endeavor, "Redemption". After that, the creative and much more free roaming sequel, "Bloodlines" came out and basically shut down Troika games because of its bugs and glitches. However, the game itself, with its plot, choices, characters and overall lay out were good enough that fans have been releasing unofficial patches for the game in the decade since it was released. What does THAT tell you about the game? ;)    In Bloodlines, unlike Redemption, you get to choose your character by picking which gender you are and which vampire class. The vampire classes are an interesting assortment and essentially choose what your main skills and penalties turn out to be. If you're a Nosferatu, you're hideous and can roam about in public, but you're very intelligent and technical, if you're a Toreador, you're gorgeous and persuade/seduce almost anyone in the game, but you aren't very strong or intelligent and so on. Once you pick your class, you are thrust into a world of vampiric politics, gothic nightclubs and other fun stuff.    The fight mechanics are decent enough and the overall choices that you get make the game extremely enjoyable. The game has multiple endings and you essentially choose what kind of vampire you want to be (nice to people, recklessly homicidal to people, break all the rules, etc.) and what kind of vampire politics you want L.A. to turn into (ruled by the manipulative Vampire prince, ruled by the manipulative asian sorceress, ruled by you, or kill everyone and embrace vampiric anarchy). While the glitches are noticeable, even with any of the numerous fanmade uber-patches, the game is worth playing.

I hated every combat section because it was uncomfortable, clunky, with insane difficulty spikes. This game is also really glitchy. But they never broke my game and only broke immersion twice. The Physics (Source game, of course) were all over the place. Very unnecesary. Hair and clothes bounce without restraint and makes walking around in third person look really silly.TL:DR versionPROS:+Atmosphere+Story+Lore+Characters(All uniwue and well written+Voice Acting (no voice actors are recycled)+Graphics (aged a bit, but still holds up)+MusicCONS:-Combat-very glitchy10/10 I cry every night I remember there's no sequel

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												If you play RPGs not only for incredible loot and skill tree leveling, but also for the sake of role-playing a character and taking in the atmosphere, this is the game for you. While you do gain experience, and unlock new abilities, the skill tree will be unfamiliar to those not already versed in White Wolf's pen and paper games. Also, there is very little gear, whether dropped or bought and it almost feels scripted. You get to a new place, and get a new weapon or armor, at the same time on every character you make. The only other bad point i'll touch on is the combat system. While it's fun hacking away in melee, and the vampire powers you get to back your fighting skills are top-notch visually and mechanically, if you specialize in guns, expect to have a REALLY hard time until about halfway through the game, even if your ranged skill is high. On top of that, even when your wielding a trusty baseball bat knocking some punk to the floor, you literally have to wait for them to get up to strike again as the hit-boxes don't register when they are prone. But those a few minor annoyances, and really aren't the spirit of the game. You can get through many missions without physical confrontation if you are socially inclined, or can make people magically go insane. The characters you meet all have a story and each one's personality might clash with another or even yourself. It's a great opportunity to really role-play a vampire and a must have for anyone looking for more than a run-through guns blazing type of game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is something that is very unfortunate. It has a seriously interesting world, that will imerse you regardless of whether you're a fan of gothic culture or not. It spins a vampire tale that is both interesting and enjoyable at the same time. The plot remains solid and tense up until the 75% mark and then it feels unfortunatly rushed. I ended this story, feeling satisified of the journey but the overal end just left me feeling like alot of choices I made didn't matter. This is of course, due to the game developer being rushed to finish the game on time and highlights of game gems such as this one, are unfortunatly not given the extra attention they deserved.Gameplay is very similar to that of games like Deus Ex. You are allowed to tackle objectives in any way you wish, in fact the game presents you with a series of classes which almost define your playstyle from then on. And this isn't just a minor state boost ethier. Playing as a particular class for example, renders you unable to travel on the streets due to your inability to blend in. The consequence of this is that you spend most of the game in sewers eating rats, but have a massive advantage when it comes to any stealth encounter. This is one of the fantastic game design choices the games makes! Certain vampire classes have advanatges in certain areas. Some are good at meddling with humans, others are better at combat and violence. One class is considered insane, and has an entire dialouge choice to back it up in conversations. Combat can be a little worse for ware, but it isn't unplayable. The broken AI, doesn't tend to put up much of a fight - especially in stealth sections. When you pick your class, you will find it difficult to progress down any other path. Stealth classes, tend to be killed quite easily if you try full frontal combat. Stealth isn't just a one off thing ethier, it is supported by stealth kills, shadow blending etc. Overall, when you play this game - it is very difficult not to appreciate it, for what it could be and for what it is. I find it difficult to discredit the game up to the 75% mark. After that, things are obviously rushed, everything becomes more combat focused and you will find yourself struggling if you didn't pick a combat class. Before that though, is a game that definatly rewards player choice in both story and gameplay. It provide an interesting, immersive gothic world that will delight both those who enjoy vampire culture and those who don't, alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												A flawed masterpiece.The game has its problems, that's undeniable.  It seems the development team ended up being punished by time constraints and ended up sorely neglecting the last quarter of the game; neglecting the truly excellent role-playing elements for more and more uninspired combat.  Fortunately, thanks to numerous community patches, the rest of the game has aged pretty well.If you overlook the minor annoyance that combat represents, and the fact that the end of the game feels too brief and rushed, even with the significant amount of "lost content" added to it by the aforementioned  patches, then you're in for a real treat.The atmosphere is outstanding; the game does an excellent job of creating an almost film-noir bleakness that typifies the World of Darkness setting.  At least two relatively early missions ratchet up the creepy into moments of true horror, and there is a constant air of menace that you'd expect from a game where you build a custom vampire and embark on the life of a creature-of-the-night.The roleplaying elements are truly first-rate.  Some of the best I have ever seen, with characters that are unique, memorable, and fully formed.  The degree with which you can interact them is solid, and just a whisker shy of being superlative.The skill-sets you can pick from strike a great balance between utility (being able to hack computer terminals for info, or lock-pick), social (seduction, intmidation), and combat.The stealth system is solid, but not amazing – the obfuscate ability makes it pretty redundant for a couple of "clans" (classes) but stealth-kills are an effective tool in most situations.The plot is gripping, although as I mentioned above the conclusion feels a little rushed; as if they ran out of time in the third act and just cut-to-the-chase.  The numerous side-quests are insinuated into the game subtlely, and in a way that makes completing them fun, rather than just busy-work you have to go through to get 100% completion or some extra XP and loot.This game is truly a diamond in the rough.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												This is a great game with amazing role playing opportunities but unless you're willing to use unofficial patches and the console to get past issues, choose a different game. On a modern system, this game won't run without an unofficial patch and even then you run into hiccups. Still interested? Well, sit down because I'm going to tell you why this game is the vampire RPG you've been looking for and more.Ever craved more after Skyrim's tiny vampire section? Well, here it is, with fangs and bloodlust to match.This game puts you in the middle of an urban city environment based in 2004. You've been sired by a vampire against the Masquerade and if not for Kindred (vampires) political machinations, you'd be ash alongside your sire.Now, you are thrust into a world of politics, monsters and blood, all whilst hiding your true nature. The clan you pick has a decent factor in on this and some more than others. There are different ways to handle situations throughout most of the game and it's really just near the end where the rewarded path becomes the least successful which is quite discordant.Each situation is very different, leaving very little of that normal copy and paste side quest/main quest situation, giving you a fulfilling storyline to warm your undead heart. Mechanics have you thinking like a vampire- a game where you are the predator and sometimes, the prey don't know how close they were to their death, spared because it was too much effort. Your judgement, skills and so on will determine how you approach things.The penalties for violating the Masquerade by exposing vampiric activities to the Kine (humans) can be severe if you're not careful. Feed on anyone out in the open, use certain powers openly, amusement, even the wrong speech choice can get you in trouble. Five strikes and it's an automatic final death/game over. Humanity Loss, unfortunately with the XP you can spend to undo is a little less dire but be careless and not fix a severe deficit and suddenly you're looking at a frenzy where you literally lose control for a bit. Injury and thirst for blood can bring out the vampiric beast within. Mostly, a savvy player will sidestep these pitfalls but occasionally, you’ll find yourself desperate for blood and a crowd of unwitting humans after a hellish quest so stock up on those spare blood bags.Gameplay can get frustrating and there's no difficulty bar. My best advice to new players is don't get intimidated, and you'll make it through, even if you need to add self-advantage.I won't spoil the main game but the World of Darkness universe is an amazing playground for your vampire RPG-ing wants. You have to play it for yourself and carve out your potential eternal life, although be careful. The wrong side at the end can leave your legacy as a fate worse than death. It’s a game of consequences with logic behind decisions and outcomes based on your choices. Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines is a great vampire RPG, arguably one of the only chances you'll have to play a vampire as they were made to be and it leaves you wondering why more entries couldn't have been made. It is 'the' vampire RPG everyone wishing to sink their fangs into the night must have and the price is worth the gamble to get it running on newer computers.My final score for this game is 9.5/10 and the half point loss is for the bug that required no-clip and the fifteen reloads it took to get through to the next section for an otherwise game breaking bug. Any older game made for XP and earlier you pick up at this point will come with all kinds of issues but this game was released as an unstable beta, requiring years of caring work by Wesp5, who deserves an eternity of gratitude for getting this game to run as well as it does.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I'll give you the TL;DR right away to save you some time: BUY THIS GAME. NOW. (or wait until it's $5, either way, it's worth it)Cons:Buggy. Download the unofficial patch (link in Steam forums), it fixes most of the bugs. I recommend the basic patch on your first playthrough. There's still some bugs after the patch, but just make sure you save a lot. Fixing most bugs is as simple as restarting the game and reloading your save. I only had to do this maybe two-three times with the patch. It's probably more without it. I encountered no game-breaking bugs. I do hear of some people having a hard time getting it running as well. I've never had issues, but the solutions are out there, and the effort is worth it.Clunky Combat. This game tricks you into thinking it's going to be more like an FPS, at first. Disregard. It's fairly straightforward RPG combat via mashing the left-click (with a little more to it as you'll learn). Guns are very weird at first, and melee is a bit hard to grasp right away. I actually quit and uninstalled the game on my first character because of this. I'm very glad I gave it a second chance. Once you get used to it, it's not bad at all. You'll be a ninja in no time, I promise.Character models. This is more of a personal preference, but I think the chracters have a bit too much charicature. They're a bit cartoony as you can see by the screenshots. In spite of that, the game is actually pretty dark, gritty, and sometimes, downright scary. I often forgot all about them while playing.Animations. The animations, especially during cutscenes, are a bit funky. It's bearable, though. And that's just the body animations. The facial animations are pretty good. Great for 2004. The cloth physics are a bit wack.Map size. A pro and a con at the same time, almost. The map is split into fairly small loading zones focused around city hubs and various quest locations. If you're used to more open worlds, it might take a bit to get used to. It doesn't bother me, personally. They do a decent job at filling them with content, even if the content does get a bit thinner in the later maps (a lot of games do this).Pros:Atmosphere. The biggest seller for me in this game. Bloodlines nails it's gothic atmoshere so well, it's almost uncanny. It's horror elements are also very well executed. Not too many games can get my heart racing like this one has. One part in particular, if you don't know what you're doing, is nightmare inducing (Hint: The last screenshot might have something to do with the part I'm referring to).Story. The story is gripping and packed with intrigue. Some of the gameplay elements might get a bit repetitive (as with just about any game), but I was always driven to continue just to see events unfold. Lots of twists and turns. Everything you would want from a VtM story. Some things were a bit obvious, but everything works. There's also multiple endings depending on where you choose to put your loyalty. They ultimately lead to the same place and overall outcome, but this didn't bother me. I found that siding with myself got some of the most epic dialogue and immersion. Every step of the way, you really feel like you're being dragged deeper down into a dark underworld. And don't worry if you're not familiar with the PnP, this game does a great job introducing fledglings to the VtM universe.Characters. Memorable and well voice-acted. They drive the story along flawlessly. Not much else to say about that.Choice. Wanna skulk in the shadows, Gordon Freeman through ventilation systems, picking locks and hack computers to get through? Or do you wanna kick the door in and beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everything with your fists? You got it. Unfortunately, the amount of choice peters off around the halfway mark. Due to Troika having their budget and their deadlines cut by Activision, much of the latter half of the game is very combat heavy. The story and characters don't falter, though. I found stealth and social-focused characters fairly difficult to play later on. In some cases, I even cheated and/or just stopped advancing with those characters. It's a bit disheartening, but it is what it is. You can still enjoy the first half thoroughly, with social or stealth. Just make your first character combat-focused to get the whole story without much of a hitch, then play around with the other stuff in subsequent playthroughs.Music. The music selection is small, but well-produced. They are also in non-propietary formats in the game files, so if you really enjoy them, you can copy them to your preferred device.Replayability. Although the game isn't terribly long, there's plenty of oppurtunity for replay. Playing different clans alters your experience, sometimes dramatically. I recommend a Brujah specializing in Celerity for an easy-mode play through. The Matrix-esque effects of a high Celerity level is pretty neat. The wacky Malkavian makes a great second character (might be hard to follow along with the dialogue for a first-timer). Nosferatu is expert mode. Along with that, the modding community is still undead and well. You can find everything from the basic bug-fixing patches like suggested above, all the way to major game alterations. I state again, I recommend only the basic unofficial patch for a fledgling to minimize bugs/incompatibility frustration.Conclusion:Although both lists have a similar number of entries, I assure you, the Pros FAR outweigh the cons. This is the perfect game to play during the Halloween season (in which it usually goes on sale as well). I can play it any time of day, myself. With CCP plopping their fat asses on the IP with no apparent interest in using it, this is the best VtM game you're going to get for a long time. In extension, I would argue that it's the best vampire game ever made, and sadly, will probably remain so.

												This is one of the greatest games of all time.  It also is a twitchy pile of bugs by default, so it's a misunderstood cult classic that's basically unplayable by default.  Don't let that scare you, Bloodlines spins an amazing world with great characters, disturbing ideas, and an amazing amount of choice that is rarely seen in games (it puts Mass Effect to shame, at least). The combat is decent, but it's definitely not the important part of this game and can make you game a bit annoying if you built a poorly-planned character.Don't let the negatives dissuade you though, this game has hundreds of hours of gameplay if you look for it and tremendous replayability. Posted: December 16, 2010
												I had to go back and re-review this.It's dated, it's bugged and it's a bit short... but none of that matters, because this game is down right awesome, even with it's quirks and flaws. The game focuses mainly around Vampire societies, clans and other assorted things most people don't actually touch on that go beyond the "I'm a vampire. I'm a monster. Blurgh!" stereotype as surprise surprise, you've just recently become a vampire yourself.Picking a clan you get sired into also affects how people react and talk to you or how the game plays itself. Picking Malkavian makes everyone want to smash their faces in trying to understand your cryptic methaphors, Tremere makes people wary about you because you can use your own blood as a magic weapon and Nospheratu means getting in the shadows because you're so god damn ugly and no one wants to see your face. Just a few examples. While not the longest game ever, it's still pretty good for all it's worth.VtM:B is the game to get if you're into the vampire thing and going beyond blood sucking children of the night, minus Stephenie Meyer's sparkling turd dust.

It was released in an unfinished state but that can be fixed with a patch since the game has had lots of attention from fans for over a decade.So what is it all about? Well, you are basically a random person turned into a vampire. After this you get introduced to the vampire society and the game starts. Amazing game overall, it has aged really well. The voice acting is amazing and all the side quests are fun in their own way. There are seven different vampires you can choose to play as. All with different pros and cons. I'd recommend playing through as any clan but the malkavian and then replaying the game as a Malkavian, as it is almost impossible to understand without finishing it once first.So... Yeah, I recommend this game

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.Long name, incredible game. Quite possibly the best game I have ever played. I have reached the final boss several times, but only finally got around to giving him his Final Death today. Taking around thirty hours, this is a game complete with an amazing story, interesting characters, cool powers, and the most legit vampire's I know of. The basic story begins with your 'embrace' - where you become a vampire - and continues as your rise in power and prestige, until you are causing the events, rather than reacting to them.Each of the nine clans you can choose from have different abilities. They could be considered classes, similar to other games, but they aren't usually wildly different. Most of the change is in the player models, and the powers - each clan getting two powers from a pool, and a third unique to their clan. But there are enough differences to make replaying a possibility. For example, the Nosferatu are hideous, and as such cannot seduce people for blood, and instead have to suck on rats in the sewers below the streets, while the Ventrue clan is the opposite - they cannot drink from rats due to their nobility. Another is clan Malkavian; each and every one of them is insane. Incredibly, they have 100% unique dialogue, opposed to other clans having a few lines or opportunities each, and can engage in some interesting tangents - such as having a conversation with the news reporter on TV.While the vanilla version is very buggy - due to the developers being rushed in their final stages - most of these issues can be resolves with the fan made Unofficial Patch, which is a must-get if you plan on playing. It's not the prettiest game either, with some pretty terrible animations at times, but all this is forgiveable in the face of such a wonderful experience. The game uses Valve's source engine (an earlier version of the engine Titanfall is built on), and was released on the same day as Half-Life 2; and though the models in the game are by no means of equal quality, they are attractive in their own way, and help nail the bleak, horror/noir atmosphere.If Firefly was a game, it would be this one. While the themes are not at all similar, it is the kind of game that when someone brings it up in conversation, or you read about it on the net, you pretty much have no choice but to reinstall and have another crack at it.10/10. I honestly cannot think of any way to improve it, other than give the devs more time to improve a couple of the cutscenes.tl;dr - V:TM-B is one of the best games ever. It is often on sale on Steam. buy it. Install the most recent Unofficial Patch. Enjoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of it.P.S. ♥♥♥♥ the haunted hotel. The game isn't all that scary, the hotel always gets me.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I bought this game just cause it was on sale for $5, didn't think much of it, but when I played it I absolutely fell in love with the game! Not gonna lie, this game is GREAT but it has many flaws. From what I heard the game was rushed, which really shows. Buggy graphics and animations, broken stealth system, broken damage system. Besides that it's still a solid game with rich dialogue and an interesting storyline. The games' lore is very detailed, and there are even books you can buy that tell you about the clans! Even after the game ends there's still so much to learn about the world it takes place in, the playable clans the unplayable clans, and the other supernatural beings. I've played the game 3 times just with the patch, and now I'm currently playing with a mod called 'The Final Nights' which adds all new clans and game mechanics. So after you get bored of the regular game you can download one of the many mods available. I highly recommend this game, even though it's old and rushed it's still an amazing rpg. (This game can be hard at times especially near the end, just a heads up.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is something that is very unfortunate. It has a seriously interesting world, that will imerse you regardless of whether you're a fan of gothic culture or not. It spins a vampire tale that is both interesting and enjoyable at the same time. The plot remains solid and tense up until the 75% mark and then it feels unfortunatly rushed. I ended this story, feeling satisified of the journey but the overal end just left me feeling like alot of choices I made didn't matter. This is of course, due to the game developer being rushed to finish the game on time and highlights of game gems such as this one, are unfortunatly not given the extra attention they deserved.Gameplay is very similar to that of games like Deus Ex. You are allowed to tackle objectives in any way you wish, in fact the game presents you with a series of classes which almost define your playstyle from then on. And this isn't just a minor state boost ethier. Playing as a particular class for example, renders you unable to travel on the streets due to your inability to blend in. The consequence of this is that you spend most of the game in sewers eating rats, but have a massive advantage when it comes to any stealth encounter. This is one of the fantastic game design choices the games makes! Certain vampire classes have advanatges in certain areas. Some are good at meddling with humans, others are better at combat and violence. One class is considered insane, and has an entire dialouge choice to back it up in conversations. Combat can be a little worse for ware, but it isn't unplayable. The broken AI, doesn't tend to put up much of a fight - especially in stealth sections. When you pick your class, you will find it difficult to progress down any other path. Stealth classes, tend to be killed quite easily if you try full frontal combat. Stealth isn't just a one off thing ethier, it is supported by stealth kills, shadow blending etc. Overall, when you play this game - it is very difficult not to appreciate it, for what it could be and for what it is. I find it difficult to discredit the game up to the 75% mark. After that, things are obviously rushed, everything becomes more combat focused and you will find yourself struggling if you didn't pick a combat class. Before that though, is a game that definatly rewards player choice in both story and gameplay. It provide an interesting, immersive gothic world that will delight both those who enjoy vampire culture and those who don't, alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2013
												A flawed masterpiece.The game has its problems, that's undeniable.  It seems the development team ended up being punished by time constraints and ended up sorely neglecting the last quarter of the game; neglecting the truly excellent role-playing elements for more and more uninspired combat.  Fortunately, thanks to numerous community patches, the rest of the game has aged pretty well.If you overlook the minor annoyance that combat represents, and the fact that the end of the game feels too brief and rushed, even with the significant amount of "lost content" added to it by the aforementioned  patches, then you're in for a real treat.The atmosphere is outstanding; the game does an excellent job of creating an almost film-noir bleakness that typifies the World of Darkness setting.  At least two relatively early missions ratchet up the creepy into moments of true horror, and there is a constant air of menace that you'd expect from a game where you build a custom vampire and embark on the life of a creature-of-the-night.The roleplaying elements are truly first-rate.  Some of the best I have ever seen, with characters that are unique, memorable, and fully formed.  The degree with which you can interact them is solid, and just a whisker shy of being superlative.The skill-sets you can pick from strike a great balance between utility (being able to hack computer terminals for info, or lock-pick), social (seduction, intmidation), and combat.The stealth system is solid, but not amazing – the obfuscate ability makes it pretty redundant for a couple of "clans" (classes) but stealth-kills are an effective tool in most situations.The plot is gripping, although as I mentioned above the conclusion feels a little rushed; as if they ran out of time in the third act and just cut-to-the-chase.  The numerous side-quests are insinuated into the game subtlely, and in a way that makes completing them fun, rather than just busy-work you have to go through to get 100% completion or some extra XP and loot.This game is truly a diamond in the rough.

And it just has so much replay value due to the different clans you can play as (not to mention the gender option - female vampires have a kinda sexy way of taking their night snacks). The music is great too, varying between atmospheric to industrial.I think the devs should perhaps clean up a bitmap or two on this new release, because the various maps - especially useful as Nosferatu as you'll be hitting the sewers a lot due to their unsightly appearance - are not clear. If you can find the maps online do print a copy if you're playing as Nosferatu. Even with these cosmetic issues it's still a wonderful game.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												The game is quite old, so the graphics are not all that. You will also need to download a fan-made patch to make it work properly, but once that's sorted the game works just fine.You get to choose one out of seven clans, your gender, and if you want - a backstory. All of these will have an impact on your playthrough, and gives you a lot of diversity to play with. Each clan has different abilities and traits. Sadly, you don't get to customise your appearance though, it's set by your sex and clan.The dialogue options allows you to voice your opinion, often in a rude way. The game gives you the options you need to go around and be an a-hole to everyone, and you can of course lick butt if that's more of your style. There will also be unique dialogue options based off your clan, stats and abilities.As you play through the game you will eventually be part of a story of politics, intrigue, and the fight for power and gain in the city. You will get to choose through your actions the outcome of this struggle, which I found very satisfying as you can make the ending of the game directly reflect your opinion on the conflicting factions of LA. There is no black and white answer here, as all these factions could be considered bad in different ways.All in all it's a good experience, and I highly recommend it.Oh, and one last bit of advice: Do not open the sarcophagus.

												Vampire Bloodlines is an awesome game! Hardly anyone has heard of it because it came out the same day as Half Life 2 (so it's pretty obvious why it hasn't had much limelight) You start out by either choosing your own clan and gender, or answering a few questions and letting the game assign you a clan. After assigning stats and giving yourself a name, the game opens with a cinematic of you doing the dirty with some ♥♥♥♥♥ (or man♥♥♥♥♥) and suddenly some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s break in and stake her (or him) and you! It then cuts to you both knelt infront of a large audience of various vampire clans and groups (apparently in this, staking only paralyzes) and then your lover (♥♥♥♥♥) gets put to death for changing you into a vampire without permission, but you get set free as it wasn't your fault! Then the fun begins in a dark grissley world full of sex, violence and a wide variety of enemies. Although this IS an RPG, don't go into it expecting a world the size of Skyrim! Just expect a good game.

Plus both stealth lovers and gun fanatics can have fun, with both being great choices for getting most jobs done. Either way, action and stealth lovers alike are sure to have fun with this game.My only problems with it are that it can be really glitchy, so it would be best if you went and downloaded the unofficial patch, which fixes problems for newer systems while also adding new quests and weapons.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Every time someone mentions it, someone will reinstall it.This is one of the most enjoyable games you'll ever play. Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines is first person and third person action RPG based of the pen and paper RPG of the same title(Vampire the Masquerade). You play as a fledgling vampire who was spared after your sire was executed, now you have to fight the beast inside you by keeping your humanity and obey the laws of the masquerade.Story 10/10This game has amazing writing. From the get go you got yourself into some vampire politics and have a whole new world around you that you have to discover. There's not only kine and kindred (humans and human like vampires) there are also things like the sabbat, werewolves, vampire hunters, etc. The main vampire government are the Camarilla, but their are also vampire rebels known as the Anarchs. As the story progresses you'll have to pick a side. Beyond the main story there are countless side missions that often have mini stories or side stories to them.Gameplay 9/10It's got a lot of buggy issues to the game but there are several 'unofficial' patches to the game that can help. I can't compare the vanilla game with the patched version because I installed the patch before playing it. But mainly there are various mechanics to the game, from simple combat like shooting and melee attacks, disciplines which are basically spells, you have a blood bar you regenerate from drinking blood, you have a humanity bar you need to keep balanced, and finally the masquerade bar. Knowing the names of the mechanics is one thing, figuring and mastering them is another.The game is very immersive, depending on what clan you are and what you do and say to people effects how you are treated by various characters throughout the game. The game allows you to have your own play style, from sneaking around vents to going guns a blazing, and seducing or threatening people you talk to to get information. There are also the little things that make this game so amusing as well, for example I mercilessly murdered a fat guy at a diner and I heard the sounds of sirens and the police were waiting outside, I also broke into an art gallery and a mission later watched a news reporter talk about that very thing. Great stuff!Music 10/10The music is top notch! Composed by Rik Schaffer & various others, the game has many tracks to fit the mood. From ambient tracks for the streets of LA and haunted hotels to Club tracks by actual bands and slow tracks to strip clubs. I absolutely love it!Over all: 9/10VtMB is an amazing game to have. I personally found it hard to stop playing, and within two and a half days already had 25 hours of play time. Even though I make this sound like a masterpiece it does have it's negatives like the need for a patch to properly work, it gets a bit hard/confusing at times to find stuff or complete objectives, or the fact there's not enough Jeanette(play the game and you'll know what I mean ;P)! ::I almost forgot to mention this game has lots of sexual content, it almost surprised me. So if you're not into that kind of thing or just don't like it in general I would highly consider that a factor before thinking about buying this game::  But this is still something to have, especially if you're into vampires or just Action RPG's in general. So I urge you to check it out!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												One of the hardest parts of writing any good review comes from writing the review itself. Every person has their own appeal, games they like and dislike, and reasons for those likes and dislikes. Not every game a reviewer will play will conform to those likes or dislikes, and a review must still compose himself and present a fair and balanced review in spite of his personal thoughts. I bring this up because it is very difficult to talk about Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines (hereafter referred to simply as ‘Vampire') without delving into the subjective elements it presents without sucking all the emotion and personality from the review and transforming it into a technical overview of the game itself. As such, I have divided this game up into two sections, an objective and a subjective one. But first an overview of the game itself;In Vampire you play as a young person living in L.A. who has recently been transformed into one of the undead. Upon your indoctrination you quickly come to discover that the vampire society needs to be very secretive about how they act so as to keep the public unaware of their actions. Before long, though a sarcophagus which may or may not house the remains of a very ancient and very powerful vampire is uncovered and the various vampire clans in the city all begin a secret war of cloak and dagger tactics, each trying to recover the sarcophagus and its contents or deny them to others for themselves, all while trying to keep their very existence secretive from humans.Firstly, for the objective. The game is VERY well designed and it shows in its game mechanics. Serving as a action RPG with elements of The Elder Scrolls (except less open, confining the player to four primary districts that are fairly small and multiple dungeons) it is solid right from the get-go. From the beginning you are forced to select one of a series of vampire clans, each offering its own unique set of bonuses, abilities, and disadvantages that will end up shaping how you play. I, personally, ended up going with Clan Ventrue which focuses a lot on persuasion, but can't feed off of animals and can only feed reliably on upper-class humans. Someone else may end up with Nosferatu which can't raise their appearance at all and has to avoid being seen at all by humans for example.The gameplay itself is fairly solid with most of the controls being very tight and having almost no real problems beyond a few glitches (which I will cover later) which I can't blame on the controls. One of the interesting things is that, instead of leveling up stats like strength and such, the player instead levels up various skills and abilities which, in turn, affect stats. This can cause for some very interesting outcomes where a character may choose to level up a skill they don't intend to use at all to bolster another skill which they do, in fact, use and results both in a large amount of flexibility and interesting builds as well as a drive to experiment around and see what else can be done.Another interesting thing is that players do not gain experience from killing enemies in the slightest, but rather from quest completion. This puts an added drive to complete even simple sidequests as the added experience is the only way to make your character stronger.Lastly, there are two special meters that will need proper attention. The Humanity meter and the Masquerade meter. A large focus of the game is the focus on struggling against the vampire urges and keeping ones self ‘human' despite needing to drink human blood in order to survive. Certain actions can cause players to lose some of their humanity and, as the gauge lowers to 0, it can result in them becoming utterly feral. Meanwhile, keeping the humanity high can result in a weaker vampire who struggles with their new nature. Additionally, keeping ones actions as a vampire secretive is very key and, every time a player is caught being a vampire in public, it costs them on the Masquerade meter. They start with a set amount of chances and, if those chances ever all disappear, game over (going feral wastes a chance). This puts an added focus on keeping ones nature as a vampire truly secret and staying human as going feral at the wrong time on a player who didn't try to keep hidden can cause an outright loss.Visually the game is fairly solid as well. While, sadly, you won't be able to delve too deep into the many complexities of polygon count, it very successfully manages to convey the feeling of the World of Darkness (the world as a vampire sees it). Vampire does its best to drive this home too, but manages to back it up with some solid displays. While they may look a bit dated today, there is a HUGE difference between ‘dated' and ‘bad' and this is most certainly not the latter.There are some problems with the game though. First off it seems to revel in giving vague directions and not giving you anything resembling a quest-marker. While this wouldn't normally be too bad of a thing it is very easy to end up lost and unsure of where to go or who to talk too, especially if you stop playing the game for a week or more and don't remember the location of an important NPC with the lack of a map (aside from some bus-stop signs) driving the annoyance home. But, more overbearingly, is the glitches. There are a LOT in this game, and they are NOT of the minor kind. These are the kind that can destroy a game and leave it unplayable. Hunting down a patch and/or activating the command console may very well be a requirement for this game.And now for the subjective. This is a dark game. A VERY dark game to say the least. The game makes sure to reinforce this with such locations like abandoned hospitals, scummy apartment buildings, sleazy motels, brothels and night clubs galore, and death around every corner. The streets are almost never clean and are littered with trash, bums and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s seem to be the most common ‘professions', and so forth. People looking for a game about sparkling vampires, or even just ‘normal' vampires may find themselves off-put easily. This is a very dark and pessimistic game, and it ended up causing me to rethink about how to score this.To say that this is a bad game simply because it's world is so scummy and grim is shortselling what the game does right. In any other setting where you can count the number of people who are ‘good' on more than one hand this probably would have been an amazing title. However, this game does not hide for even a moment that this is a grim and depressing world. People not looking for this sort of thing specifically can very easily end up becoming disguised and/or offended by it. Even the ending of the game seems to love rubbing in just how dark this world is.As a result, I feel it is VERY important to look into the game before buying it and deciding if you wish to play a game like this. While it can be enthralling for people who revel in its darkness, for those people looking for even the tiniest ray of light and hope, they would be better off searching elsewhere.In summery: while a solid game that is mired by some technical problems, its subjective aspects and story may simply be so off-putting to a player who does not enjoy its dark and grim world as to not make this game recommendable on a whim. If you buy this game, you should know what you're getting into, because this game is in no way shy about tossing you into the shadows.My pricing: For someone looking for a dark game: 15-20 bucks. It's very solid, if a bit dated and dealing with bugs.For someone not: Avoid at all costs. Remember, this is a game where it is possible to lose because you couldn't pretend to be a human being instead of a blood-sucking monster well enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Favourite game, and has been for a few years. Fun, quirky, clever, and the graphics really aren't that bad at all for its time. It can be extremely buggy, even game-breaking at times, but the fanmade patch usually fixes those problems. Combat is relatively simple. It's important to remember you can't be a jack of all trades. There's very limited EXP in the game (which is why I suggest playing all of the side-quests) so it's best to spec into things. The characters are cool. There's several factions you can join. Playing as different clans can prove to be a new experience (especially Malkavians, Nosferatus and Tremere, but my favourite is Gangrel as bland as it is.) I find characters like Jack and Gary to be hilarious. There's a great voice acting crew, too. Most of the voice actors sound like they put some real heart into it. Though the generic NPCs that roam around sometimes sound like they used a less-than-moderate quality microphone and didn't care. All in all, I think this game is 10/10. Just make sure you patch it before you play it or you're going to have a bad time.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												A lightening pearl in a World of Darkness, which I had forgotten eventually for ten long years. In December 2004, I installed this game for the first time, but at that early point in time, this game was released unfinished. At the same day, i happily uninstalled it to never play it again because of the heavy load of bugs and crashes. 10 Years and a lot of unofficial patches later, in December 2014, I bought this game on Steam for 5€, installed the 9.2 patch and completed it with much joy in 43 hours, with no frustrations at all and even without having to use a single cheat. Even installed on a Windows 8.1 x64, the game did only crash twice, both times in the very beginning while configuring my character.I enjoyed every minute of it, and I will certainly play it again in the future. Who could have ever imagined this game would become such a Cult Classic? A must-have for fans of RPG, vampires or just all good PC games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2013
												Hands down the BEST ROLE playing game made to date (2013). And it was made in 2004. Also the best RPG mechanic I've ever played. Makes the systems used in various MMO's and other rpg seem massively inferior and sometimes pitiful. Highlights are: Every character (except yours) is voice acted, and done by professionals. Your dialogue choices are numerous and varied, and based off how you increase your social skills. Every character is really interesting, and all side quests are excellent. All dialogue is very well written.The main story is really good. And the choice of endings is more "branched" then even current rivals, although thats not saying much (Except for Witcher II which holds the crown for choices that  change the entire game and political landscape, and truly stands out in the RPG marketplace). There is plenty of music made by professionals. There are details like news reports and radio shows that progress as you progress thru the game and make mention of things you do. An if you play Malkav you are in for a bonus surprise with regard to that. The whole atmosphere is so darn immersive and well constructed.Multiple clans to play, so the game has at least a couple of repeat play thru's. By my count, minimum of three, since the Nosferatu (stealthy) are quite different, and certainly the Malkavs (totally crazy), and then there is everyone else (they follow more conventional social interaction).Make sure you check out/read up on the community mods for the latest patch (Activision does not bother to fix their own property), and also resolution fixes.

												A Classic RPG with a mature rating, a bunch of bugs, and patchs. Be sure and read the forums for this game BEFORE purchasing. I had to apply some patches before I could run the game on a Windows 7 SP 1 machine. Once the game was patched it is a joy to play. There are multiple paths through the game and a pseudo open world environment to explore. There are multiple endings based upon the players choices. Decent replayability as well.I did experience a few bugs in the game that required switching to a developers console to work around. No show stoppers, just a few nuisances.The game may not run on Windows 8 | 10 and above based upon a report from Microsoft's Upgrade Assistant. The good news is that the game will run in the WINE emulator.If you enjoy classic RPG games with multiple story lines and are not put off by the need to apply patches and work around a few bugs, then grab this game and enjoy.

And hey, maybe that's an incentive for you! Whatevs. It's a great and under appreciated game. Give it a go!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines is a heavily story driven Action-RPG where there's several town hubs with whacky characters who want YOU to do their bidding. Everyone has their own ulterior motive and the deep lore that goes into the "World of Darkness" that this game is based on just enhances the feel and depth of this story.The combat mechanics are pretty simple, there's 2 types of weapons, melee and ranged. If you want to be a crazy monster vampire who uses his fists to beat people into dust.. You can do that. If you want to use ranged weapons by running around and shooting people up.. You can do that.  If you want to go around with a katana and slash people up.. You can do that as well. The skill and "clan" system helps you build your character the way you want to. There's many different clans, all of them have different skill sets, pros and cons - There's the nosferatu that need to go through sewers because of their hideous deformed bodies would alert humans of the supernatural. There's the Malkavian who keeps on hearing different voices in their heads (Although most of it seems gibberish, a lot of it is actually true and the voice can also tell you the future or hidden intends behind the people.), malkavians have completely different dialogue options and their lines can also be seen as insane and convoluted with hidden intents. The lore is just so deep in this that you can't help but get invested.This games second strong point is choice. You will have different choices on how to complete your quests, you will have choices on what you would like to do with the item, would you be OK with giving the item to the person who wants it, or can you find a third party who will offer more for it? Do you care for your own humanity and help people out just to keep your connection to the mortal life that you had. Or will you only look out for yourself, discarding the other peoples needs just to further your own agenda. There are multiple choices for everything you do, but what's great is that there's choices that aren't apparent and if you manage to find them they will usually pay off sweetly. This is a masterpiece in gamedesign. You WILL find interesting quests and items if you look around enough and you are not rewarded for going around and killing everything, but are rather ENCOURAGED to do things the way you want to.Even though this game was released in an extremely buggy state because the game developer didn't have enough money to keep working on this. The game has been fixed with several patches (Some of the game devs worked for free after getting laid off, just to fix this. Goes to show how much they actually loved this game.).. Now thanks to the huge community there's several mods, unofficial expansions, etc that completely change up this game.Before buying this game on steam I had already spent more then 100 hours in this, so I've played this for around 200 hours or so..

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												I mostly love this game for the world created for it, and the stories contained within that world. Besides that, it's got memorable characters, a good soundtrack and can be funny at times, both on purpose and accidentally (keep in mind this was released in '04). Combat gets repetitive pretty quickly, so I suggest trying to kill enemies without being detected to make things a bit more intense. I also suggest to not bother with guns and stick to melee (always collect any dropped weapons though, so you can sell them later). Plenty of sidequests to keep the main narrative from getting boring, great character sheet. I recommend the hell out of this game.

Posted: February 5, 2014
												OK, first off, you will most likely need a patch just to run this game. Unfortunately when this game was originally released it was full of bugs & I guess Steam doesn't provide any fixes but don't worry there is a solution. Go to the forum or the website patches-scrolls and install Wesp5's patch version 8.9. This person has done amazing work to not only get this game running but provided many fixes for any in-game bugs. And it's worth the extra bit of time it takes but first off the bad stuff. The first thing you will notice are the outdated graphics but they really are not that bad and you get used to it pretty quick. The worst thing is combat. It's a bit clunky.....actually, it just plain sucks but not so bad that it's unplayable. The thing is VTMB is billed as an RPG & it not only delivers but it may be the best game ever in this aspect if you like getting immersed in an excellent story. There are rules you have to (un)live by & consequences if you don't. Decisions you make early on reflect what happens later. Basically, in a nutshell, it's an RPG that truly allows you to roleplay who you create & that's what makes this game shine.
