content:
Posted: March 25, 2013
												If someone were to ask me for an incredibly non-linear RPG I could name a few.  There's Deus Ex (The original), Mass Effect, and then there's the cult classic that is Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.  A heavily overlooked title to be sure, Bloodlines is a one-of-a-kind game.  It's rare to find a non-adventure game where pretty much everything you say and the type of person you turn out to be changes how the game is played drastically.  In that sense, this game is what I would consider the true successor to Deus Ex.Much like Deus Ex, the game revolves around making choices.  For instance, there can be a story chain revolving around some character, and just because you♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥him off earlier you've drastically changed the course of the chain.  This might sound shallow by the way I'm explaining it, but some of the consequences behind ones choices aren't immediately noticeable, which adds to the game's unpredictability.  Skills also play into the choices, much like they can in Knights of the Old Republic, and not only offer more choices, but they also offer more ways to play the game.Also like Deus Ex, the game almost always offers several ways to go about missions, though not with the versatility of Deus Ex (and understandably so).  There's usually a direct approach, a rather intuitive sneaking approach, and a charismatic approach, though each of these approaches can branch off into other approaches as well, which gives the game quite a bit of replay value.  Similarly, because your a vampire, you are also given skills that, depending on which race you are, can give you even more ways of going about the game.The only real downside to the game is its combat system.  Well, specifically, it's hand-to-hand combat system.  It's kinda...bad.  It's somewhat clunky and inaccurate, but it isn't terrible and can certainly be enjoyable, and if you don't like it you can always employ your skills and/or grab a gun.If you're looking for an incredibly non-linear title, this game is definitely for you.  Despite its age, the game hits many strides in its storytelling and non-linearity, and it hearkens back to the days of Deus Ex on more than one occasion.  The side-quests can also be shockingly impressionable, such as one mission where you go to an abandoned hotel and...well, it'd better that you just play it.  Pick up this game, it's a very good title.  If you're looking for a deal, it almost always goes on sale during the Halloween Sale.

Posted: December 31, 2010
												Don't let its appearance deceive you; underneath an early Source Engine exterior lies a truly magnificent game that takes the World of Darkness Role-Playing system and brings it to the  moderately-sized screen. Taking the role of a newly-turned vampire, the player navigates the strange new world of the supernatural as the Vampire Society faces a threat that could change the world as we know it. Choose supernatural powers such as transmogrification and invisibility and master skills such as lockpicking, firearms and hacking and face off with a host of foes that would do anything to see you die your last death. You're about to find out that the World of Darkness isn't much better than our own...

The graphics may be dated but this game is seriously awesome, if you got textures problems then deactivate/activate '' bump mapping '' in the options In game, it works great for me.If your game won't launch/crash then launch the game in administrator mode and Windows XP (Service Pack 2) it works for me, you can also download the custom patches but I'm not using them and the game is working pretty fine.Now, you'll probably say '' vampires are gay and it's gay to watch/play them ''. Well I've never seen a vampire that was gay and I actually love girls and only girls.Vampires are awesome, supernatural stuff always been awesome and the vampires are In my opinion, the greatest, now of course Twilight is another story, Twilight is giving a bad name to the vampires but do not trust Twilight, it's stupid.Vampire: The Masquerade, Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Castlevania, Legacy of Kain, BloodRayne, Blood Omen, Darkstalkers, Soul Reaver, Nosferatu, Dracula: Undead Awakening and The Elder Scrolls just to name some, there are some others that are really great, that's about it for the video games.The Vampire Diaries, True Blood, The Originals, Buffy the Vampire Slayer are some great vampire TV series. The Vampire Diaries and The Originals are my favorites, you'll love them if you love history and supernatural even if they're not really horror, drama and suspense, True Blood is really great too.Let Me In, Near Dark, Blade are some great vampire movies.Hellsing, Vampire Knight, Blood + are some great vampire animes.There are also books like The Vampire Diaries (the original serie and the new one) and probably many more but I am not much of a reader.If you've watched, played, read all of them and didn't like any of them then you're just not to Vampire/Supernatural stuff.Look at the vampire lord in The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim, It is amazing, not like Twilight.Vampires can be pretty badass actually, just stop looking at Twilight.I seriously wish that there would be another Vampire The Masquerade but It probably won't happen.Anyway great game, I recommend 9.5/10 and don't forget, Twilight is simply stupid, vampires aren't about beauty, In the Vampire Diaries they manage to make it awesome but normally vampires are supposed to be scary so do not believe Twilight.No hate, just facts, If you like Twilight then it's good for you, I don't really care but it's not a true vampire movie, it's just some random movie for 8 years old and mainstream girls.9.5/10

												This is the buggiest, practically unplayable game I've come across in my many moons on this planet.The animation is a joke, the control is horrible, you will have to patch the game before you start... Even then you will most likely need use the console and the noclip command to get through at least one part of the game.So why the positive review then?If you can somehow get the game to play through to the end, you will experience one of the most immersive RPGs of the last 20 years. The writing and voice acting are top notch. The character models are also pretty cool. Despite the fact that the sun never comes up, you will kinda feel like a Vampire. Bloodlines is a sexy and enthralling piece of work, even if it is hopelessly buggy.Oh and last point.... There is a character in the game called Jeanette Voerman. Jeanette's design was created in 2003 but her likeness was "borrowed" by DC comics for the Harley Quinn redesign in 2011. As far as I know, nobody at Troika was compensated. The Harley redesign has the same body type, same hair, same makeup, and even a choker... just like Jeanette. Yeah it's probably just a coincidence.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I tried to play this game years ago and abandoned it after a short time due to the amount of bugs rendering it unplayable. After rediscovering the game a far corner of my steam library, I decided to give it another go.Io and behold! By now, a very active community of enthusiasts has fixed 99% of these problems with their unofficial patches. And the game is an absolute gem. Brilliant writing, memorable characters, dialogues and settings. I Recommend it wholeheartedly. Where else can you play a batshit crazy vampire who ventures to have a conversation with a stop sign?While the story is quite linear, it provides reason to replay it because the different clans of vampires provide very unique game experiences: Some, like Toreador and Ventrue, will be able to talk themselves out of most situations. The Nosferatu look like the monsters they are and will cause a panic the moment a mortal sees them, which leads to a focus on sneaking and exploring the sewers of the city. The Brujah are combat experts, inviting a hack'n'slash melee-fest. Others, like the Tremere, focus on magic.And then there's the Malkavians, a strand of vampires who's very blood causes insanity, leading to some of the craziest dialogues in video game history. They can (temporarily?) cause insanity in others - who wouldn't want to make their annoying ex think you're their long lost pet turtle? It also allows them a near prophetic insight into their conversation partners' thoughts and motives - That is, if you listen to the right voices n your head and ignore the others...

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												....But seriously, play this game is all I'll say as the bottom line. Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines has one of the best voice acting I've heard in video games from the sheer amount of life breathed into each character. This game has something for everybody and may try way too hard in some places but makes up for it with variety, fun, and creative level designs that become familiar rather quickly. After installing the unofficial patch to fix this game, it becomes one of the best games you'll play from the 2000's. Take it as an RPG/Dialogue sim or make it a FPS, there's no wrong way to play this game and it'll give you enough option to try as many routes as you want without much repetition outside of the main storyline. Buy it, play it, then play it again in a completely different way and as a completely different class - this game will let very few players down. Pros:+High replayability including multiple endings and a GOOD variety of classes/clans. +Excellent Voice Acting+Decent Combat System+Great Environments+Memorable Characters+Great Writing and an interesting plot+Informative menus and inventories with a quest logCons:-Bugged as hell (fixed with the unofficial patches)-Music is pretentious and laughable and sounds like somebody compressed three entire Hot Topics into a soundtrack-Backtracking becomes tedious

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is quite a mess. There are parts missing, game-breaking bugs and more mistakes than any other game I've played. I won't lie; it's very dated and probably not for everyone. It was one of the first Source engine games to become available, but sadly the companies involved were financially doomed. Thus, the game never really got the attention it deserved.However, if you fancy yourself as a Source Engine Vampire, you'll be rewarded with this one. There's an unofficial patch, which adds more content and fixes hundreds of bugs - but it still remains quite broken. Putting all of this aside, I'm happy to recommend this title. It may even have replay value to you.Pros+ The story is perhaps one of my favourite in a game. It's dark and tries to be adult orientated. Max Payne-like?+ Reasonable variation between Vampire Clans.+ Plenty of levels spread across a wide assortment of environments. The explorable areas and buildings are quite varied.+ Vampire skills, knives, baseball bat or gun - kill at will, however you please.+ Great character progression.+ Moderate customisation.+ Dark humour.+ In-game actions decide your character's path, skills, items and fate. Play Mr Nice, or Miss Nasty.+ Faithful to the original "Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption" and the whole White Wolf thing.+ Fairly good skill set for the different Vampire Clans.+ Captivating story of your making.+ Atmospheric cinematics using the engine instead of full motion video.+ Graphics aren't terrible for it's age. At the game's release most of us went "Wow!"Cons- The dialogue scenes and their "1 - Yes, 2 - No." interaction becomes tedious after the first mission.- Major flaws in AI. Missing dialogue, broken responses and overall beta quality [at best].- Dodgy controls, FOV and camera angles.- My Vampire feels like I'm driving a bus. It's a very clumsy affair when you encounter stairs or obstacles.- Enemies usually aren't very clever or tough. There isn't much variation. Sometimes they bug too.- Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption was a much more enjoyable story, game and overall experience.Overall, if you give this game some perseverance - you will probably enjoy it. It's not that easy to become fluent - but stick with it. The endings are quite rewarding. It's also very slow to begin with - but picks up pace to be quite an enjoyable challenge. It's not unlike Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption in that respect.If you have already played Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines and enjoyed it, you probably want to check out Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption. It's much, much older - but easily one of my favourite games ever.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is known as a cult classic, and it’s certainly earned its fanbase! With 7 clans and more than one solution for most quests, there is a lot for RPG fans to sink their fangs into. The dialogue is clever and the plot is intriguing even for players who aren’t familiar with the tabletop RPG it's based off of. It also has a bunch of my favorite voice actors in its cast. (I knew I was going to have a good time when the first NPC I talked to was voiced by Bender.)Unfortunately, as other reviews have pointed out, it’s buggy as hell unpatched. Story missions near the end of the game don’t have as many solutions as earlier ones and are mostly solved by fighting, which can screw over characters that are better at sneaking or talking their way out of confrontations. Also one level in particular, the Warrens, just plain sucks; the plus version of the unofficial patch adds a shortcut that lets you skip it, thankfully.If you can look past its flaws, VtMB is a solid roleplaying experience that has more depth than even most newer RPGs. It’s just a shame that it wasn’t as polished as it could have been.Pros: Has 7 character classes that offer a unique play style, especially Nosferatu and Malkavian Many missions have multiple solutions, especially early on Great writing and complex plot Excellent voice acting Atmospheric, dark without being edgy Fans have made several patches and mods that improve the gameCons: Buggy without fan patches Can be hard to run on newer computers Late game story missions are almost entirely focused on combat Warrens level is long and godawfully boring

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines was rushed and pushed out the door by Activision. As a result, the game is rather buggy, featuring shoddy AI, missing content, broken stealth mechanics, and other annoyances. In spite of that, this is perhaps one of my favorite games I've ever played. This is an absolutely charming and underrated game.It's a closed sandbox RPG: think Deus Ex (a masterpiece) but set in the modern world... and with vampires and other creatures of the night.There are seven different vampire clans you can choose to be part of. Can't decide which one? Then take the quiz the game offers, I got the Tremere: the spellcasting mages that use blood as their mana. Allowing you to steal an opponent's blood from a distance or internally "boil" their blood until they explode into a visceral masterpiece. It's rather adorable, honestly.The gameplay is similar to Deus Ex, an RPG first person action game with multiple choices affecting the story, thus each playthrough is different from the other.There are multiple weapons to use: firearms, melee weapons, and your own clan skills are all fun to use. There is also a skill tree allowing you to customize and enchance your proficiency in certain categories, although many of the skills are rather useless save for a few circumstances.The graphics aren't too shabby to be honest. This is the first game to use the Source engine (even before Half Life 2) and while dated by today's standards, is still a fairly nice game to look at. The facial animations in particular look great.The atmosphere though is simply wonderful: the characters all feel real, the voice acting is well done, and this game's world just feels alive in its own undead way. The writing is top notch too, this is one of the funniest games I've ever played, and I still haven't started my second playthrough as a Malkavian!The bugs I mentioned before? There are fanmade fixes for them (I recommend the unofficial patch), in fact there are a lot of mods available for this game. Proof of its quality.Overall, despite its flaws, this is an awesome game that I recommend for anyone who enjoyed Deus Ex, or you really like vampires.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												A timeless classic, even in it's flawed Vanilla form. One of the more unique and interesting games i've played, especially the sotry and world. Supported by unofficial patches and mods for years now, which only made the game closer to what it's initial glory could have been had the company not met it's fate like it did.Infinitely replayable due to a large number of outcomes, dialogue, player characters and interactions with NPC's, and even your choices in character build dictate how the gameplay will be. Talk your way through the game? Use melee or ranged weapons? Fists? Rely on your powers? The choice is yours, and the gameplay differs pretty radically, especially for the Nosferatu and Malkavian clans. If you buy this game, you owe it to yourself to play as a Malkavian character in one of the playthroughs. Yes there will be more playthroughs, guaranteed!A must play for all RPG lovers, and lovers of great games.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												This game has soooooooooo many problems. It's glitchy, unpolished, and seems ready and willing to snap at any given moment, crashing and exploding like some glorious, terrifying reenactment of the fall of the Hindenburg.Yet despite that, it's worth every crash, and every glitch. It's worth those frustrating, teeth-pulling moments when the game seems to have broken into a thousand pieces. This is a game that has a soul. It's not a pretty soul, but that's probably part of the point. It's a game about monsters doing their best not to be monsters. It's a game where the developers, rather than investing time to test it properly which they probably should have, they elected to instead rewrite all of the dialogue around a single type of character, a Malkavian, that you can play. Most developers would only write in a token two or three choices that you'd get sporadically during a game. And this isn't text-based, either. They had all of the actors record additional lines so their characters would react accordingly.And it's all of these little things that keep showing up during the game. Having a tutorial that feels good to play through, even if you've gone through it before, just because they took the time to make it feel good. Designing a vibrant world full of wonderful characters that feel like they belong and have stories to tell. A story that hits so many of the right notes. I suppose it'd be of no surprise to mention that the people who worked on this worked on the original Fallout, and eventually went to Obsidian.This game isn't without problems, though. Don't get me wrong. Combat can feel weird and clunky, and sometimes unfinished. Glitches can be infuriating when they happen. And, sometimes, it feels like a game that should've spent another four months in development, because it feels like playing a barebones beta at times. But it's worth it all, just to experience everything else. It's worth the glitches.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												This game is AMAZING.  Think Fallout 3 meets the Table Top White Wolf Masquerade Vampire games.  Why there isn't another one already is beyond me.I had fun wandering around like a little fiend of the night and biting hapless b!tches before I even delved into the main story line of this game.  And if you appreciate games that have good writing, suprising humor, and take more than a walnut sized brain to plan skills and character dev - then give it a shot.  The detail in this game is OUTSTANDING.  I found myself staring at the interior of certain locations and wondering how I could build a house the same way.  Or I got lost staring up into the city sky as I walked around with my head pivoted directly upward.  IT LOOKS SO GOOD.  Ex: You go up into a super high penthouse loft and can look all the way down at the streets you just prowled. Oh, one note:  This game is excellent as is - but it ends early ie: they stopped dev on it.  Not to fear....  just download the "UNOFFICIAL PATCH."  Its a safe, free fix.  The game is SO DAMNED GOOD that someone created an unofficial patch to pull the storyline out to its full length and hyper-polish the graphics.  It is BEAUTIFULLLLLLLLLLLL.  Just google Vampire Bloodlines Unofficial Patch.  SO WORTH IT!Also try out the other Vampire the Masquerade game, "Redemption."  Its older than this one, but a masterpiece.  You can get it on Amazon.com or Gog.com for like 6 bucks and its got FANTASTIC original music, a solid storyline, and its straight from White Wolf.  The Vampire Masquerade games are REALLY ♥♥♥♥ING FANTASTIC ROLEPLAYING HORROR GAMES!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												It was at about 1pm on my birthday this year that I realised I had been playing this game for 12 hours straight and had forgone sleep simply because I needed to complete every single side-quest the game had to offer.I unrepentently love this game - I bought it on sale as a joke because I remembered seeing it in a Yu-Gi-Oh! Abridged let's play series when I was an embarassing tween. I thought it would just be a fun early 2000s RPG, but it's that and much more - humorous and extremely well written, simple enough for a filthy casual like me to play but immersive enough that the relative lack of difficulty was never boring or tedious.While the price is a little higher than it needs to be (in my stingy opinion), if this game is on sale, BUY IT. You won't regret it, I promise.If you do buy this game I also highly recommend downloading the Unnoficial Plus Patch. The (Non-Plus) Unnoficial Patch is generally required to run the game on newer computers, but the Plus Patch takes this game from great to amazing - upgrading the character creation, tying together storylines, giving better quest rewards and fixing all the little annoying glitches the unmodded version has - just check the Bloodlines wiki to see what I'm talking about.And a little advice from experience - don't play as Nosferatu on your first run. It's tempting, I know, but while invisibility is awesome, constantly blowing your cover due to severe butterface is a bit of a bummer.EDIT: I nominated this game for the "I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award" award in the Steam Awards 2016, if that tells you anything about how much I like it!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Everytime I buy a game I want two things. A well made story, and fun gameplay that makes me have to think. This game delivered on both fronts fantastically. I would even go so far as to say that this is my second favorite game of all time (the first being DA:O) The game not only has branching dialog options, but multiple factions and endings. It also has a level up system similar to shadowrun, with you being able to improve both combat and non combat skills. This makes balancing your character hard, because while you may be able to talk your way out of some fights, not all of them will be easy or even possible. The game made for a fun experience where I felt like a bloodsucker stalking the streets of hollywood, caught up in a battle with multiple choices and vital decisions that could change the world. Overall, the great story wrapped me up in a web and I thought about the moral and fatal conse qunces of every action, from decisions that could shake the world, to where to spend my experience so that i could spend another night breathing, VTMB had me thinking about every action, and their consequences. 10/10P.S. Install the unofficial patch, you won't regrett it.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2013
												If someone were to ask me for an incredibly non-linear RPG I could name a few.  There's Deus Ex (The original), Mass Effect, and then there's the cult classic that is Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines.  A heavily overlooked title to be sure, Bloodlines is a one-of-a-kind game.  It's rare to find a non-adventure game where pretty much everything you say and the type of person you turn out to be changes how the game is played drastically.  In that sense, this game is what I would consider the true successor to Deus Ex.Much like Deus Ex, the game revolves around making choices.  For instance, there can be a story chain revolving around some character, and just because you♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥him off earlier you've drastically changed the course of the chain.  This might sound shallow by the way I'm explaining it, but some of the consequences behind ones choices aren't immediately noticeable, which adds to the game's unpredictability.  Skills also play into the choices, much like they can in Knights of the Old Republic, and not only offer more choices, but they also offer more ways to play the game.Also like Deus Ex, the game almost always offers several ways to go about missions, though not with the versatility of Deus Ex (and understandably so).  There's usually a direct approach, a rather intuitive sneaking approach, and a charismatic approach, though each of these approaches can branch off into other approaches as well, which gives the game quite a bit of replay value.  Similarly, because your a vampire, you are also given skills that, depending on which race you are, can give you even more ways of going about the game.The only real downside to the game is its combat system.  Well, specifically, it's hand-to-hand combat system.  It's kinda...bad.  It's somewhat clunky and inaccurate, but it isn't terrible and can certainly be enjoyable, and if you don't like it you can always employ your skills and/or grab a gun.If you're looking for an incredibly non-linear title, this game is definitely for you.  Despite its age, the game hits many strides in its storytelling and non-linearity, and it hearkens back to the days of Deus Ex on more than one occasion.  The side-quests can also be shockingly impressionable, such as one mission where you go to an abandoned hotel and...well, it'd better that you just play it.  Pick up this game, it's a very good title.  If you're looking for a deal, it almost always goes on sale during the Halloween Sale.

												One of my favorite games of not just the RPG genre but of any genre. Be warned right now though you will want a unoffical patch as Troika Games is no longer around and it does have some bugs. Also when it says mature 17+ it means it. You play the role of a fledgling vampire from the world of whitewolf. Its a dark and gritty world where their are no good guys, just different degrees of evil ones. You will choose from one of seven differnt clans (clans are differnt bloodlines of vampires each with their own quirks and perks) that lead to a very differnt type of game on multiple play threws.Combat is not the smoothest and the graphics are a bit dated. However the voice acting is superb the atmosphere is a increadible 11/10 as well. Depending on how you spend your EXP points on various skill and what type of vampire clan you are the base game can play very differntly from one play threw to another. Also features a 5 ending setup (although some endings arnt as varied as what you would think) leaving the game open to some replayability even at the ending.Overall i would give this game a 10/10 even with its problems and age.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Absloute genuis. This game is absolute genuis. The story is VERY well writen, the graphics hold up incredibly well considering when this game was made (however mods are recomended), the characters feel real, and the combat is very satisfying. That being said make sure you download the unofficial patch because this game is broken without it. You only gain experience by completing quests and there are ALOT of them. The side quests can distract you from the story for awhile but they aren't needed to complete the game but its recomended that you do them in order to level-up your stats. At the begining of the game you really only need melee skill, but once you get farther in you really need some ranged skill or your gonna have a hard time. You can pick from 7 diferent vampire clans each one VERY different from the others, even more so if you pick a background for your character, but thats not required. There are some pretty dark moments, but its a game about modern day vampires so there kinda has to be. I HIGHLY recommend this game to any RPG fan, you will not regret buying this game. This game is very underrated and deserves much more attention and recognition.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												Caveat: the base game is riddled with problems that a fairly complicated modding procedure will address up to a point. It's both an older title and on a game engine that was almost entirely untested at the time, and it shows. But there are few games available that encapsulate the World of Darkness setting quite so well, and it thankfully has acceptable writing and voice acting to back up the narrative.Worth it for the pleasantly surprising ending(s).

Posted: July 14, 2013
												Hands down the best RPG available on Steam. Outstanding, immersive atmosphere, lots of questing to be had and each one serves to provide or explain lore in the world. Combat isn't the best and there are some glitches, but neither should be show stoppers in this amazing adventure.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Finally got around to playing this game and quite enjoyed it. I don't normally play horror games and while the game was fine for the most part, when the more freaky bits of horror intruded I didn't enjoy the game quite so much. My Steam playing time won't be accurrate as I copied the game files out of the Steam directory so I could install the unofficial patch. I don't know how the game played without the patch, but it certainly played fine with it. In fact, I couldn't play the game unpatched as it instantly crashes on startup (hence it sitting unused in my library for so long). The only way I could write this review was by starting the game, watching it crash, then leave the "vampire.exe has stopped working" message open for 5 mins to trick Stream into thinking I'd played :)Lots of quests, interesting characters, and a fairly interesting story with a unexpected ending. Graphics are a mixed bag, but I did find that some of the expression animations to do a pretty accurate job. Levels are fairly linear but they do.Of course, during the questions as the start of the game I answered in the sneaky vein where I could and so ended up as a Nosferatu which possibly isn't the best choice of character for a first playthrough - pretty much everyone runs screaming from you, and you have to sneak pretty much all the time, unless you use the sewers, which I did find tedious and just stuck with flittering around the surface.But if I play through this game again, I think I'll try a melee heavy class that looks human. At least I'll won't have to hide all the time and assumbly will get different dialog trees and be able to speak to characters I couldn't before.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
There's a golden rule about this game that when anybody talks about it somebody reinstalls it. Vampire was released in 2004 and still manages to have better facial animations and emotional conveyance than games released today. Ever feel like every voiced rpg game out on the market is inhabited by a bunch of lobotomy patients? Starting to notice how most games have an abbundance of side-quests with no attention to detail? Less is more comes to mind, as all the side-quests included have variety with way more world building.Have a feeling you already know what somebody wants you to do before they even finish their sentence? Want to get tricked by clever dialogue trees with a margin for actual error non-existant from games today?There's even a section of this game, that's a contender for one of the best horror game levels out there. it's not even a "bloody"  horror game.How about a dating simulator where this one chick with glasses sucks on your arm like it's a strawberry twizzler.

Posted: October 16, 2015
												This game is from 2004. So it doesn't have fancy graphics for today. Combats aren't great. There are still some bugs.  Thanks to Activision rush, this not perfectly complated as it was intended. But still after finishing this game once, can anybody say that they don't want/need to play again? I don't think so.The awesome story, incredible dialogs and perfect adaptation and presentation of the lore from the universe it originally belongs. Every RPG fans should play this game. Really, if you are RPG fun or you love good stroies and rich background but somewhow you still didn't play this game, you should fix your mistake.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2010
												Don't let its appearance deceive you; underneath an early Source Engine exterior lies a truly magnificent game that takes the World of Darkness Role-Playing system and brings it to the  moderately-sized screen. Taking the role of a newly-turned vampire, the player navigates the strange new world of the supernatural as the Vampire Society faces a threat that could change the world as we know it. Choose supernatural powers such as transmogrification and invisibility and master skills such as lockpicking, firearms and hacking and face off with a host of foes that would do anything to see you die your last death. You're about to find out that the World of Darkness isn't much better than our own...

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												This is probably one of the games that has the most bugs, the most glitches, and the most crashes I've played in the past ten years. It is also one of the best games I have ever played. The theme and mood are perfectly put together. Most of the quests are both exciting and interesting, without any filler whatsoever. It is incredibly fun to experience the growth and development of your vampire. The only aspect that will bore you and aggravate you will be the bugs, glitches, crashes, and sometimes sub par AI. Even the voice acting is well done. Easily, one of my current top five favorite games of all time on the PC. Even with all the glitches, bugs, and crashes. Do not miss out on this one!Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is great.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2013
												Bloodlines was damned to be a "flawed gem" straight out of the box. Despite a loyal, yet small fanbase creating unnoficial patches to fix the bugs found in the game, it still has a lot to be fixed. The game works on the early Source engine, so it uses to base code for Half Life 2, but the development cycle took different paths from the very beggining. The most notable feature of this RPG in particular is the fact that Experience isn't gained for kiling enemies, but for completing quests or finding alternate or special routes to them. That makes it a lot more that a run & gun game. This is - a true Role Playing Game.Even though this game came out in 2001 it i still by far my favorite RPG and no matter how many times I play it I always want to go back for more. I definitely reccomend this game.

Posted: September 13, 2012
												Despite its age, glitchy adaptation of source engine (after all, I believe this is the first game to feature it) it still is probably one of the greatest RPGs out there. A little bit depressing, but much more diverse than any Bethesda game in terms of gameplay and missions. The storyline is intense and engaging, but the game is more streamlined than Bethesda's "sandbox" design like Oblivion or Skyrim. However, I think is kind of a good thing, because the characters and the quests really do leave a greater impact on your entertainment experience than, say, nearly identical NPCs in abeforementioned titles.

												Despite a few bugs, this game is excellent. It has a truly amazing atmosphere (one of the best I've ever experienced in a game, seriously... play this game in the dark, and you'll feel like you're there). It also has deep RPG elements, pretty good stealth gameplay, an interesting story with memorable characters, great voice acting, immersive music and more. The game may not have the best combat and shooting mechanics, but it gets the job done, and everything else more than makes up for it.This game is a very unique and immersive experience, and for that reason alone, I'd recommend it.

												This game is so incredibly corny and has so many cliches that you will audibly groan at parts of it. Plus, it is absolutely chock-full of unimaginative stock characters and sexist tropes. But I still really, really like it. It is hard not to like this game. The controls are easy to get used to. The quests aren't that challenging, but are still rewarding and fun. The conversational structure is reminiscent of old-school point-and-clicks where you have the option to be a turd, or be polite and persuasive for extra information. Also, you're a vampire and need to survive by feasting on humans (including police, doomsayers and stuffy businessmen) using your stealth and charm, which should really be all the reason you need.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												If you have not played this 12 year old game it ROCKS if you like a Vampire RPG where your character is turned against his/her will (girls are more fun to play ;)) and she is introduced into the Los Angeles vampire scene. I first played it  on Windows 7 and now on Windows 10, neither of which are mentioned as compatible on the game page. IMO Steam or someone dropped the ball on this. You need to install a patch to get proper functionality. There are threads about this in the Community pages.Find the 9.5  patch here: http://www.patches-scrolls.de/patch/4647/7/73349.Runs fine on Windows 10. You may have to use an earlier version of the patch for Windows 7, but I've not looked at which patch.Some tips: Make sure the patch has the right path to the game (Steam or SteamLibrary to SteamApps>Common>Vampire The Masquerade - Bloodlines)  especially if you have multiple Steam libraries. If it goes to the wrong place, no warnings, ti will happily install it at the path it shows.After it's installed and you launch the game, the first sign the game is running from the patch, you'll see the game intro splash screens. If it's a black screem, just hit enter several times to get to the game menu and be advised you are not running the patched version of the game.  My understanding it's still possible to run the vanilla game after the patch is installed.Select Options>Gamepay and if the patch is not listed, that's verified it's running the vanilla game. The vanilla game may seem to run ok, but when you run through the tutorial, you may run into issues, like not being able to select your fists using the default key (F1).It has been suggested to find the game in in your Steam library list, right click it, select properties, and under the General tab, click "Set Launch Options" and in the blank space type in "-game Unofficial_Patch" without quotes, so the patched version of the game launches. I did this and really don't know if it made a difference, but the  patched version of the game launches. :) Also read the readme with the patch. If you add the "+" plus  content, it says you'll have to start over with a new game. No problem, this is my 4th run through. :):) Good luck, enjoy!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												A word of warning for Windows 7 users, this game isn't immediately compatible, however, this *very* useful thread exists, which should clear up any issues: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035The story is fairly contemporary as far as vampire fiction goes; vampires have to keep their existence among humans a secret otherwise the 'normals' will catch on and exterminate them. This effectively means you are given a number of 'strikes' before it's game over, making gameplay more about sneaking and persuading than going on a Blade-style romp through Los Angeles.There are multiple different types of vampire you can become, although all feel somewhat impotent when it comes to combat, which is an inelegant third-person ordeal.After you get bitten and find yourself in a power struggle between the elite and the renegades, the game is essentially a linear (although enjoyable) path with multiple variations of what may feel like a joke ending.The voices sound a tad echoey, but the soundtrack is more than atmospheric enough to overlook this.Overall, it doesn't suck.

												Fantastic game!Basically, it's the poor man's Skyrim, while being just as good, if a bit smaller. content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Time hasn't been kind to the graphics, but this remains one of the best CRPGs to ever grace a hard drive. Amazing, interesting characters fill a dark and compelling setting brought to life by an incredible soundtrack. The story is brilliant and well-written: both the main story arc and sidequests are far beyond what most studios put out these days.The game does suffer in the third act -- it was rushed out of production and it shows, painfully -- but the last levels are a small price to pay for the first three-quarters of the game. Be sure to look for the unofficial patch, as it remedies a number of bugs and salvages content cut from the final release.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This game is such a mixed bag; I can't bring myself to dislike it, but in order to actually get it in a decent working order I had to download a mod. Then the mod didn't work and I had to download another one. Then the game crashed. Then it crashed again. Then I was at the tutorial and an npc did not spawn. The steam playtime is a complete lie, as said mod creates a different shortcut on your computer.Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, holy crap; that title is so long (enchanced edition) is the one game that I completely and totally forgive for making me jump through so many hoops in order to get started, and I'm including the original Witcher game when I say this.Gameplay is nothing special, but it's functional. You can stealth, speech, shoot and melee your way through any situation. It's pretty varied. I'm not going to say you can use any of these in any situation, but the flexibility reminded me of DeusEx, and that's always a good thing.The writing, however, is what makes this game into something really special. Dialogue options that only like 5% of the playerbase would ever get to see on one playthrough are actually the norm here - yes, the writers were actually that dedicated.Every character is incredibly interesting, there's a lot of funny, bizarre and unique situations in every hub and overall it's just been a while since i've found a game that made me forgive it's general mediocrity because it nailed a few aspects so well. You need patience if you're going to buy this game. It's worth it. I'm really hoping they revisit the Vampire: The Masquerade universe at some point; maybe with the new world of darkness?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												"The blood of Cain controls your fate"What a game, what an absolutely amazing cult classic, a gem. Originally an unfinished mess with lots of bugs, the community patch has improved this to a point where you can enjoy it to its full potential. Not to mention you get cut content as well.Dialogue 10/10The dialogue in this game is very well thought out. Each vampire clan has its own dialogue and intricacies in gameplay that a playthrough is never the same. Malkavians are the crazy ones, talking in riddles whereas the Nosferatu are the monster Vampires that have to hide from society or be shot on sight. There are lots of dialogue options here and the skills you can get for your characters heavily influence the direction of each conversation. Graphics 7/10To me graphics in such a game are not very important. It's a game from 2004 running on the source engine, it's expected to look quite aged but make no mistake here, the art direction is beautiful as well as the environments are designed in such a way that almost every quest can be completed in a different way. There are some lightning and texture bugs but that could be an isolated case on my end.Gameplay 9/10The gameplay immediately pulls you in from the start. Each vampire clan has its own powers and it's up to your choice on how to play and approach each situation, unlike a certain very popular "RPG". Will you try the diplomatic route and talk your enemies to death/surrender, try to make the enemies fight each other, maybe sneak past them because you decided to take a hidden path or will you make them explode in a gory mess of blood and guts as soon as you see them? It's up to you! However, your vampirice powers aren't unlimited, you are expected to feed from humans(or other things...) and drink their blood to sustain yourself, as a proper vampire would!My only complaint here is that towards the end of the game, you don't get much choice in the matter and you HAVE to resort to combat but that's clearly an indication of the financial problems that Troika Games faced back then. I still have to put it out there though.What is more, you can't go around town and destroy people with your awesome vampiric powers without consequences. You have to uphold the Masquerade, a set of rules in the vampire community. Betray the Masquerade and face what's to come.Keep in mind that there's no hand holding in this game. You have to solve the quests yourself, the puzzles yourself, read the quest text and use your brain. Oh that security door is locked huh? What if there's a password around here somewhere or maybe I can bypass it by returning to the apartment and find a clue on my email. The possibilities are endless in this game, I can't stress enough how good the questing is. There is no minimap either, you'll have to remember the layouts of each area. Personally I love this, it's been quite a while since I played an RPG that wasn't a mindless follow the objective arrow simulator and it's been a breath of fresh air. Audio 9/10The music is excellent in this game. It really gives you chills when you hear Cain by Tiamat for the first time, the music immediately immerses you into the depraved, corrupted world of Vampire the Masquerade. Each piece of music and sound is specifically crafted and chosen in such a way as to make you think about what's really going on, if what you're doing is right or wrong. It really fits the vampiric theme and I can't stop listening to the soundtrack of this game. My complaints here are that the gun sounds are not very good. Conclusion: I can't recommend this enough to RPG lovers. If you can put up with older graphics and gameplay quirks(no map or magical arrow that points to the quest, you have to do the reading and thinking yourself here), you will absolutely love this. Remember to download the latest community patch!P.S A certain main quest in the game will remain in your memory forever. It didn't get an award for one of the best levels in gaming for nothing.

												Time hasn't been kind to the graphics, but this remains one of the best CRPGs to ever grace a hard drive. Amazing, interesting characters fill a dark and compelling setting brought to life by an incredible soundtrack. The story is brilliant and well-written: both the main story arc and sidequests are far beyond what most studios put out these days.The game does suffer in the third act -- it was rushed out of production and it shows, painfully -- but the last levels are a small price to pay for the first three-quarters of the game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Product received for free
												A very fun RPG, especially if you're a fan of titles like Knights of the Old Republic or Fable. It's easy to see why so many consider this to be a cult classic, though you should be prepared for the occasional bug.Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines delivers the creepy feel of Vampiric nightlife, without relying on gimmicky jump scares and disgusting faces, instead focusing on offering an atmosphere of darkness and mystery, accompanied by a soundtrack that supports it.This is definitely a game that deserves an HD rerelease.If you are put off by the occasional bug, such as doors not unlocking properly, you may get frustrated by this game.Looking past that, however, this game makes you feel like you actually gain something from most of the quests given to you. Like most games of this type, however, your choices don't seem to impact the quest-to-quest style, however you do get a few choices of ending based on what you do throughout, which is pretty cool.There are definitely characters that feel under-utilised, but for the most part, characters within were fun and interesting, and most left you wanting to help them (and sometimes hinder). The dialogue options for the vast majority of the game were varied and intriguing, though your options are different depending on your clan, and your skills.Another thing to note is that each clan makes your playthrough different in some significant ways, such as "racial tension" each clan has their own reputation and may be viewed with disdain or awe depending on who you deal with, and the choice of clan you make can change your entire experience in the game.Further, this game doesn't fall into the usual pitfall of simple race and class mechanics. Sure, some clans excel at certain things that others don't, but for the most part you are able to customise yourself to be able to fill the roles you want, though there are extreme classes that restrict specific aspects of your character. It actually feels like your choice of clan doesn't dictate entirely who you are, merely your initial strengths and weaknesses.The absolute best part of this game though, is that it doesn't make Vampires boring. Not all vampires are the same, they're given personality. It actually feels like the undead have lives.(It's recommended to get the Unofficial Patch, to support your gaming experience)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												"The blood of Cain controls your fate"What a game, what an absolutely amazing cult classic, a gem. Originally an unfinished mess with lots of bugs, the community patch has improved this to a point where you can enjoy it to its full potential. Not to mention you get cut content as well.Dialogue 10/10The dialogue in this game is very well thought out. Each vampire clan has its own dialogue and intricacies in gameplay that a playthrough is never the same. Malkavians are the crazy ones, talking in riddles whereas the Nosferatu are the monster Vampires that have to hide from society or be shot on sight. There are lots of dialogue options here and the skills you can get for your characters heavily influence the direction of each conversation. Graphics 7/10To me graphics in such a game are not very important. It's a game from 2004 running on the source engine, it's expected to look quite aged but make no mistake here, the art direction is beautiful as well as the environments are designed in such a way that almost every quest can be completed in a different way. There are some lightning and texture bugs but that could be an isolated case on my end.Gameplay 9/10The gameplay immediately pulls you in from the start. Each vampire clan has its own powers and it's up to your choice on how to play and approach each situation, unlike a certain very popular "RPG". Will you try the diplomatic route and talk your enemies to death/surrender, try to make the enemies fight each other, maybe sneak past them because you decided to take a hidden path or will you make them explode in a gory mess of blood and guts as soon as you see them? It's up to you! However, your vampirice powers aren't unlimited, you are expected to feed from humans(or other things...) and drink their blood to sustain yourself, as a proper vampire would!My only complaint here is that towards the end of the game, you don't get much choice in the matter and you HAVE to resort to combat but that's clearly an indication of the financial problems that Troika Games faced back then. I still have to put it out there though.What is more, you can't go around town and destroy people with your awesome vampiric powers without consequences. You have to uphold the Masquerade, a set of rules in the vampire community. Betray the Masquerade and face what's to come.Keep in mind that there's no hand holding in this game. You have to solve the quests yourself, the puzzles yourself, read the quest text and use your brain. Oh that security door is locked huh? What if there's a password around here somewhere or maybe I can bypass it by returning to the apartment and find a clue on my email. The possibilities are endless in this game, I can't stress enough how good the questing is. There is no minimap either, you'll have to remember the layouts of each area. Personally I love this, it's been quite a while since I played an RPG that wasn't a mindless follow the objective arrow simulator and it's been a breath of fresh air. Audio 9/10The music is excellent in this game. It really gives you chills when you hear Cain by Tiamat for the first time, the music immediately immerses you into the depraved, corrupted world of Vampire the Masquerade. Each piece of music and sound is specifically crafted and chosen in such a way as to make you think about what's really going on, if what you're doing is right or wrong. It really fits the vampiric theme and I can't stop listening to the soundtrack of this game. My complaints here are that the gun sounds are not very good. Conclusion: I can't recommend this enough to RPG lovers. If you can put up with older graphics and gameplay quirks(no map or magical arrow that points to the quest, you have to do the reading and thinking yourself here), you will absolutely love this. Remember to download the latest community patch!P.S A certain main quest in the game will remain in your memory forever. It didn't get an award for one of the best levels in gaming for nothing.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												A word of warning for Windows 7 users, this game isn't immediately compatible, however, this *very* useful thread exists, which should clear up any issues: http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2025035The story is fairly contemporary as far as vampire fiction goes; vampires have to keep their existence among humans a secret otherwise the 'normals' will catch on and exterminate them. This effectively means you are given a number of 'strikes' before it's game over, making gameplay more about sneaking and persuading than going on a Blade-style romp through Los Angeles.There are multiple different types of vampire you can become, although all feel somewhat impotent when it comes to combat, which is an inelegant third-person ordeal.After you get bitten and find yourself in a power struggle between the elite and the renegades, the game is essentially a linear (although enjoyable) path with multiple variations of what may feel like a joke ending.The voices sound a tad echoey, but the soundtrack is more than atmospheric enough to overlook this.Overall, it doesn't suck.

content:

												While not a perfect RPG, it does do its job well by providing interesting story and characters to the player. It is the cRPG that really bolstered my interest in the Tabletop RPG and even my interest in the original Vampire the Masquerade pen and paper roleplay.The game has terrific characters, dialogue, and atmosphere. It really does feel like I am a Vampire, being made a pawn in a big game of Chess. And I happen to be one of many gray pieces. While the combat is very lacking, and the overall story could have used some polish, this game is still nonetheless a must play for any die hard RPG fan.One of my favorite games to play from time to time and a classic.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												I played this game almost ten years ago... ten years is a long time to still think about a game, and I do. Why? The story does a good job of making you feel like it's YOU in the game, that your fate has been forced on you, that you're the one gett screwed over when your character is. The storyline is very strong and your choices MATTER. They matter the way they do in the Original Dragon Age, depending on your choices NPCs will treat you differently, you get different outcomes/endings, you can actually have repercurssions to your character if you're an a-hole all game long.  These guys were way ahead of their time, even still in the games released 10 years later it's hard to find a game engine with facial expressions that don't look like "the sims", Vampire Bloodines was one of those games where the devs put a LOT of work into the facial expressions. The only negative about this game are the graphics, but then again, 10 years was a long time ago.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Steam version works well. Game is still very glitchy. You will likely need to do a few things to get the game to run on a newer machine, which includes disabling Auto-Updates and installing the unofficial patch.Win7 users will need to periodically modify their save file to allow for indexing (turn it off, then turn it back on, wheeee) or the game will not be able to find your latest saves. If you hit "Load" and you hear the load sound effect glitch over and over, you have run into this problem and will see outdated saves magically appear in the queue. Good luck!That said, the game is still very fun when it wasn't busy crashing. Or the random number generator wasn't deciding that combat just wasn't going to work for me that day.  I gladly wasted a lot of hours on it.If I had a complaint, really, it would be that the writing downright horrible. Normally I would let that sort of thing go without saying, but there is literally a section in which the radio host makes fun of freelance writers saying that they should leave it to the professionals with degrees. Which would be all good and well if these professionals hadn't written a low-grade "Matrix" plot I would have possibly found cool at the ripe age of 15 and no later. I mean, they literally pull the "it doesn't work like in the movies" line half a dozen times to excuse changes to vampires made for convenience sake and naught else. Crosses don't work, but faith does? Magic exists, but everything is scientific? Five minutes into the game I have a hairy hobo fellating me while giving me the basics and pretending he's the cool one of the group. The motivations of each "faction" leader boil down to "be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" with almost no pretext as to why. There is literally one character who is supposed to be a Japanese tearaway speaking in broken English. But her accent is firmly American, most of the dialogue is written with English grammar in mind, and there are literally no words that can be confused for others given the context. Not to mention that all the endings are anticlimactic AND melodramatic, somehow at the same time. I just...if you're gonna kick sand in someone's face, just make sure to back it up with something that isn't just a turd sandwich, okay?Anyway, great game overall. Game play is great, balance is iffy, writing is awful, and it is so unstable you will need to mod it, patch it, tweak it, and pray over it to get it to run.Or as I like to call it, PC gaming. And I wouldn't have it any other way.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Hello LA, you're up way past your bed time, aren't you? Hope you've slipped into something comfortable, I know I have. If you're new to town or just new to this whole radio thing, you're listening to The Deb of Night, the only girl who will spend the night with you and leave first thing in the morning, guaranteed. Well, looks like the boards are lighting up! Aren't I the popular one? Lets see, eeny, meeny, miny, moe, who will be the lucky... caller, you've got the first shot at Deb tonight! So who do I have the pleasure of speaking to? Hi Deb, this is... uh, Vigo. Vigo. So... Vigo, why are you up so late? Uhm, I'm working the night shift here at the... uh, yacht club. Aha. How many boats do you own, Vigo? >Two, actually three. Uhm, one is... in the shop. I used to do a little yachting myself, what kind of yacht do you have? Uhm... you probably wouldn't know the brand, I... uh, bought them in Italy. Ah, l'Italia bella. Parlate Italiano? Uhm... yes. Arrivederci, Vigo. Caller two, you're on The Deb of Night. Be gentle. Hi Deb. Hello caller. Hi Deb. Is tonight a re-run? Deb?Money troubles? Need cash quick? Why not try mugging someone? These are exactly the kind of questions that criminals are asking themselves right now. Did you know that the government requires you to wait ten days for a gun? Why, in that time a criminal could kill your family fifty times over. So how does a law-abiding citizen like yourself get a theft-deterrent system in their hands in the next hour? Come to Loophole Lenny's! We've got antique military weaponry from blunderbusses to World War One grenades. Modern muggers may be stronger and faster than they used to be, but that doesn't mean they can take a slug fired by a Civil War era pistol any better. And if you're the kind of person that can't sleep at night knowing serial rapists might be in your front yard, we've got German sniper rifles approved by the Kaiser himself that'll make picking them off one by one from the safety of your roof no problem. Buy a weapon this month and we'll throw in an ammo belt with the Constitution printed on it free of charge. Loophole Lenny's: defending your tomorrow with the weapons of yesterday, today.

content:
Posted: January 7
												Bloodlines was a game ahead of its time with a fairly complex & in-depth storyline full of both drama & dark humor oriented to a more mature-audience. It contained a plethora of (sometimes hidden) content & alternatives dependant upon your chosen character's build/evolution (skills & abilities) as well as roleplaying actions & dialogue choices, revealing possibilities for more diverse interactions with non-player characters, finding items (Magical Swords to Flaemthrowers), unlocking additional story/quest options & finaly determining which alternate ending you experience. Even selecting a different clan offered unique additional alternatives & possibilities for added replay value (admittedly some clans offered much more additional content and a far more unique experience: Clan Malkavian). Unfortunately, when Bloodlines was released, it masqueraded as a rushed & bug-ridden mess, often frustrating at best & unplayable (literally) at worst. It took years of hard work by devoted fans who looked beneath the original facade to discover an actual treasure and reveal it to the rest of the world, carefully removing the bugs & even unlocking lost content the original programers created but left unfinished, yet hidden within. Years later it emerged in an updated version, cleansed, even improved, with lost/unfinished content restored & to this date, numerous player-made mods still being created by an active community fanbase.  The original advertising along with some of the more overt tragically (pseudo) hip stereotypes & soap-opera cliche's, often straight from the origianl pen & papper/live-action roleplaying books, didn't do anything to help entice the more mature audience the game was originally aiming for; however, the machiavellian plotlines, diverse characters from both ancient times to the modern nights, & the dark but fascinating merging of real-world history with the supernatural entities, timeless conspiracies & endless Jihad of the World of Darkness made this into the lasting classic it has become.

												Easily one of my three favourite games of all time. Forget all you think you know about vampires, this is the White Wolf universe, a beast on it's own class. This is one extremely well written, engrossing, seductive and replayable game; it does and tells just the right things to keep you coming back. I won't lie though, it's buggy as hell due to a rushed release, but there are fan-made patches for that problem.  Having said this, the fact  people are playing this game extensively decades after it's release even despite the bugs should at least make you curious (The patches are being updated even now). number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												VTMB is a hidden gem in the RPG genre. Not a lot of people know about it, partially because it has some flaws which are off putting to some. It runs on an early version of the Source engine, which is just so sucky and glitchy. Another flaw is combat. It can be a bit boring and way to difficult, especially melee because it is clunky and awkward. There is supposed to be a system of pushing directional keys to vary your swings, but it doesn't work well. I high recommend playing a gun-wielding character. However, in the long run, combat is mostly avoidable (more on that later), so it doesn't matter too much.Other than that, this game is perfect. You get to play as a vampire for one thing, which is awsome. I know of no RPG like this except Oblivion, but those aren't real vampires in that game. The world's lore about secret vampire societies and laws is really well thought out and interesting. The sheer amount of it shows you how much work the developers put into the game. Another great feature is the story. I just felt that it was really cool and interesting. It's very subtle and mature without being too long-winded. The dialouge is really awesome as well. In fact, both the voice acting AND the writting of the characters made me feel like I was watching a movie or reading a novel. The gameplay and rules system is also extremely well done. You're assigned experience for completeing goals. Thats it. No XP from killing things. A lot of RPG's award too much XP for killing, and as a result you're actually punished for finding alternate soloutions because you'll be under leveled. In VTMB, there are always multiple ways to finish a quest. You could be a cowboy and fight your way through it, or you could look around for a way to sneak in. Or maybe you can hack a computer? Don't forget charming, persuading, or intimidating people to get your way. You're allowed to play any way you want and have tons of freedom. More RPG's need to be this way. All things considered, VTMB is an awesome game that compensates for it's flaws with a legendary story and backdrop. It's a must have for RPG fans who like vampires.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												The GoodIt's like Deus Ex but instead of an augmented govt agent who can't aim for♥♥♥♥♥♥you're a vampire, who also can't aim for♥♥♥♥♥♥ There's a whole slew of politics, lore, and tons of dialouge options and methods for going about your objectives. Sneaking or coercing people with seduction, intimidation, hacking, melee and firearm combat, sprawling open area levels, this game has a lot of paralells with that old doos sex. The BadHoly ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥these ♥♥♥♥ing bugs. Imagine clicking a door to open it and walking through. The door opens slowly so you burst through it when it's finally fully open. only problem is if you touch the ♥♥♥♥ing door before it's open all the way it stops ♥♥♥♥ing dead and goes in reverse against you. Stuck in enemy territory? You better crouch all the time because if you stand up everyone will see you THROUGH THE ♥♥♥♥ING WALLS and fire at you with pinpoint accuracy THROUGH THE ♥♥♥♥ING WALLS. I didn't relaize I was playing MLG counter strike, give me a ♥♥♥♥ing break. Sneaking in general isn't very well implimented. As long as I'm crouching an enemy can look directly at me but since I'm maybe twenty feet away they don't see my pale vampire skin, but you better not ♥♥♥♥ing stand for even a second. I can really appreciate all the effort Deus Ex HR did in giving me tons of options to circumvent combat.The biggest problem of all is this though: As soon as an object touches the periphery of the screen the texture for it dissapears. This includes ceiling, wall, and floor titles. Every twenty seconds my immersion is shattered as suddenly the ceiling dissapears revealing the night sky (from indoors) or a huge ground tile goes completely black but the grass tendrils remain in tact on top. You see this lamp? Watch it dissapear completely as soon as just a pixel of it hits the side of my monitor. This is Sonic Boom levels of grafix. Go ahead and tell me I just need to git gud. Then compare my 4000+ achievements to your piddly dip total--and tell your mom to stop calling me.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												I love this game, loved the storyline, loved the mechanics. It's an old game but I don't mind how outdated the graphics and stuff is. The characters are great, the quests are fun, and it's enjoyable. Wasn't a huge fan of the endings, because all of them feel rushed and sorta anti-climatic-- I was really hoping for a boss fight with whatever was in the coffin, or at least hoping to become the next Prince. But it was  fun anyways.The one uncomfortable thing is all the weird racism in this. It's from a decade ago, and what was acceptable in the media was different I guess, but I still can't imagine how the creators thought this stuff was okay. The storyline does centrally feature a lot of anti-asian xenophobia and a couple black stereotypes. I think it's supposed to be funny, but it's just really awkward and gross. It's too bad that such a fun game is packed with so many harmful stereotypes. Just something to be aware of.

												Pixelated garbage from the past. The story is OK, but no one ain't playing this just because of it, as if it were be a text-based game as the graphics are obviously cringy. The fact is that it was done in that early 3D era when the transition from 2D to 3D games looked a bit funny, out of proportions and messed up in physics. number of helpful: 7 of 20 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												Bloodlines is another one of those games I have where it is really difficult to decide whether to say yes or no to a recommendation. Sure it's quite dated by now but even when it was released it wasn't a marvel of first person role-playing games by any means (in fact it barely worked back then). Since its release many, MANY patches have been released by the fan community which almost make it a good game but it falls short because, at its core, it is flawed. You can't fix a games core mechanics.Combat is awful. It wouldn't be as big of a deal if you could talk your way or sneak your way through all of the game but you can't. There are some missions which force you to fight and if you didn't put enough stats into combat for your Ventrue super-persuadertron sex machine, you will have to start the game over. The ranged weapons don't have any punch to them and melee combat basically involves exchanging blows and hoping your enemy runs out of health before you do. Make sure you put enough points into soak and dodge or you won't make it very far.Like a lot of the action rpg's of the era, the world is lifeless and hollow which is surprising considering this is the company that made Arcanum. That is more of a technological limitation I suppose but if you look at, say, Deus Ex... they managed to make the world in that game feel alive and active with even less hardware power. Part of it could be that they built the game in the old Half-Life 2 Source Engine which really wasn't made for role playing games... but then you look at Dark Messiah which by no means is a real RPG but they nailed melee combat so much better than Vampire does.Visually it's not bad for when it was made and there are new texture packs that update it a bit. The hub cities kind of look like 20 different people designed a different part of it and then they sewed it together at the end. Interior areas aren't bad. Sparsely furnished and not very immersive (you're telling me 4 people go to the only club on town on the weekend?) but, again, that's just a sign of the times.The different dialog choices are where this game shines and you can tell they put a lot of time into mapping out different paths you could take with every major NPC. The script and voice acting are garbagebag, unfortunately, but video games didn't start hiring Keifer Sutherland and Patrick Stewart until later. Listening to a low-talent white actor try to portray a black hoodlum is epic cringe so I guess there's some merit there.The inventory system is atrocious but like I said, Source wasn't really built for RPG's. Switching weapons mid-combat is dangerous and time consuming. The weapon choices are pretty uninspiring and don't really have much of a variety in what they do. You have guns which all do pretty much the same thing and melee weapons with which if you have the strength for the better one, it's always the one you're going to use.The variety in dialogue based on which clan you are, your humanity rating, and your skills as well as the variety in quests are really what make this game shine for me. It is fun to play at times... experimenting with what different dialogue choices or actions will do... but it just doesn't have much of a payoff gameplay-wise.When it's difficult for me to say yes or no to a game it comes down to am I going to have the patience to finish the game. I really doubt it with this one. I've owned it for almost a decade and I've never gotten past the second hub because it's so boring and broken. I know there are a ton of fanboys out there who will disagree and probably give this review tons of "unhelpful" ratings (if anyone even sees it, this game is old AF) but, you know... fanboys are always wrong.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Quite possibly the most under-rated RPG ever in the history of PC gaming. Sure, this game IS unfinished and broken in several places, BUT there are now unofficial patches that fix 99 per cent of the bugs. The story is truly awesome, the amount of work that went into this game is staggering, this is a great example of a game YEARS ahead of its time, and still holds up today. One of the few games that can actually "give me the willies", the atmosphere is astonishing for a game this old, the voice cast are in incredible form here too, every character is believeable. This is a game that will linger long in the memory, and you WILL want to play it again, just to be back in that world, where the "creatures of the night" rule. Without the patches 7/10, with the patches 9/10.

												Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines is a wonderful game to play- and a terrible pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get running on Steam. Normally I would talk about the strengths of the game itself (which are considerable), only in this case to actually get to the game you'll have to go through a considerable amount of aggravation to make it function properly. It does not play nice with newer operating systems, and patching and tweaking the thing to work is aggravating. You'll find plenty to like if you have the patience to make it work; I do not. Activision dumped this thing on Steam, not knowing or caring that it wasn't going to be compatible with most of its purchasers' hardware. Don't reward them for treating their customers with contempt.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I would love to reccommend this game to everyone. You have no idea how much joy it would bring me to tell every PC gamer I know that there was another great Action RPG they never played. I want to like this game. I realllllllllly do. But I just can't ignore the fact that this game has problems, and I mean ALOT of problems. I'm not even going to touch on the fact that the game is basically unfinished and even modded out the bum, still glitchy as all hell. This game is HORRIBLY unbalanced in terms of RPG stats. Good luck finding any ammo if you built a gunfighter, cause a word of advice, in the first 3rd or so of the game, there isn't any. Good luck earning money to buy armor so you don't die from so much as a gnat brushing past your shoulder, because there isn't any. Money, I mean not gnats. Combat feels extremely clunky and unsatisfying. You can be an all powerful Vampire decked out with powers and holding a shotgun and easily takes down by a thug with a knife. While there are multiple solutions to problems, there arent enough given the large amount of skills present in the game. And don't be surprised when your silver-tounged computer whiz gets locked in a room with a giant blob monster you have to defeat. A blob monster only weak to edged weapons. As far as Action RPGs go, I would much more highly recommend Deus Ex, Fallout 3, or System Shock 2. Those games feel all around more complete and you aren't gritting your teeth the whole way through. However, I can definately see why it's considered a cult classic and beloved by a section of PC gamers. The RPG elements, while unbalanced, are incredibly deep and allow you to build a multitude of characters (even if most of them end up completely useless). The way the game immerses you into the rich setting and intresting story is really something to behold. Character Interactions in paticular are well done and allow you to complete conversations with completely diffrent outcomes, adding to replayability. It's just a shame the game was rushed out or it could've been one of the greatest of all time. But execution counts for everything, and unfourtanetly, this Vampire stepped out into daylight.
