content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												I wish I could recommend this game. I really,  really  wish I could. I love the World of Darkness setting from playing the pen-and-paper games as a kid, and some parts of this game are really great. It's just the bad parts really spoil those good parts, and tainted my enjoyment of what preceeded them too much.You'll likely already know that this game was shipped in a terrible state. It's one of the first things you hear when it's recommended to you; "You should totally play it! ...But install this huge fan-made patch first, because otherwise it's borderline unplayable." That I could live with - it's not as heavy duty as the Morrowind overhaul, for example - but I'd argue that it still doesn't turn VTM from an unfinished game into a "finished" one, it just turns it into a "completeable" one. Yes you can get to the end of the game (even if it takes a console command or two), but at about the 3/4 mark the game just collapses in a way that the fan patch cannot fix.Up until that point the game is structured very much like  Deus Ex  or  Dishonored  - a lot of ways to complete the quests, and using means other than brute force is actively encouraged. But past a certain point (  for those of you who've played the game, yes I'm talking about the Hallowbrook Hotel, but the Blood Plague and Tzimisce monsters aren't exactly a barrel of laughs either  ) it becomes nothing but straightforward combat and boss fights. I was playing as a Nosferatu, the stealth-oriented clan, and investing a ton of XP into getting my invisibility powers to maximum only for the enemies to suddenly all have the ability to see through it, and all the levels become corridors so you can't sneak past them either was infuriating. I usually frown upon people who insist upon playing games with "optimal builds" but having the game allow you to paint yourself into a corner like this just makes you feel like a chump for having played creatively until that point. Thank goodness I wasn't playing as a social character, otherwise I'd have really been screwed!In the end there really is a lot to like about VTM, and some moments you won't see in a lot of other games, but with the game itself having done its level best to invalidate that enjoyment, I find that what I was really enjoying was the game it could have been, the game it ended up being.

Posted: December 4, 2016
												To be clear, I played this game with the update 96 patch. I like this setting and I like what they were attempting to do; essentially, Deus Ex meets World of Darkness. However, despite releasing after DE, it really only seems to do atmosphere, story, and characters right. The combat feels awful regardless of going melee or ranged. Stealth feels clunky and ineffective, as far as I've used it with Nosferatu. The story, having played to chapter 3 at a different time, feels incredibly railroaded. I took a different route this most recent playthrough, threatened Therese, "NO ONE THREATENS ME AND GETS AWAY WITH IT!"; I was then handed my next stock mission like nothing happened, as with every other playthrough. COME ON - GIVE ME A BOSS FIGHT OR SOMETHING. Dragon Age: Origins did this type of 'A-hole' playthrough better when you talked♥♥♥♥♥♥to people.I can't imagine what people see in this game other than the setting. All it makes me want to do is play Deus Ex again, which came first and somehow did all of the gameplay mechanics better.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												From what I'd heard about this game I was expecting a diamond in the rough, a cult classic from yesteryear.....Hmnn, not quite....People talk about this game like it's Deus Ex with vampires - a world where you can pick and match gameplay styles, be stealthy or be brutal, or influence things through conversation. And maybe it is those things, but if you look at my playtime it will be obvious I don't care to find out!First of all: it looks incredibly ropey. Graphics aren't everything, but beyond the ugly looks it's also hard to take the stealth seriously when your character's stealthy walk animation seems like they're desperately holding in a poo....Second problem: the combat is pretty woeful, and consists of you either (a) directly fighting the enemy, which basically involves flailing about until the enemy drops dead, or (b) doing sneak attacks where the enemy gives you all the time in the world as they gaze at their shoes, or at an interesting speck of dirt on the floor, or are mentally distracted as they  wonder if they left home without turning the oven off. For whatever reason they spend a huge amount of time not paying any attention to their surroundings - most stealth games choreograph their AI behaviour in this manner upto a point, but it's pretty simply implemented here.Though this may improve over time it still leaves a bad impression. Having said that...at least that helps with stealth, except it doesn't because the stealth is crap.I only managed to get through that part of the  tutorial (!!) thanks to the AI doing something stupid. It took about twenty attempts just to sneak past some vampire who absolutely refused to look at anywhere but the spot I had to go past (which was the only possible route!)....until for some inexpicable reason he didn't notice me, despite doing exactly the same thing on the previous nineteen attempts....If stealth is a gameplay choice, then I choose not to, thanks! Because it totally sucks here! And that was just the tutorial...Third problem: To hear about this game it sounds brilliantly told, with amazing dialogue and an intriguing take on vampires. I certainly didn't experience anything like that - it was passable stuff, but nothing particularly special or gripping. To be fair though, the voice acting is pretty decent.Overall I got the impression that to love it in this day and age you have to have nostalgia from playing it before - as someone who only just played it I found it to be somewhat overrated. Yes it's old and is therefore understandably not as slick as modern games, but that's not a problem so much as the fact it just doesn't seem very good. I played System Shock 2 fairly recently and that's old, and not much of a looker, yet it still deserves it's status as a classic. I know Bloodlines was an ambitious title released by a developer that maybe lacked the talent and / or budget to do it justice, but knowing that doesn't change the fact I don't want to play it anymore after an hour and a half.....

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												I gave this game a second chance after leaving a bad review about a year ago. I thought maybe I did something wrong during my first play through but this is still not a fun game.The first problems started before I even launched the game, you have to download the unofficial patch just to get the game to launch on modern systems. The game runs smoothly as you'd expect from the Source Engine. It has a fitting atmosphere to it with some unique characters and dialogue options that allows you to do what you want for the most part. This seems to be the selling point of the game; it fits the RPG genre well.The combat is not enjoyable. Spellcaster and ranged builds seem very underpowered while melee is the opposite. Blood runs out very fast leaving spellcasters vulnerable and the only viable guns I've seen are shotguns. The melee seems to be the most effective, allowing you to take out almost all enemies with a few swings. If you want to buy this game for any sort of combat or action, look elsewhere.Sneaking is broken. You can sneak right in front of enemies in bright rooms and they won't be able to find you. This was with a non stealth character. It really breaks any sort of immersion since a decent amount of missions involve stealth.The worst part of this game is doors. Doors will get you killed, stuck, or leave you sitting at a black screen just by touching them as they open or close. Many times through my last playthrough I've had to noclip out of doors or reload.I would not be so critical of this game if it was priced fairly. The game is almost 12 years old and costs $20 while being buggy and just not that great overall. The game is overrated.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												I'll go out on a limb here and base my vote on what is actually being offered, which is a decade-old technical nightmare at a full 20 bucks. Oh, and on any version of Windows still supported by Microsoft, it won't even work until you star fiddling with compatability settings and UAC.(Also, the storytelling may rank among the most overrated in gaming history, because while it certainly is good, it is not the flawless masterpiece of writing brilliance too many make it out to be.)If you absolutely want to give it a try:1. Wait for a sale (75% off or so seems fair).2. Be prepared to use - and put up with - community patches. (Yes, there's two competing ones. No, I'm not going to recommend one. Damn straight I'm going to say if you didn't expect the kind of bickering that goes on between the two sects, surely you've never dealt with anything resembling a WoD/Vampire community before.) 3. Be prepared to be disappointed. It's just good, but not what it is cracked up to be.As the more bone-headed cheerleaders for this technical atrocity like to point out so little Steam play time on record means I don't know what I'm talking about:This game works a lot better with a community patch [on ANY operating system, even the officially supported ones!] and without Steam overlays. Which, as it were, is even more proof it being 20 bucks on Steam is questionable at best.EDIT: I would actually recommend trying the game at a fair price. But $20 ain't it.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												While there are many, many people who say this is an utterly brilliant game, I sadly cannot verify that. Why ? Because whoever coded this made such a complete and utter hash of it, it takes hours and hours to get it to work.There is an Unofficial Patch available, which is still being made 10 years after the original was released. This is done completely by fans of the game and is supposed to fix many many bugs. However, because of the sheer crapness of the original coding by the original developers, there are still some bugs that you have to manually fix. They include bombing out when you select New Game and crashing on game load if you have more then 4GB of RAM (these days who doesn't!). It also seems to hate Windows 8, though I've come across some people who can run it fine, and others where it just refuses to start. Unless you have hours to kill trying to get the game to run, don't bother. For me, this will have to be a game I come back to at a time when I actually have time to to get it to run. Very disappointing.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Great game overall but it was rushed out the door because of money issues but the game is still a masterpiece even as is. There are unofficial mods that will make the game play better and also change it as well. Play it through once with the official patches and then MOD it. Be sure to investigate the world and do the side quests to open up more side quests. Have fun. It is made with the Source 2 engine I believe.Forget about all the negatives people have said about this game. It is well worth 5, 10 or 20 dollars even with it's age. The only reason this game was released before it was polished up is BIG F'ing GAME COMPANIES who want dev teams to rush out their content. When this game was bought out that company could have spend a few thousand dollars finishing it up and made multi-millions off it but short sighted money hungry attitudes killed that idea. The game as is is a Vampire Masterpiece and I am not a fanatic of vampire stuff.Even if you don't like RPGs this game is still appealing. Yes the graphics are not as they should be, nor is the controls on PC but the overall atmosphere, storyline, quests, items you can use, characters, dialog, areas to travel, humor, horror, music, etc. are very original and immersive and enjoyable. About patches: There is no real company to work on this game anymore so there are no fixes from those who created the game. But there are many mods out there that do fix a lot of broken things in the game and even some mods that overhaul the game extensively. There are model and skin patches as well. Nude and otherwise. The mods are NOT hard to install. If you can read it is very simple. The only thing that I had an issue with is the game not running on install from Steam and in 64bit mode. There is a patch to fix this. Sorry I do not have the links at the moment. Google them or look on the community page.  I have the boxed version and the Steam version and have played it lots of times in many ways. All have been pleasurable experiences. I recommend playing through without modding it first if you can or at least not using the overhaul mods that change too much of the game. Then play again with the conversion MODS.The game gets a 10/10 for me even with the quirks and work I have to do to get it to work efficiently.

												I wanted to like this--it has some RPG elements I usually enjoy plus vampires--but it just wasn't happening. The ratings and fan ravings drew me in. I may have liked it a decade ago too. But if you're new to the game, there may be some insurmountable obstacles.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I'm about mid-ways through this game, maybe past that point. My enthusiasm in the beginning has waned. The combat is bland and forces you to play ranged also, not just melee. For me, firearms are not what vampires are about but the boss battles force the player to put points into guns. Otherwise I don't see if some encounters could be completed on melee, or not atleast without considerable difficulty. There are still some glitches which don't prevent completing the game but harm stealth for an example. The writing is good and I enjoy the politics and some of the kooky characters (Jeanette), but there hasn't been that much roleplaying yet for me. For an example, I can't choose sides even though the opportunity is coming. It just isn't doable at this point of the plot, and I presume I'm already past half-way point. So that is also disappointing, I'm having to have to do missions to someone I prefer not doing them to, with no possibility to change things.If you can get this game cheap it's worth a shot, like I did. But for the asking price of almost 20 EUR, it's way too much. Not recommended at the asking price.

number of helpful: 7 of 28 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												V:TM:B puts you in the shoes of a freshly sired vampire roaming a murky, big city environment. The game is based on the pen and paper system World of Darkness by White Wolf, and remains largely true to the system's setting and style. As exciting as a gritty, mature world where the vampires never sparkle sounds, there are a few glaring problems with this game. The foremost being that it doesn't actually work. There are literally moments in the game that can break so fantastically that it will render the rest of the game unplayable. And they aren't optional events or sidequests that were glossed over, I'm talking certain main questline events can end your game if they decide not to work. Reloading isn't a sure fix in several cases. Don't let those 30 some hours fool you, the most gamebreaking glitches are fixed by several wonderful fan mods- some of them even restore cut content- but your money isn't going to the modders, it's going to the creators of a shoddy game. V:TN:B is a blast with the patience to find the right mods, which honestly isn't too difficult, a google search will yield the best ones, but I can't shake the misgivings of paying for a game that the fans were charged with completing.Pros:Great environmentInteresting StoryDifferent classes add some replay valueCons:Modding is an absolute necessityEven with mods, some bugs exist1/5 standalone4/5 modded

												So this game is in bad need of a patch.  The default steam version does not support 64-bit OS's -- specifically, if you are running Windows 8 it won't work.  If you are running Windows 7 64-bit, it won't work.You can get one of two 3rd party patches to fix the problem, but they are a bit sketchy.  Any patch whose site to download from comes with a warning of NSFW or requires the game to be run as administrator from then on is pretty suspect.  Furthermore, installing either patch will apparently cause steam to complain that the game has been patched any time you launch it.I never got to play the game because I don't think either patch is safe or reasonable to install.  I'd like to see Steam actually put a patched version of the game up if they are going to list it as supported for Windows 8.

number of helpful: 21 of 60 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												This is purely a gamer's review, someone who's enjoyed horror, survival horror, action, and rpg games.  I am not a fan of the series, or of pencil and paper rpgs.  I have played unmodded, with only the unofficial patch.  EDIT: you fanboys can downvote me all you want, this is still an objective and accurate review.  Interesting story, that.  As it turns out, even though this game was released 10 years ago, with the developers apparently and immediately dropping support for it, people are STILL churning out both patches and mods for this game.  That should pique your curiosity at least.  Let's get something obvious out of the way.  Even with the patches, the graphics are pretty rustic.  Bugs are STILL legion.  You'll be able to ignore that with the atmosphere, but there's no denying this was a small budget enterprise in 2004.  With the unofficial patches boosting things up to higher resolutions, you may have terrible omnipresent screen distortion along the top edge, amongst various other snags.You pick your vampiric clan and one of several back-histories, which determines your beginning stats and primary 3 vampiric abilities.  You can have the game distribute the points for you via questionnaire, or do it all yourself (which I did).  The game takes place in several small (and I do mean small) areas packed with buildings and npcs.  At first you'll wander around lost (the only maps are on bus stops and in sewers), but exploring is part of the fun in a game like this.  Several missions will have you venturing outside the city via cab to special areas that you cannot access afterwards.  Being a vampire, of course you have to feed on blood, and you can't let humans see you do this.  You have a system of 5 strikes which can be violated any number of ways, such as feeding with witnesses, allowing evidence of vampires to become known (sometimes objects, or dialogue choices), to random butchering of the cattle.  In the same way, being discreet can sometimes earn you these marks back.  The concept is neat, but fundamentally flawed, and in any case completely avoidable by simply not being a terrible player.  The story isn't overly predictable, and the game has a strong cast.  There's an undeniable atmosphere here, and I believe it's that undercurrent and plausible mythology that keeps the fanbase going.  There are certain people who have latched onto this game and will not let go, for various reasons.  The dialogues are lengthy and varied, and occasionally influenced by your specific clan type and certain vampiric traits (seduction, intimidation, etc).  However, there's no getting around the fact that you are basically an errand boy the entire game.  It's a little more plausible being the new vamp on the block and everyone you meet being centuries older than you, but the game never steps outside of this formula, not even once from what I've seen.  The combat is clunky, at best.  You could call it challenging, or cheap, depending on your viewpoint.  For my run, although I made sure I was fully stocked on firearms, I stuck with melee weapons, which may have altered the difficulty.  There's also a stealth system, with stealth kills if you're directly behind enemies, but don't expect too much.  AI is functional at best, even with the occasional wallhacking.  During one boss battle my enemies implanted themselves into walls and I had to start over.  The combat camera (3rd person view) is surprisingly fair, if a little squirrely.    Doing sidequests helps combat (and everything else) in the form of acquiring skill points, but the truth is you will never feel like a badass.  I played through spamming two primary abilities, superhuman speed and some form of intimidation to lower enemy's combat stats.  I know the Gangrel clan can transform (but I've heard it's underwhelming), another one can make enemies commit suicide, still another can turn invisible entirely.  The vampiric clan differences are pretty broad, and are wasted on the combat here.  Using your abilities consumes blood, and if you don't feed often enough or have enough blood to start with you run the risk of frenzying.  You'll get massive stat boosts, but be unable to control your character for the time being.  Obviously if it happens in public, this is bad.  Some clans are more prone to this than others, but it never happened to me.  Even with everything I just said, I'd still recommend the game - if it weren't for the endings.  Several glaring plot holes are present regardless of which of the five endings you get - which really aren't five endings, more like three and two variations.  All of them are at least vaguely unsatisfactory.  The game does a terrific job of building up, and you're always interested to see which fictional creature turns out to be real next, but the endings just flop out.  As engaging (if slightly predictable) as the game's atmosphere and events are, there's no feeling of reward for actually reaching the various mediocre endings.  If they were all different from each other, or at least interesting, I could recommend this game in spite of its flaws.  But they aren't, so I can't.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I can't believe I missed this title before a Steam sale brought it to my attention. Heck, I didn't even know much about it. Why? This game is great! It might be about 10 years old, but it has most everything an RPG gamer could want: Unique setting, a great branching story filled side quest and political intrigue, brilliant voice acting, and customizable character sheets and moves. It has some bugs, but nothing big so far, so...why was this game such a cult classic? With vampires so main stream you'd think it'd not only be common knowledge, but something so big that it would be on it's forth or fifth sequel with console ports right up there with Fallout, Elder Scrolls, Deus Ex and Mass Effect. Why hasn't this IP been promoted and progressed more? Are all the vampire books, movies, and comics out right now not enough of a sign to point out  that this IP is a potential gold mine worth promoting and expanding on? That's what I want to know.Oh...yeah...this version is messed up. It's broken. This game is so buggy that the whole thing just falls apart hours in. Save data corrupted. Storyline and mission data corrupted. Gameplay corrupted. It's so sad, because it was so good. Makes me want to cry, if I had the ability to do so.Still, this thing a had so much that makes it worth bringing back. Seriously, some big game company that knows how make games that work from start to finish, buy this IP and make another title.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												The game is adequate, or at least for its time it was. It has, in my opinion, aged very poorly and will ultimately make you wish it had been made with modern technology. The combat felt clunky and kind of dull. Everything about this game looks amateur when viewed through a modern day lens. It has strong role playing elements and from what I experienced a solid story. In fact, it does role playing better than any other RPG recently released. I choose the Nosferatu breed of vampire and as the description of the class indicated, I was unable to interact with normal humans, for a single glance at my face inspired dread and fear. Because of my less than attractive features I often had to stray from the beaten path to get to objectives. I often traveled through the sewers. Getting too close to people got me a masquerade violation. The game didn't offer up easy work arounds either. It respected the fact that I had a brain and could work out my problems without a map marker. Outside of the solid story, strong role playing elements, and respect it has for the players cognitive abilities, it isn't anything special. You'll only end up wishing someone else revisited the concept with our more advanced tools.Edit: How could I forgot to mention one of the biggest problems this game has? It doesn't work on modern operating systems. You'll need to install unofficial patches if you want to even play the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 15 people (7%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Haaaa, this is a tough one.Vampires: The Masquerade is a semi-famous Pen&Paper rulebook which, duh, is about Vampires and their Masquerade to stay hidden from humanity. This game is one of the few (if not the only) PC adaption.Clear pro's of VtMB: The story is quite solid, the characters are quite finely fleshed out. The atmosphere of the game is fitting and the background&setting (naturally, when derived from a RP rulebook) nice to explore.Aaaaand, that's about it.On the other hand, the list of downsides: The game is old. Obviously this means it has an outdated graphic engine, but that really isn't a big deal (at least not to me). HOWEVER, the gameplay is as well OLD. It puts you back into the days of awful backtracking. It doesn't have all those nifty features you would be used from modern RPGs. The fights feel sluggish and uninspiring, the animations/hitboxes don't seem to match whatsoever.There are quite a few bugs in the game, too. Actually, you can't even start the game on a 64bit system unless you download yourself an unofficial patch to fix the problem. (And another to fix up the game's limited resolution options.)In total, VtMB was, no doubt, at it's release a REALLY formidable RPG with an immensely powerful and detailed background. By today's measure, however, it's barely a better interactive story teller with fundamental RPG elements.Rating: 5/10, sorry, I like the Franchise and the P&P, but the game just isn't playable past it's 'classic' valueAs such, I can only recommend this game to nostalgiast who WANT to play old games or hardcore VtM fans and only below a price of 5€.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Unless you're starved for a game to play, really like vampires, or like the universe - avoid this game. To say it's unfinished is an understatement. Given another year in development, with actual QA testing it could have been good, but as it stands it's mediocre at best. Even with the fan patches the game has quite a few issues, isn't well balanced, and just feels tedious at times.There's a lot of hype around this game, and a lot of people defend it - I thought I'd understand their devotion to the game after playing it, but... Nope. It could be that I'm indifferent to vampires in general, but I see very little value in this game - it was clearly rushed, was released too early, and/or just plain poorly executed.I wish I could add more to the review, but honestly the only impression I'm left with after beating it, is that it killed time at the best of times, and was tedious at the worst. If I had to give it a score, it'd be 4/10. There are so many better RPGs out there, and spending your time with Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines would be a waste if you aren't already a fan.

number of helpful: 3 of 21 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												I know most people will just thumb down this review without even reading it because its just one of those games where its the socially acceptable thing to love it unconditionally.. But i know a great game when i see one and this is not one of them. It is not a bad game by any regards, but it is certainly not the cult classic all the reviewers had made it seem.Its very cartoonish and arcadey and a majority of the game is spent going from A to B in mini city-like towns doing mundane quests for random NPC's with tons of loading screens inbetween. I would say 90% of the game is running back and fourth between loading screens and 10% is actual combat.The combat consists of an awkward free mouse aiming spam-clicking action onto your enemy as fast as you possibly can. Every time you hit an enemy you either knock them down or send them flying in an overly-dramatic sideways barrel-roll through the air.. It is laughable to say the least. And you will notice right away that there is no depth to the combat mechanics at all. The block is way too slow and unresponsive to be deemed worthy of any use in combat. It is also impossible to do any sort of stratgy like circle around your enemy to get behind them because they always face you no matter how fast you try and run around them..And there is no way to prepare for an enemy attack because it  occurs instantly and the game shows no animation to let you know the enemy is lifting up his arms to attack. It just happens instantly when you get near the enemy.  Not to mention the silly damage numbers that float above their head with each strike. It's is just a very hard game to reccomend to anyone over the age of 12 as it is extremely cartoonish and bubbly.Quests..some very long, very carried out, and not very specific in what you have to do. Many times you are forced to look up a walkthrough online just to figure out where to go. Each quest requires a lot of backtracking (check your email, go back to your haven and check your mailbox, go back and talk to so and so again) Not to mention that these extremely long quests only result in a mere 1-3 exp reward which is very frustrating considering you need at least 8 exp points to unlock anything worthwhile.. The only leveling up that seems to make any difference is lockpicking and hacking because strength, melee, and brawl seem to change very little in terms of the physical damage i do to my enemies. And the gun combat.. The gun combat takes the trophy for the worst gun combat i have ever seen in my 15 years of gaming. The first time i used my revolver i walked up behind an enemy, aimed it at the back of his head at close range, and when i fired i saw huge yellow letters that said "10" listing the damage amount that my shot did.. The enemy than said "Ouch" and turned around and started punching me, i than shot 5 more times and each shot showed huge yellow damage numbers. I than had to ditch the gun and just kill him with my fists. It is just so arcadey and childish. Not to mention ammo is extremely scarce.For a vampire game you would think it would be raw, mature and gritty, not bubbly and cartoonish.The textures are extremely low resolution for the date the game was released.If you are 9-13 years old i can see you enjoying this game

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												This is a cult classic game I had only heard of when I saw it on sale and figured I'd pick it up to see what the fuss was.  Admittedly, they do a very nice job of creating a dark atmosphere within the limited graphical capabilities of the time, but ultimately the game itself is unplayable.  Bugs which have persisted since release were never fixed, resulting in a lot of frustration - like the completely invisible boss I had to fight.  You can actually play this game for a while before finding out that you did the wrong sequence of highly specific things for a given character build and now you can't go any further in the game.  If they cleaned up the technical issues then this would be a pretty slick release, but as it stands it's just not worth playing.

number of helpful: 0 of 17 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												First of all games should not require any effort whatsoever beyond installing to play. None. This is on par with buying a car you have to drop an engine into so you can drive it off the lot. The fact that you have to add a mod just to make this game work is insulting. I've seen people say "oh well you didn't play this game or that game that needed this and that" and the truth is they're idiots. Because that statement and type of thinking is a logical fallacy called appeal to tradition. Just because other games sucked too has ZERO bearing on whether or not this one does. Or saying that tons of people love it so it can't suck is just appeal to the masses. Justin Bieber and Brittany Spears are millionaires with millions of fans. Are you really going to say they don't suck? The masses like garbage and we all know that. This is why and only why pop music exists.        I haven't seen one intelligent comment on why this game DOESN'T suck. The problem is that this game absolutely does suck and not in the way a Vampire game should. I began as a GM for Werewolf AND Vampire the Masquerade when they FIRST CAME OUT as a tabletop RPG's in 1991.Many people who may read this weren't even born then. Or they were far too small to be playing them. Understand this means you sorely lack the context to understand why these games suck. I watched Kindred: The Embraced religiously for the brief period it was on. It was even shot in my backyard of San Francisco. The point is I am and have been a huge Vampire fan from day one. So my hopes for this game were very high. And I was sorely disappointed.     Anyone who has been a gamer for a couple decades knows and has seen the evolution of games with super powers. From tke original Xmen Arcade game released in 1992 to the flurry of super hero games released on all consoles, it has always been hard to get super powers right. This is where this game ultimately fails unbelievably. The game does not match the tabletop RPG AT ALL when we look at starting characters and power. In this garbage you are essentially nothing more than human who has to suck blood randomly. Guns kill you, baseball bats kill you, a stiff wind kills you. I've been fascinated by vampires for 30 years and done an immense amount of research on them. And the piece of crap representation in this game fits absolutely NONE of the stories.    The fun part about playing a vampire game is the power associated with vampires. Some great examples are the Legacy of Kain series. With Legacy of Kain 2 being the crowning achievment. You start out weak but not even close to as weak as a human. The game  does a fantastic job of evolving the character to be more and more powerful as you progress. VTMB is just an utter waste of money and time. They betrayed their own tabeletops and all of us original fans. Whitewolf made the same mistake when they released the second rulebook for the tabletop game. They just tried too hard and ended up diluting the quality of the game with crap that really didnt need to be added. Take the money you would spend on this game and find "The Book of Nod" which was a companion fiction novel that is a much better way to spend your time than on this trash.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Aside from the unique game concept, a rpg about vampires in modern-day america, this game is pretty much garbage. There's very little character involvement and development. You /maybe/ have three outfits that you can earn throughout the game, and the outfits you're given pretty much suck as it is. The fighting is a bit stiff, as well as other movements in the game like talking and cutscene acting, and yes, given that this was made a while ago when software wasn't all that amazing, it still is very lacking. There's not much of a desire to go on with the story because the story in itself just isn't enthralling, or even interesting. Sure, sometimes you're a little curious as to what they mean by a few things so you go about the missions, la-dee-da without a care in the world only to, again, be let down by yet another over-used plot device. I've watched a few playthroughs of the game simply to see if it was worth finishing, and I'm not even convinced that this game entertains me when I'm bored enough to play it. Overall, I do not reccomend this game. It certainly wasn't worth the $20 I shelled out to get it, and so, I ward others away from it unless it's being offered for maybe, MAYBE, $5 or less.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Overall a very well rounded game with a great deal of replayability. The player choices are sometimes frusturatingly  limited in the main plot line, but the overall degree of control over side quests is immense. Combat options are diverse, however the endless swarms of enemies in some dungeon zones can be tiring. Overall the npcs are well rounded and believable characters. There are multiple endings, though they are not the light at the end of the tunnel. The missions along the way are more meaningful than the end result. Perhaps this games best feature is the ability to blend some modern day realism with a dose a fantasy terror. The "dungeon" areas are really not boring and offer up a challenge for several playthroughs. The environments are fairly detailed and the overall map desing usually makes sense. The older graphics also do little to diminish the gore factor in this game. Some scenes should not be redone in HD. The game is plagued with several tech issues if you are running a newer operating system. The game works fine normally if you run in compatbility mode as an admin. Also be sure not to auto-update as this can cause crashing. I also recommend downloading the unofficial patches as they really do add more depth and refinement to the overall gameplay. So wether you are a fan of "Blade" or "Twilight", then this game has something for you.

												Best game of its time, an genre, if you like vampires buy this game, you can play it the way you want it, stealthy, persuasive, or you can be a big beast that solves things with your bare hands, the skill tree in this game is big, and the possibilities of ways you can create to complete your missions, it's amazing, with 6 clans to choose, each with unique story, and you can even see the other clans that are unplayable, it's a fantastic adaption of World of Darkness, The dialogue is big, each clan and depending on what tipe of person your character is, it  can look like a totally different game. The graphics are outdated due its realease in 10 years ago, but you still get the dark feeling of the game, and the sountrack gives you an immersion in the world. The maps are detailed, with various types of stages, from Haunted Hotels to an ancient tomb with hundreds of undeads, there is SO many types of enemies to deal with, you'll hardly get bored in this game, there are a lot of side quests to complete that give you experience points to spend with your character sheet. Now the problem in this game, is being able to run in more advanced computers, due to compability problems. But there is a community forum to help you figure out what to do, there are many unnofficial patches to remove the bugs and even add some few new things to the game. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												This is apparently a sequel to Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption, hence the really long name. However don't let that put you off - this is such a great game. If you haven't got this game you must get it! I'm not a massive vampire fanatic or anything so I was skeptical at first. However this isn't your average load of vampires or vampire setting. Forget sparkly celebrities and even your average Bram Stoker vampire - these are the vampires of the present day world. The game begins in Santa Monica, CA but you are also able to travel to Downtown LA, Chinatown and Hollywood. This is where the real RPG element comes in. You choose who to work for, whether it be Prince LaCroix who technically saved your life, the Anarchs or more obscure factions. You can also choose from quite a huge choice of Bloodlines (also known as Clans - basically the equivalent to classes) which also affect what you look like and how you are treated. The game can run on pretty much any system now too! GET THIS!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game was a pleasant surprise. I picked it up on sale for next to nothing and have already invested a good 20 hours into it. I've been a fan of pretty much all of the World of Darkness game systems since I was a teenager and it's nice to see Vampire brought to life in a video game. The game does have it's issues, but they are easily overlooked. There's an unofficial patch that I downloaded that seemed to solve a majority of the glitches. I've experienced minor graphical hiccups with water textures once or twice and the controls take some getting used to, but other than that I have no real complaints. It's an older game so the graphics are a bit dated (2004 i thhink), but the story and the environment are all very immersive and the characters are believable (as far as WoD standards go) and well written. A couple of canons make an appearance as well for those of you out there who are familiar with the lore of VtM. All in all I'd say it's a great game that definitely captures the spirit of VtM. It makes me long for my days of LARPing.

content:

												Quite possibly one of my favorite games ever. No RPG before or since has nailed presentation, atmosphere, and dynamic NPCs the way this game did. You really feel like you're wrapped up in the game world, and the missions (including the overwhelmingly brilliant haunted hotel mission) are some of the best in the genre. Despite the base game's numerous bugs (it was released too early to capitalize on the Source engine before Half-Life 2), several excellent unofficial patches solve a great deal of the engine issues and add great gameplay tweaks. An absolute must-play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												While fans of the White Wolf game will enjoy this RPG, fans not familiar with the setting will still enjoy the experience.Set in modern day where vampires walk among us.  You take the role of a newly turned vampire.  Given a crash coarse in the "masquerade", the term used for not exposing vampire's existence, you're then thrust into the world of a modern day LA.  You can't just willy-nilly go on a wanton blood bath, as breaking the masquerade can have severe consequences (perma death).  There is some politics involved as you soon learn that not all vampires see eye-to-eye on everything.Game itself is skill based, but left up to the player as to what they want to do.  Want to charm you way through a lot of conversations avoiding combat as much as possible?  Sure.  Want to skip the talk and let the bloodbath begin?  If you want to. There are multiple endings, something we see more common now but was somewhat rare back in 2004.  So the game has a high replay value as you can join a different vampire clan and go a different route politically.It's too bad that CCP's World of Darkness MMO was cancelled, leaving this game as the showcase for White Wolf's world.4.5/5  (some minor glitches for the half pt off)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines is game not to be missed by RPG fans. Even after a decade, this title still holds it's own against "modern" games. From character creation to it's voice acting and storyline VtMB is a treat. Having had the chance to play this for the first time through steam, I have to say this was money well spent. Gameplay is very engaging and is most definitely worth multiple playthroughs as each class of vampire will have a VERY different experience. I'm so impressed by the multitude of paths and choices presented to the player, especially considering the release date of this game. I find myself wishing for a remake of the game but I think that it would be an impossible task to try and top a game that, not only fills what I think to be a huge void in the gaming market, but brings fantastic ideas to table and is able to execute them with such grace. 9/10 simply a must have experience for any rpg addict.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines is far from a perfect RPG experience. That being said, those who can overlook it's bugs and simple combat can find an engaging and refreshing take on the vampire genre.What Vampire does well is create an oustanding amount of compelling and interesting classes with rich backgrounds drawn from various forms of Vampire myth, as well as well written dialogue and interesting quest-design. While this may not excite the common RPG player, Vampire enthusiasts will enjoy the rich world created to explore. The various "Bloodlines" serve as both the class system as well as a twist on character's story and how they interact with the world. A noble Ventrue vampire will find manipulating vampire's of lesser bloodlines easy, while the insane Malkavian will be forced to spread mania to acomplish his or her goals. This all leads to a considerable amount of replayability amongst the different builds and bloodlines.Unfortunatly Vampire isn't without it's problems. Combat can become repetetive, especially towards the later end of the game where non-threatening enemies appear by the truckload. Bugs are relatively routine, though only one was game-breaking to the point that I had to use console commands. I did have to use an unnofficial patch from a third party site to even get the game to function on my computer, and even then I found myself having to alt-tab in order for the game's visiuals to display on the screen. Lastly visuals in the game are rather dated, but considering the age of the game, this is something the user should overlook.While Vampire won't stand out to anyone not interested in the World of Darkness, any curious Vampire enthusiasts should consider picking this game up, it's well worth it's minescule asking price. 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Wonderful game, with some amazing ideas. I very much recommend it, as it belongs in the RPG Hall of Fame, despite all its shortcomings. But remember: for all intents and purposes, this is an Early Access game, that never got finished. It lacks general polishing and bug-fixing, and the endgame was pretty much just tossed there, to have an ending at all.It will offer 25-30 hours of great fun, playing as a vampire, with a very very good RPG system under the hood. This game truly excels when doing what Vampire: The Masquerade is all about: keeping up the Masquerade, while going about your vampire business. The system forces you to be mindful of keeping your vampire existence hidden from mortals by the way of Masquerade Violations. If you commit an act that reveals you as a vampire (feeding in public, using obvious vampire powers in public, telling humans about your condition), you lose one such point, and if you lose them all, it's Game Over.The RPG system also rewards going the non-violent way in quests, as there is no experience awarded for killing things, only completing objectives - often giving higher rewards for not killing anyone. This mechanic, combined with the fact that combat is a horrible click-fest, makes it well worth it to pursue other ways of completing the quests, and using violence only when absolutely necessary. Right up until the end-game, situations where violence is the only way are few, and well placed. Going without leveling up any combat skills is a viable (although challenging) route to take right up to the "Hell at the Hotel Hallowbrook" quest during the end-game. And that quest also happens to be the part where the game pretty much starts falling apart.I keep mentioning the end-game, and for good reason: it is astonishingly bad. While up until this point the game is all about giving you choices, by the end it turns into a mindless action game with boring combat, and even more boring and repetitive boss fights. The only way through is by fighting, so all the points in Persuasion, Seduction, Stealth and other skills turn completely useless, and you are forced to kill waves after waves of enemies... The last hours of the game might as well be another game completely, and a bad one at that.My recommendation would be to play the game until you meet a taxi driver that keeps asking questions, answer him as you want, then go on YouTube and watch someone else suffer through the horrible mess the game devolves into. That way you get to enjoy all the wonders of the game, and also get to skip 1-2 hours of mind-boggling stupidity, that has nothing to do with the game you've been playing anyway.Another recommendation would be to download and install the Unofficial Patch - that fixes a lot of bugs, fixes broken parts of the game, and generally brings Bloodlines closer to feeling like a finished product.Link: http://www.moddb.com/mods/vtmb-unofficial-patchBuy the game and have fun with it!

												Well my Neonates this was bound to happen eventually I'm going to do it I'm going to take my mind and put it to reviewing.Vampire: The Masquerade-Bloodlines.So what did I note about the game,what did I take seconds to critcise under my breath when I should've been working find out now!So what was the first thing I noticed?The Lore.Oh yea this is a lore game and all the lore in this game is uber-fantastic it's rich and flavorful hell it's one of the best things in the game it gives the game boat loads of personality and more reason to play and involve yourself as much as possible it was so inviting that I actually started to roleplay as though I actually knew anything about the lore surrounding the game in the end I had to look up a lot of extra stuff.What came to be noted by me after Neonate?Well it was the gameplay.This was harder to comment on as you could play nearly anyway you wanted to by using stealth or going guns-a-blazing or if you want to to even more extreme just bare knuckly boxing the crap outta everything the gameplay is the second best feature of the game it's an encapsulating gameplay system that I love entirely.But I bring unfortunate news neonate I apologise but we do have one flaw that needs to be pointed out.The lack of customisation to the characterThis one struck me down as soon as I really noticed it and the thing is it was extremely heartbreaking for a Roleplayer like myself who loves character creation and customisations the flaw with this game not having it was they never explained why we were sired or why were dressed the way we were and not counting the other armor we can buy which looks different to the beginning equipment theres little to no character customisations,also as a side note this does not include levelling skills as that was covered above.So what do I give this epic adventure through the eyes of a Vampire well neo-nate I give it a Alright, just alright due to the lack of character customisation and a few moments in the game when you can be instantly killed and how being killed sets you back to the main menu it doesn't score higher had they let me create a custom character it would've scored at at least a Bad♥♥♥♥♥seal but then again the game is old

Posted: May 9, 2014
												Fantastic game!takes a lot of tinkering to get it to run on a modern PC tho not supported on anything post xp.but what you get when you do get it running, is a great detailed game that had a rich story and great characters. the game is pretty linear with the story with a few side quests here and there, but this game will take you quite a long time to complete if you go for 100% and you do need it, the game is hard, it doesnt hold your hand. each race of vampire gives you a different experience especially the malkavian race they are completely insane and that pours into every aspect of the game, your dialog is nuts and there are a whole managery of easter eggs just for them. the game is old but has not aged that badly, the controls and clipping can be an issue because of the games buggy nature, i recommend running with the console on for that emergency "noclip" some of the puzzles can also leave you scratching your head too. this is one of those memorable gems that keep players coming back for more. for some this game at full price may not be worth it with all the tinkering and bugs, for those of you like this pick it up on when it comes on sale, but for those who want a unique game experience or those of you who loved this game back in the day this is a must have for your collection, i spent a good 2 hours getting this to run and it was well worth it. im probably clocking over 30+ hours now, it doesnt show as you play this game from its launcher not the steam one to get it to run. loved this game as a teen in highschool love it even more now as my machine then barely ran it, was one of those games that really left me wanting to play it again and again.

												As someone who isn't a fan of anything involving vampires except for the Buffy TV series, this game was definitely a nice surprise.  The game's structure is similar to the Deus Ex series, complete with hub areas, RPG elements, and the ability to direct conversations in different ways.  The combat does show its age due to the simplicity, but the story and character writing are really where this game shines.  I found the deep vampire lore to be very interesting without being off-putting.  Overall, if you're a fan of games like Deus Ex, do give this game a chance, especially since YouTube videos don't really do it justice.

												Bought this when it was first released (as an avid White Wolf RPG player of old, couldn't resist)..  Back then, it was so bug ridden it was unplayable.  I'd since lost the CD and forgot about it until a friend said it was back on track..And so it is, with a vengeance!  There are still oddities to it, and a few glitches, but nothing that really holds you back..Some may point out that the graphics are a little dated by today's AAA standard.. Well, so are the graphics in a damn good book, and I'd much prefer a damn good book to a glitzy all-flash-and-no-s♥♥♥♥♥n title..  Books and well spun tales are so much better to digest.  And they're more chewy into the bargain.The story, all important in a good RPG is all there in all its glory, warts and all..  Some things you see coming.  Some things see you coming.  And they often don't play nicely.  Which makes for lots of fun!The fact you can get to play one of the Malkavians is cherry on the proverbial porcupine.  Or was it cake.. Can't remember.  Either way, something crunchy and squishy.  With a hat.

												I don't recommend games often but this one deserves it. I was skeptical to even start playing simply because it was vampires and lets face it vampires aren't something that's considered very cool nowadays. This game will change your mind, vampires are badass. The game offers an extremely rich lore and replay value that will keep you coming back for more. Most of the negative reviews are about the fact that it's very difficult to get to run on a modern machine, which I'll give them that. It took me an hour or so before I could get the game running with very few crashes at 1080p, but the hour or two that it takes you to do that is well worth it. I got the game when it was on sale for $5, but I would gladly have bought it at full price had I known how delicious it was. 10/10 GOTY 2014

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												It is a great classic RPG, even though the graphics and certain gameplay mechanics are outdated.  It did have an issue installing on my PC(Windows 8), and you have to adjust for compatibility with Windows XP Service Pack 3 for it to start properly.  Overall, it was very fun and I would recommend it to anyone who may or may not be a fan of this franchise.  My main issue with this game was the old graphics.  There's patches and unofficial mods you can get to boost the resolution and graphics qualities, but I never looked into those.  I didn't have a problem that the game is older and isn't HD by any means, but I couldn't adjust the quality at all and some of the finer details of the game are lost from the lack of visual quality.  It doesn't keep you from playing the game to its fullest extent, it just makes it a little challenging at times reading signs, or looking for tiny details.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone.  I got this game on sale and my first playthrough took around 25 hours.  It's definitely worth the time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 19, 2011
												This is a good, if a bit old, RPG, that simply lets your imagination run wild.  There is plenty to say about it, but I'll try to keep it brief, and the awesomeness can be summed up easily:  "You get to play as a VAMPIRE".  Not pansy♥♥♥♥♥Twilight sparkle vampires, but bloodthirsty, bullet-resistant, cursed with awesome (and a curse) vampires.  Gameplay-wise it's a bit of a balancing act, with some abilities far more valuable than others (at least in some situations).  For example, a number of the vampire bloodlines have magical abilities that allow them to magically dominate, or insta-kill, or otherwise be extremely powerful against human enemies.  BUT, are not nearly as effective against the supernatural.  Otherwise, I have typically found a few solutions to most every quest, and while the areas available aren't huge, you're quite free to play as you please in them, and that freedom you are granted is rare in modern games.  Which is why I suggest this, not so new, but good, game.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												This game was a pleasant surprise. I picked it up on sale for next to nothing and have already invested a good 20 hours into it. I've been a fan of pretty much all of the World of Darkness game systems since I was a teenager and it's nice to see Vampire brought to life in a video game. The game does have it's issues, but they are easily overlooked. There's an unofficial patch that I downloaded that seemed to solve a majority of the glitches. I've experienced minor graphical hiccups with water textures once or twice and the controls take some getting used to, but other than that I have no real complaints. It's an older game so the graphics are a bit dated (2004 i thhink), but the story and the environment are all very immersive and the characters are believable (as far as WoD standards go) and well written. A couple of canons make an appearance as well for those of you out there who are familiar with the lore of VtM. All in all I'd say it's a great game that definitely captures the spirit of VtM. It makes me long for my days of LARPing.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines is game not to be missed by RPG fans. Even after a decade, this title still holds it's own against "modern" games. From character creation to it's voice acting and storyline VtMB is a treat. Having had the chance to play this for the first time through steam, I have to say this was money well spent. Gameplay is very engaging and is most definitely worth multiple playthroughs as each class of vampire will have a VERY different experience. I'm so impressed by the multitude of paths and choices presented to the player, especially considering the release date of this game. I find myself wishing for a remake of the game but I think that it would be an impossible task to try and top a game that, not only fills what I think to be a huge void in the gaming market, but brings fantastic ideas to table and is able to execute them with such grace. 9/10 simply a must have experience for any rpg addict.
